story:
Here is Our Story

After Tartuffe is a critically acclaimed dystopian reboot of Moliere's scathing satire of religious hypocrites set in a an uncomfortably close future America where extremists have actualized the darkest dreams of Christian Fundamentalists.  
We presented After Tartuffe at the NYC Fresh Fruit Festival 2015 (LGBT focused theatre festival) to a wide audience and much critical acclaim.  Due to the overwhelmingly enthusiastic reception, we have decided to pursue backers who would fund a  full production.  We feel passionately about this new, powerful, and dynamic play and feel that it is a must to bring to wider audiences.
Please help the sassy, sexy, and smart maid;  the sweet and spicy matriarch with a mission; and the young lovers all defeat the Tartuffery of Reverend Pusser!
Here's what theatre critic Ed Malin of NY Theatre Now said about our play.  Read the review HERE.

The cast includes experienced NY stage actors.

  • Don Carter ... Reverend Chadwick Pusser
  • Sean Griffin ... Daniel
  • Bonnie Cannon-Brown ... Doreen
  • Daniel Hawk Hicks ... Oral
  • Mary Monahan ... Alma
  • Pamela Joy ... Mary-Anne
  • Cynthia Shaw ... Grandma
  • Bruce Jones ... Tyler
  • Ali Andre Ali ... Vaughn
Production Team

  • Judy Klass (Playwright/Producer)
  • Janet Bentley ( Director, Costumes, Props)
  • Andy Evan Cohen (Sound Design)
  • Page Clements  (Dialect/Voice)
  • Gilbert "Lucky" Pearto (Lighting Designer)
  • Al Foote III (Photography) 

The performers have worked in such NY theaters and with theater companies:   The Articulate Theatre, T. Schreiber Studios, Nylon Fusion, Ensemble Studio Theatre, The Drilling Company, Blue Coyote Theatre Group, Berkshire Theatre Festival, The Theatre Row United Solo Show, to name a few.  

What We Are Planning

We want to raise $5000 for a backers audition, to support a fully mounted production with a solid run.  
Specifically the $5000 will go to:
rehearsal space, the theatre performance space, costumes, makeup, sound, lighting, and set design. 
Payments for playwright, director, designers, stage managers, and actors
In the tragic event that we do not reach our goal all of the funds will go towards launching our backers audition which is already scheduled for December 17 at a prestigious NY off-Broadway theater.
Our ultimate goal is to present this play in an off-Broadway production.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand if you are unable to financially contribute but there are so many awesome ways; share this link with your friends, follow, like, and share us on Facebook and Twitter!
The more noise that you help us create about After Tartuffe the more likely our production will become a reality.

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! 

It's us from Impulse Theatre from beautiful Victoria, British Columbia. We are a multidisciplinary theatre company that strives to create transformative live performances that weave contemporary myth with visual depth. We invite the audience to participate in their own interpretation. We have been creating work since 2010 with over fifteen new works.

One of our dearest projects is ana, the focus of this very campaign. ana is a collaborative creation between myself, Andrew Barrett, and Emily Piggford, a Victoria-born, now Toronto-based, actress. Our collaborative team also features the work of designer Halley Fulford and composer Aulden MacQueen-Denz. ana is our theatrical response to the rampant violence against and persecution of those deemed feminine in society. The catalyst for the project came from musicians CocoRosie's own response to the story of a young girl named Lama Al-Ghamdi. Lama was repeatedly raped and tortured by her father before she succumbed to her wounds and passed away. He was tried and chose the option of paying blood money to her mother's family, but was only required to pay half the normal amount because she was not a boy. CocoRosie created a song and eulogy for Lama entitled Ana Lama, after the hashtag #AnaLama that erupted on Twitter following Lama’s story. #AnaLama means “I am Lama.”

After discovering CocoRosie and the work of their friends, the Future Feminists, I approached Emily about creating this solo work with her. We developed it initially in the Petri Dish Residency of Intrepid Theatre's Winterlab Festival (January 2014). We continued to develop the project through Intrepid Theatre's Uno Works program (May 2014), then Impulse Theatre's own two week workshop intensive (January 2015). The final phase of development will take place at the acclaimed Videofag in Toronto, finally returning to Victoria to premiere at Intrepid Theatre's Uno Fest at the end of May. We have had incredible support so far through Intrepid Theatre and our whole creative team, but we need your help to finish the work that has been started and so that we may officially launch this piece on the world! In doing so we will contribute to the positive evolution of our society towards one that is far more respectful of the feminine.

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign will allow us to complete the project and cover the costs of hiring and working with the incredibly dedicated team that we have. All funds gathered, even if we don't make our goal, will go directly to the team who have donated much of their time already to bringing ana's story to life.
ana's expenses
  • PROFESSIONAL FEES - $2,800
  • PRODUCTION COSTS - $600
  • ADMINISTRATIVE/INDIEGOGO COSTS - $600
  • IN-KIND REHEARSAL SPACE - $1,000
  • TRAVEL - $2,250
TOTAL EXPENSE - $7,250
ana's revenues
  • GUARANTEES - $2,300
  • FUNDRAISERS/PRIVATE DONATIONS - $1,200
  • IN-KIND REHEARSAL SPACE - $1,000
  • INDIEGOGO - $2,750
TOTAL REVENUE - $7,250
We have created some wonderful perks to help you feel that you are a part of the process, because you are! We know not everyone will be able to come see ana live, so the perks are a way we can share the experience and essence of the show with you in other ways, whether it's through music, video, writings or items! 
And for the perks above $150, we will give a portion of your donation to Girls Not Brides, a organization devoted to bringing child marriage to global attention, and to build an understanding of what it will take to end child marriage. 

The Impact

ana encapsulates our reaction to what is happening in the world right now. We have created a primary titular character, who acts as an arbiter for multiple feminine personalities. This being has reached their breaking point and has come to an audience in a call for action. This work is a union of emotion, ceremony, violence, and rebellion. We use physical theatre, song, dance, and design to bring each face of ana to life.

Our long term goal is to tour ana and to share it with as many people as we can. By contributing to this campaign, you become part of the conversation on how we can change the world. We will also keep you in the loop--letting you know when ana comes to your city and how the project and its themes evolve over time through other mediums.

Impulse Theatre is continuously analyzing itself and moving forward. We create work that isn't afraid to be vulnerable. We have recently incorporated and have founded a Board of Directors who believes in the work and stands behind it. Join us in moving forward. 

Risks & Challenges

The risks and challenges of creating this piece lie innately within its very content-- the truths that we are exploring are largely unpleasant. The challenges we face, then, are how to sculpt a visceral piece that implicates the audience, inciting change, without being didactic or exclusive? We have been working these past two years to find the right balance of vulnerability, inclusion, fact and hope. Our penultimate workshop at Videofag is a pivotal opportunity for our team to solidify the structure. We have such passion for the project and what it stands for that we are confident we will have a powerful piece to premiere, yet getting there is still certainly an exciting challenge. We appreciate every ounce of your support along the way!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please do not hesitate to share ana through your social networks. Send us to your friends, families, and artistic communities. We want to get the word out and share the work with the world! Share Emily's videos, our trailers, buy tickets, volunteer for Uno Fest, or even send us a message (impulse.theatre.email@gmail.com).

story:
Will You Please Shut Up? a one-act by Dan O'Brien

Hi there! My name is Sarah Wax and I'm a sophomore at Wesleyan University in Middletown, CT. A theater lover, I’ve been involved in more than 35 plays and musicals over the course of the last 15 years. I’m hoping to make my Wesleyan directorial debut by independently producing Dan O’Brien’s one-act play, “Will You Please Shut Up?”

The show will go up April 14-16th in Alpha Delta Phi’s Greene Room (185 High Street) in Middletown, CT.

A 40 to 50 minute two-person play, “Will You Please Shut Up?” explores the absurdities of modern relationships. Moving backward through the lives of Sylvia and Tom, the play begins with the exes’ unexpected reunion and traces their crumbling relationship. Through complicated text and weird, complex characters, “Will You Please Shut Up?” uses humor to examine the difficulties and consequences of deep love, resulting in a hilarious and absurd, yet poignant, production.


What We Need & What You Get

Through the help of many individuals (including YOU!), I’m hoping to bring to life a play, which I love and admire, to the Wesleyan community! As an independently produced play, however, we need to fundraise enough money to finance the production.

Here’s where your generous donations will be going:

  • Performance rights – $120 for three performances

  • Scripts – $40

  • Posters and Programs – $240

  • Props – $100

Our most generous donors ($50+) will receive a personalized “Thank You” and digital copies of the performance poster and program. Any contribution, no matter how small, is greatly appreciated and beneficial toward our goal. Please do not underestimate the value of a dollar!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a monetary donation, we would greatly appreciate if you simply spread the word (on social media platforms) and shared this campaign with your friends and family! Thank you so much for helping us make this project happen!


Our Team

Sarah Wax – Director/Producer

Claire Shaffer – Stage Manager/Producer

Ali Arminio – Public Relations Manager

Ian Rice – Master Electrician and Projection Designer

Blake Pritchard – Master Electrician and Projection Designer

Kira Newmark – Sound Designer

Lila Levinson – Costume Designer

Alison Silverstein – Props Designer

Daniel Gordon – Assistant Stage Manager

story:
The Story

The age of Japanese movie monsters is fading, and Godzilla is living high off the millions he's made over years of trampling Tokyo.  It's been easy for him to forget all the little people that have made him who he is today, but they haven’t forgotten him, and some are bearing grudges...

"YOU CAN’T BEAT GODZILLA!" is a dark comedy about four has-been movie monsters that have failed in their screen careers and are now stuck in dead end jobs and poor living conditions to make ends meet.  While they look and act human, they each have a physical element to them to insinuate their “monster status” (one has a horn, the other is covered in body hair, etc.)  In a demented sort of “Wizard of Oz” type scenario, the monsters grow tired of the poverty and humiliation they've endured and form a plan to find Godzilla, rob him and bring him down once and for all.  Their “yellow brick road” presents obstacles, however, and their journey proves to be more difficult than they all hoped.

The play makes numerous references to pop culture and satirizes the entertainment industry every step of the way.  Audiences will enjoy the show because it speaks to our greatest fear (failure), and they’ll be particularly entertained when King Kong, one of the monsters involved in the plan earns a spot on the game show “The Price is Right.”  The play calls for multiple viewings and contains humor to fit everyone’s tastes.

                                       

How You Can Help

What started out as a popular workshop production has evolved into something that’s ready to go on tour, and with the latest Godzilla film coming out, NOW just seems like the perfect time.  Our initial start-up goal is $15,000 which will be dispersed in the following ways:

Theatres and rehearsal space ($6,000);

Pay and travel accommodations for cast and crew ($2,000);

Costumes and props ($500);

Publicity and promotion ($1,500);

Insurance ($1,500);

Sets ($500);

Miscellaneous expenditures (we all know they come up, and it's better to be safe than sorry -- $3,000);

With Godzilla taking over the red carpet this summer, our friends have had enough of the big lizard hogging the spotlight, and they want their chance to steal the show.  Perks range from having one’s name in the program to attending a champagne party with the monsters (you’re bringing the champagne, right?  These guys are too broke to have ever tried it).

Hey, with enough luck the story of these guys will make it to the big screen, someday… Wouldn’t that be a "monstrous" comeback??

                               

THE TEAM:

NICK MARINOFF is the writer and creator of “You Can’t Beat Godzilla!"  He has been working professionally in film, television and theatre for over 10 years.  Regional credits:  1776, The King & I, Peter Pan (Cabrillo Music Theatre); Oliver! (Colony Theatre); Much Ado About Nothing and Duchess of Nowhere (Ark Theatre Company).  Nick is the recipient of a Body Shop Award for “Outstanding Achievement in Musical Theatre” and a Four-Star Theatre Alliance Award for “Best Lead Actor” for his portrayal of the title character in Sweeney Todd.  Notable film appearances:  Anacapa, Unravel, 7-10 Split, Blackout, Terezin (official selection – Bel-Air Film Festival), Washed Up (Audience Choice Award winner for “Best Film of the Year,” Oceanside Int’l Film Festival; official selection – American Independent Film Festival).  Nick also starred in Under Surveillance and Masquerade (which he also co-wrote).  Both films premiered at the Santa Barbara Int’l Film Festival in 2011 and 2012, respectively.  Television:  The Wedding Bells (FOX), opposite Missi Pyle.  Commercials, industrials, voice-overs.  Proud member of SAG-AFTRA.

                                      

BRIAN MACK is a a member of Charlatan Studios, a film collaboration which has produced over two dozen short films, one of which won "Best Low Budget Short Film" at the Palm Springs International Shortfest in 2009, an award co-sponsored by director Jason Reitman.  In addition, several more of Charlatan Studios' shorts have screened in festivals around the U.S., with two more shorts in post-production and several long form projects in development. Brian serves as Charlatan Studios' producer, writer, and occasional director and actor in their films.  Brian has also written and directed several one-act plays. More on Brian and his work can be found here:

http://www.wearecharlatans.com

And on his website:

http://www.charlatanstudios.com

                              

LORNA BOWEN has worked as a theatrical director, producer, and costumer for over a decade.  Her directing and producing credits include 110 in the Shade, Man of La Mancha, It’s a Wonderful Life and The Diviners.  Her costuming credits include productions of Les Miserables, Jekyll & Hyde, Sweeney Todd, Noises Off, Fiddler on the Roof and the recent film The Hit Girl (Silver Screen Award, Nevada Film Festival; official selection – Action on Film Int’l Film Festival).  She is a three time recipient of the coveted Four-Star Theatre Alliance Award for her work and dedication to the stage.  Her most cherished creation is her daughter Ella.

                             

A Final Note...

Can’t contribute?  Don't worry.  If anyone gets it, it's THESE guys!  You can put them back in the limelight by getting the word out about the show!  

The monsters thank you in advance!

contribute?  Don't worry.  If anyone gets it, it's THESE guys!  You can put them back in the limelight by getting the word out about the show!  The monsters thank you in advance!

story:
Who is Project: Motion and What is PROMenade?

Project: Motion is a Memphis-based not-for-profit modern dance collective devoted to the creation and presentation of innovative, well-crafted dance works that inspire, stimulate and engage audiences on an intellectual, emotional and physical level. Project: Motion fosters artistic collaborations and provides a forum for local dance artists to experiment, develop skills and hone artistic vision in a nurturing and challenging environment. We are Memphis’ longest running modern dance collective!

PROMenade is sure to be the ultimate performance party and will be presented on the evening of May 31st, 2014, at Co-Motion Studio in the Crosstown neighborhood. Guests are invited to relive their proms, create new prom memories, and experience the one of a kind performance that only Project: Motion can offer. PROMenade will showcase premier works by Project:Motion choreographers and community collaborators that seek to capture and present the rich tales of prom through the words and experiences of community members.

What We Need

  • Publiciity and Graphic Design
  • Set Materials and Costumes
  • Printing and Signage
  • Theater, Rehearsal, and Venue Rental
  • Dancer and Choreographer Fees

The Impact

The 2013-2014 season for Project: Motion was a successful departure from our theater roots as we sought to mobilize our talents into the community. Project Motion was a featured arts group in ArtsMemphis' Beauty and the Feast culinary series where a new site specific work "Soul Burger" was performed at the famous Ernestine and Hazels for a sold out audience of over 100. I Project: Motion was also invited back to the Woodruff-Fontaine Home to present dances at the first "Dead Poets Dinner", a fundraising soiree for the historical home and part of the home's "Haunted Happening" series of events. Finally, Project: Motion presented several flash mob performances including a festive "Twas The Night Before Christmas" which was toured around the Cooper-Young area in December.

In addition to our various performances throughout the city, Project: Motion continues its commitment to engage our community by offering a wide range of technique classes taught by rotating instructors that are offered twice a week. Project: Motion dances for the Memphis community and we covet the active support of the community in the creation and presentation of dance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make some noise about our campaign by sharing with friends.
  • Be our PROM guest on May 31, 2014 as we present PROMenade, a performance party!
  • Come to modern dance classes 10 am Saturdays and 7:00 pm Mondays at Theatreworks

story:
Chairness Productions Presents Eurydice by Sarah Ruhl

Eurydice, by Pulitzer Prize nominee Sarah Ruhl, is a bittersweet and off-beat retelling of the classic love story of Orpheus and Eurydice; this time through the perspective of the departed heroine, Eurydice. After her arrant death on her wedding day, Eurydice finds herself in an aphasic underworld, where she reunites with her father while struggling to reconcile with her lost love, Orpheus.
L.A. Based Director Joe McCormack Estrella brings a darker view of a world without Eurydice. We are working with a skillful cast of actors as well as an incredibly talented local band named Titus ("Dead To Me" and "Venus") to bring a production of Eurydice that nobody has ever seen before.   

What We Need and How You Can Help

We estimate that we need to raise $6,000 USD to put up the absolute best version of this production. With your support we will be able to fund the costumes, set, design, music, the rights to the script, and other essential production needs. Without your help, we will be unable to fully realize our artistic goal for this production. This means reducing some of the more fantastical elements that we have worked hard to develop. When Sarah Ruhl developed Eurydice, she opened up the piece as a designer's playground. Please help us fulfill the author's desires, as well as bring to life a beautiful landscape for you, our audience, to experience. 

The Cast

EURYDICE: Katarina Flavin
ORPHEUS: Zach David
FATHER: Paul Carpenter
BIG STONE: Daniel Rivera
LITTLE STONE: Lauren Tyni
LOUD STONE: Paige-Logan
INTERESTING MAN: Ben Blonigan
CHILD/HADES: Brian Tran
ENSEMBLE STONE: Rosa Sandoval
Original Music performed live by TITUS 

Other Ways YOU Can Help!

-Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social media platform.

-Email this campaign to friends, family or anyone else interested in this project!

-Come see the Production at the Secret Rose Theater, August 1st, 2nd, & 3rd.


Thank you,
Chairness Productions
www.chairnessproductions.com
www.facebook.com/chairnessproductions

story:
So... What About Love?

Created by Andrew Chandler, Amy Reitsma and Garry Williams

Presented by Ambushed Theatre in the Victoria Fringe Festival under special permission from DaPoPo Theatre.

Directed by R.J. Peters

Choreographed by Brittney Wernicke

Music Direction by Avery Brennan

Starring Avery Brennan, Mark Dozlaw and Brittney Wernicke

Piano Accompaniment by Matty Poon

Produced by Avery Brennan and Brittney Wernicke

TICKETS NOW ON SALE AT 

http://sa1.seatadvisor.com/sabo/servlets/EventSearch?presenter=INTREPID&event=ABOUTLOV

Ambushed Theatre is an ad-hoc group of professional artists producing this new version of a Canadian musical. So... What About Love?  was originally presented by DaPoPo Theatre in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Its first incarnation was created in just five days and presented in the Atlantic Fringe Festival. This production will mark its first performance on the west coast, as well as its first performance by another theatre company, arranged through special permission from DaPoPo Theatre. Both groups believe it is important for this piece to be performed to a new audience, with a new set of artists, and with further revisions in order to continue to develop the show. Throughout the process, Garry Williams (one of the show's creators and the artistic director of DaPoPo Theatre) will be working with Ambushed Theatre to revise and tweak the show. Read on, to learn what you can help bring to life on stage. 

So...What About Love? follows three actors presenting a series of songs, scenes and monologues discussing different topics about love. Meeting someone new, getting through a breakup, casual sex, marriage, being happy with being single and many other topics are covered in hilarious and, at times, tear-jerking ways.

With an awesome script, a talented cast and some brilliant collaboration, we plan to pull this off without a hitch! The only place we fall short, is our financials. In order to continue production of our show we need to cover the expenses. Here's what we need to achieve.


$600 – Victoria Fringe Fee

$150 – Sets/Props/Costumes

$200 -  Marketing/Printing Fees

$1050 – Artist Fees

$2000 - Total

Our costs are very humble, as it is a very minimalistic show. However, we still need all the support we can get to offset the costs. You can get some great rewards for donating, too!

Come join us as we learn what love is all about, and develop a new Canadian musical!

Performed at the Langham Court Theatre (805 Langham Court) at the follow times:

Friday, August 22nd – 8:00pm

Saturday, August 23rd – 6:30pm

Sunday, August 24th – 3:00pm

Monday, August 25th – 9:45pm

Saturday, August 30th – 9:45pm

Sunday, August 31st – 2:30pm

story:
Dear Yes supporters,

As we all know a Yes vote this September is vital.

Like you, I have been doing everything I can to bring about the transformation that Scotland needs. Along with thousands of fellow activists, I’ve been charging about the country shouting my face off about the benefits of independence, at rallies and meetings and events from Orkney to Oban, St Andrews to Stirling. None of us make any money from such things; any we do make usually goes straight back into the pot.  You’ll only ever hear me do one yell out for financial aid and here it is:

please help me fund a play I intend to stage at the Edinburgh Fringe this August - a month ahead of the referendum - rallying for a Yes vote.

The play is called The Pure, the Dead and the Brilliant, and it’s a cracker (he said, modestly). It’s heartfelt, it’s steeped in Scottish folklore, it takes a long hard look at the referendum whilst also (hopefully) making you laugh till you cry. The idea is to bring Don’t Knows closer to the Yes side, whilst also giving everyone a damn good night out at the theatre. The script is written, and we’ve got a venue and a cast of some of the best actors in Scotland (seriously – some BRILLIANT people involved). All we need is confirmation of the funds.

I’m personally taking no payment for the script, and will be putting quite a bit of my own money into the production.  But I can’t expect actors, a director, a venue, a costume designer, technicians and leaflet-printers to do the same!  These things have to be paid for, and I can’t afford them all.

So if you can share this post far and wide with your Yes-supporting friends it will help make possible my own big, final push for independence, close to the referendum, on a great big platform at the world’s largest arts festival, where everyone will want to hear what Scotland has to say about the biggest issue we’ve all faced in three hundred years.

There are all sorts of goodies available depending on the size of your donation, from £10 to £1500. You could nab youself a book, free tickets, a signed, framed copy of my poem ‘Vote Britain’, or even a cameo role in the play!

The first pledge has already been made from legendary Trainspotting author, Irvine Welsh, who has given us his backing and The Scotsman are already trailing the show.

Without your help we cannot stage this play.  With your support we can produce a play that’s going to knock people’s socks off, and get them believing in Yes in the countdown to that crucial vote.

Thank you for taking the time to read this.

Alan Bissett

PRAISE FOR ALAN BISSETT’S PREVIOUS PLAYS:

“**** This is brilliant stuff, an exhilaratingly fresh take on the whole business of class and culture in Scotland. It’s also so funny that some in the audience were literally shouting with laughter.” - The Scotsman, on The Moira Monologues

‘***** Alan Bissett’s new drama is an equally hilarious series of monologues all played by Bissett himself, but this time with a political edge.’ - The Skinny on The Red Hourglass

‘**** A real Fringe gem: Bissett writes with eagle-eyed vim.’ - The Independent on The Moira Monologues.

‘**** Hugely funny and thought-inducing…Bissett seems to be having a ball. This is smart stuff.’ - The Times on Ban This Filth!

‘***** focuses fiercely on a single aspect of Scotland’s myth-making about itself, tells its story with pace and economy and delivers a real and frightening dramatic punch….short and brilliant…the games Bissett plays with language are dazzling.’ - The Scotsman on Turbo Folk.

‘*****Exudes the same sort of self-assurance as Gregory Burke’s debut, Gagarin Way…You can see real talent at work here.’ -Metro, on The Ching Room

‘**** It’s exciting, totally absorbing theatre.’ - City Life, Manchester, on The Ching Room

‘***** Thought-provoking and hilarious…incredibly powerful.’  - The Arts Desk on Ban This Filth!

‘*****Whip-smart, distinctly Scottish humour.’ -  Fest Magazine on The Red Hourglass

story:
video by Chris Hatcher Pictures


Update: An incredibly generous donor from last year's campaign has agreed to donate the final $1,000 to this year's fundraiser, but only if we bring the campaign total to $5,000 by Monday, August 27th. YOU can help us get there!

Summary:

Please support Conspire Theatre’s life-changing workshops for women inside the Travis County Correctional Complex.

Conspire Theatre, a sponsored project of the Austin Creative Alliance, offers incarcerated women and their allies a healing and empowering experience through theatre and creative writing. For three years, we’ve been running Rehearsing Possibilities, a successful theatre and creative writing program for women in minimum and maximum security at the Travis County Correctional Complex (TCCC) near Austin, Texas.

Thanks to last year's campaign, this year we served more women than ever before.

Rosa, a Conspire alum, says:

I know how powerful your class was for me and I believe that other women just like myself could use someone to believe in them… [Conspire] unlocks doors that have been locked for so many years and allows us to be who we really are. My confidence, since truly opening up in Conspire, has helped me through some rough, emotional, lonely times.

Since 2009, we’ve brought creative expression and hope to over 200 incarcerated women, expanded our programming, and are working to gain independent 501c3 status. We did this all on a shoestring budget, donating our skills and services for many months at a time, while working other jobs.

IMAGINE what we could do if we had more funding?

We need YOUR help to keep our momentum strong. To continue our programs for another twelve months, we must raise $6,000 to pay our highly skilled workshop facilitators, purchase class supplies, and apply to be our own 501c3. Many women need the unique services that Conspire offers.

Our Story:

In 2008, Executive Director Kat Craft trained with the London based company Clean Break, which offers theatre programming to incarcerated women in the UK. Inspired by Clean Break’s positive impact on women’s lives, she returned to Austin and founded Conspire Theatre in the summer of 2009.
 
Associate Director Michelle Dahlenburg came on board in July of 2011, and really helped Conspire step up its game. Through Kat and Michelle’s combined efforts, Conspire has served over two hundred women in Austin and Del Valle, has a new website, a new logo, been featured several times in Austin media, and is well on its way to having a comprehensive curriculum tailored to incarcerated women’s needs – and that’s just since last October!

Community Impact:

Texas currently incarcerates over 12,000 women, many of whom have experienced childhood abuse and domestic violence. Criminal justice scholar Dana DeHart states, "programs suited for men often fail to address the pervasive physical and sexual victimization that has riddled the lives of women in prison.”

Incarcerated women need support services that mitigate the effects of trauma and stress, allow for community building, and focus on future success in parenting, career, and relationships. Programs tailored to address these needs are often discontinued for budgetary reasons. The vast majority of incarcerated women are released back into society still lacking the skills and support systems they need.

Conspire Theatre provides incarcerated women with this support by working to build a supportive and safe community in which women can reach beyond their past experiences, and work together to create creative solutions and effective coping skills.

The population we reach at the TCCC is largely underserved. In our 2012 program year, 94% of our workshop attendees did not graduate from college and 38% did not complete high school. 79% were mothers, and 4% were pregnant while incarcerated.In 2011-2012, 30% of women in Conspire were Latina, 35% were Caucasian and 22% were African-American, along with smaller percentages of Middle Eastern, Asian and ethnically mixed women. Most were awaiting trial or serving short-term sentences for nonviolent, substance abuse related offenses.

How You Can Help:

Make a donation of any amount – we welcome the very large to the very small! If you can’t donate, please spread the word. Post this on your Facebook page, tweet the campaign or share it on Tumblr. All of our perks come straight from the heart; we love our donors and the women in our classes are always so thrilled to hear about our fund raising efforts.

 

Thanks so much!

story:
My decision to choreograph and live an artist's life is due wholly to Dan Wagoner's mentorship while a student at Florida State University. For this, and all he is as an individual and dance maker - I love him. How quickly time passes, while we are busy choreographing our lives. We are ephemeral; the time is now. This project is my best effort to encapsulate a small part of the man that has taught and inspired me and many others to live a poetic life inspite of fear.

                                                                                  - Fletcher, 2012

What We Need: 

Travel Airfare - 5 x $500 (estimated cost of round trip ticket) = $2500

Film-makers pay - 2 x $750 = $1500

Dancer pay - 2 x $400 = $800

Per diem - 5 x 5 days x $25 a day = $625

Honorarium for Dan Wagoner - $500
 
Honorarium for Michelle Fletcher - $500
 
Car Rental - $275

Equipment - $300

Editing - $500 

Total - $7,500

The Impact:

HNDC and Director Michelle Fletcher have tackled many dance for camera films, but none have felt as important as this project. There are many dance students out there (NYC, San Francisco, London, etc...) who do not know who Dan Wagoner is. Yet he is part of them, influencing the way they move at this very moment. Which leads to the core thrust of this project - Mentorship/dance parent vs. emulation vs. dance appropriation - all just acts of love? This dance film is a love letter to Dan and all those who crave to have a tangible artifact of him, besides their own body memory of what Dan has taught us.

Who's Involved:

Michelle Fletcher - Director/Choreographer
Fletcher lives in San Francisco, participating fully in the SF art community as a choreographer, director, student, teacher, and writer. Fletcher founded Here Now Dance Collective in 2008 and consistently creates new work with the company. Recognized for her multi-media, post-modern "dance-theater" work that often explores themes personal to "the human experience" her company (HNDC) is engaged to perform across the country.  Fletcher has received prestigious awards including The Zellerbach Family Foundation Grant, The Margaret Jenkins’ Dance Lab CHIME Grant and The Graduate Teaching Award from Florida State University.  Fletcher received her BFA from North Carolina School of the Arts and her MFA from Florida State University.
 
Matt Barkin - Film-maker/Collaborator
Barkin lives and works in San Francisco where he has produced film and video work ranging from documentaries and promotional videos to short and feature narrative films. He is now attending the Academy of Art, pursuing his MFA in Directing and managing his own business - Vibrant Films.

Michelle Kinny - Dancer/Collaborator
Kinny received her BFA in dance from Florida State University and her high school diploma from North Carolina School of the Arts. Upon completion of her administrative internship with the Mark Morris Dance Group, she was involved in a variety of companies and projects in NYC including Vessel Dance and Fusion Danceworks. Before relocating to San Francisco, Kinny worked in an orphanage in Huancayo, Peru teaching dance and yoga.

Matthew Lewis - Film-maker/Photographer/Collaborator
Lewis first fell in love with photography hand developing his prints in the dark room. After graduating with a degree in Film from Full Sail University in Orlando, FL, Lewis made his way back home to California. Currently, Lewis works as a lighting technician and designer for the production company Lights West. Lewis also freelances as a photographer, camera man, and media designer.  
 
Andrew Chapman - Dancer/Collaborator
Chapman received his BFA from the School of Dance at Florida State University and currently works as a free lance dancer in NYC. During his time at FSU, Chapman was able to perform Wagoner's "Round This World Baby Mine" which makes working on this project a very special endeavor. Andy thanks Michelle Fletcher for being a sassy, diva Leo and for including him on this adventure to the home of their favorite West Virginia Man.

 More about Dan Wagoner:

Dan Wagoner, a renowned American modern dance choreographer, was a principal dancer in the Martha Graham Company, the Merce Cunningham Company, and The Paul Taylor Company from 1958 to 1968. He then became Artistic Director/Choreographer and Principal Dancer for his own New York-based company, Dan Wagoner & Dancers from 1969 to 1994. He choreographed more than 55 dances for his company, performing throughout the U.S., Canada, South America, Europe, and Asia as well as presenting annual seasons in New York. Over the lifespan of his company’s existence, Wagoner received numerous national and foundation grants, including multiple NEA grants.

 

Wagoner became Artistic Director of London Contemporary Dance Theatre, London, England from1989 to 1991. He was responsible for teaching, touring, dancing, and choreographing new work for the company, setting some of his existing repertory on the company, and directing the company in the repertory of other artists. At the time of Wagoner's artistic directorship, L.C.D.T. had been in existence for over twenty years and was considered to be one of the most prestigious modern companies in Europe.

 

As well as the numerous guest artist residencies that Dan Wagoner taught in the course of the touring life of his company, Dan Wagoner & Dancers, Dan has taught at Harvard Summer Dance, Bates Summer Dance programs, and at numerous universities and festivals in the U.S. and abroad.

 

From 1995–2005 Wagoner was a Distinguished Guest Artist Professor, Department of Dance, Connecticut College, where he was responsible for teaching repertory, composition, and modern technique. He is currently a Professor of Dance at the Florida State University’s School of Dance, teaching both BFA and Graduate students in technique, choreography, and setting his original and new works on dancers there.
story_txt:

For this, and all he is as an individual and dance maker - I love him. How quickly time passes, while we are busy choreographing our lives. We are ephemeral; the time is now. This project is my best effort to encapsulate a small part of the man that has taught and inspired me and many others to live a poetic life inspite of fear.
                                                                                  - Fletcher, 2012

Travel Airfare - 5 x $500 (estimated cost of round trip ticket) = $2500

Dancer pay - 2 x $400 = $800
Per diem - 5 x 5 days x $25 a day = $625
Honorarium for Dan Wagoner - $500
 
Honorarium for Michelle Fletcher - $500

Equipment - $300

story:
Help Greyman Theatre Company present Thomas Ward's International Falls at The Tank in the heart of Times Square!

Greyman is thrilled to bring Thomas Ward's acclaimed play to NYC, but WE NEED YOUR HELP to get it there.

We've been privately seeking donations over the last couple of months, but now it's YOUR turn to step in!  In order to put up the show in February and March, we still need at least $5,000!  We can't do it without you, and any donation will help us meet our goal in just 55 days!

OUR COSTS

  • ACTOR & CREATIVE TEAM COMPENSATION
  • COSTUMES
  • PROPS
  • SET
  • SPACE RENTAL & INSURANCE
  • PRINTING
  • TRANSPORTATION

ABOUT INTERNATIONAL FALLS
First seen at WaterTower Theatre’s Out of the Loop Fringe Festival in Dallas, International Falls was called “one of the best original scripts I’ve ever seen produced” by Dallas Morning News critic Lawson Taitte.  The play has since received celebrated productions in Portland, Ore. and Minneapolis, Minn.  Here's how we describe it: "Unhappy with his life and his marriage, yet touring the country trying to make people laugh, Tim meets Dee, an equally unhappy wife and mother working as a front desk receptionist at a hotel in International Falls, Minn.  When they end up in bed together after his show, what begins as an unassuming one-night stand turns into an unexpected connection as two comedians, one burned out and one aspiring, discuss their insecurities, relationships, and comedy acts.  International Falls explores what happens when a man who makes jokes about his own life meets someone who forces him to examine the truth behind them."

ABOUT OUR COMPANY
We're a non-profit theatre company in New York City with the mission to discover and cultivate new voices and support the growth of artists while fostering an engaging, challenging, and relevant dialogue with our audiences.  Named after the ghost that makes his home at Baylor University’s theatrical venues, Greyman was created in 2009 by Baylor students and functions under the leadership of Artistic Director Matt Tolbert and Managing Director Joshua Gonzales.  In its third year, Greyman relocated from Texas to New York City to further its work developing and showcasing new voices.  Seeking to become a permanent and vital presence in NYC, we will begin producing in 2014, along with providing an innovative and dynamic education program.

Check out our stuff on the web:

  • Website
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • YouTube
  • Blog

story:
The Show

Everyone has been Derrick -  naive, young, idealistic, romantic, and new to love.  And if you haven't been Derrick, you've been Tristan - sensible, cynical, and on the road to success, but afraid to let love pass him by.  Chasing Heroes explores the relationships we've been in by showing us two guys who are still in trapped in one, surrounded by swirling emotions and sexual temptations.

We're booked for three shows on Wed Aug 27, Thurs Aug 28, and Fri Aug 29 at 6:30 PM with a fantastic little theater space in the heart of New York City:

Manhattan Repertory Theatre

303 W. 42nd St, 6th Floor, NYC, NY 10036

The Third and a Half Wall

A big part of Chasing Heroes is the framing.  Derrick and Tristan are actually each played by two actors.  Derrick and Tristan narrate the action joined by three companions who help them work through their problems - largely by calling them out their bad decisions.  To aid in the discussion, they summon Avatars, past embodiments of themselves, who live out the romance as it goes on.  Both the current and past incarnations of Derrick and Tristan can be on stage at the same time, really allowing us to explore metatheatricality in the piece.  It lets us bring the characters to life in a new way.

Another aspect of Chasing Heroes is a rotating act structure.  Because it's all about building a picture of a full relationship between Derrick and Tristan, Derrick will be the protagonist of the first act for the Wed Aug 27th performance, while Tristan will be the protagonist of the first act for the Thurs Aug 28th performance.  The last performance's act order will be determined closer to the show.  We think that this structure will give a unique experience based on which act order you see.

Where Your Donation Goes

There's a reason starving artists are a stereotype!  Everything in the theater world costs money, and the cast and crew are donating their time and talent.  But not everything can be donated.  Scripts, costuming, props, and space rentals all cost money.  Even better, we'd like to hire a publicist capable of helping us get the attention of field professionals -- reviewers, producers, agents, etc.  We've got a full cast and crew of talented people, and we'd like the opportunity to get noticed!

The base line will help us give our cast the best opportunities possible, but we're hoping to exceed our goals.  Ultimately, we'd like to remount the production for a larger run in a bigger space, using as many of the cast as possible.  Exceeding our goals will allow us to buy better props and set pieces, invite more industry guests, and maybe even give a stipend to our actors.  The more we raise, the better chance we have of giving back to the creative people who are making this happen!


    Meet Our Cast And Crew

    Chris Rivera, Director / Actor
    Chris Rivera is an actor, director, and playwright from Texas. There he spent many years teaching for the Tony Award winning Alley Theatre, and The Page Parkes School.  Chris's tenure in Houston was filled with numerous roles, including leads in Hedwig and the Angry Inch, Romeo and Juliet, and Compleat Female Stage Beauty. Chris is currently teaching for the New York Film Academy, and later this year Chris will direct an Off Broadway Romeo and Juliet for What Dreams May Company at the Kraine Theater.  
    Shane Cherry, Writer / Producer
    This is Shane's first full length show, but his short works have gained acclaim.  He holds a KCACTF Region II Honorable Mention and Sydney Short and Sweet Festival Honorable Mention for playwriting, and two Best Play awards from the John Chatterton Short Play Lab here in NYC.
    Monique Sanchez, Actress
    You can see Monique in the upcoming TNT drama, Public Morals!
    Brian Esposito, Actor
    Brian recently was awarded Best Actor by the West Village Musical Theatre Festival
    for his performance in Family Therapy.
    Corey Crysler, Actor
    Corey has several acting credits under his belt including Puck, everyone's favorite fairy!
    Mark Jonathan, Actor
    Mark holds various TV and film credits including work with HBO Movies, STARZ, and CBS.  He has a BFA from Viterbo University in LaCrosse, WI.
    Austin Boykin, Actor
    Austin holds many credits including The Normal Heart, Next Fall, and Richard II.
    Will Thomason, Actor
    Will is a graduate of UNC - Chapel Hill. His recent credits include Ovid's Metamorphoses and Warp Speed: A Sci Fi Parody Musical.
    Ali Wetzer, Actress
    Ali is our personal cast diva!  She graduated from University of the Arts and have several credits under her belt.
    Elsbeth Denman, Actress
    Credits include Comedy of Errors, An Enemy of the People, and Grey.
    Allen Davidson, Assistant Director
    Yha Mourhia Wright, Stage Manger

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that not everyone can donate, but there are other ways you can show support!

    • Buy a ticket!  Tickets are available at the door, but seating reservations are made at MRTreserve@gmail.com, We'd love your help getting us started, but we'd rather see you at the show!  If you have to choose, buy a ticket and support us with your applause at the end of the show, because the entire project is meaningless if we don't have an audience to enjoy it!
    • Share our Facebook event and our Indiegogo campaign!  Make some noise to let other people what's going on!  We always love the support and attention, so tell your friends!  You can find the link to our Facebook event right here:  https://www.facebook.com/events/1430724443883348/

story:
The Boys & Girls Club of Vista Drama Club


  • Our drama program offers youngsters a chance to build their speaking and educational skills and excel on stage and the classroom.
  • The program will serve at least 100 new Club members with no previous drama experience.
  • By 'acting out' in productions on the stage, Club members avoid the risks competing for their after-school time: gangs and drugs.

What We Need & What You Get

The Acting Out Fund will help us to bring our theater space up- to- date with actual theater seats, curtains and this-century theatrical technology. This is Phase 1 of our Drama Club crowdfunding which will enable us to continue the upgrades to our cozy little performance space, and to move forward to improve and expand our teaching curriculum, programs and productions for the Boys & Girls Club of Vista.

  • We're starting with theater seats. We're not fancy: we can buy used seats, but they don't come cheap.
  • Our small theater troupe consists of boys and girls of all ages and all backgrounds and talents. Don't forget- actors such as Denzel Washington and Jennifer Lopez spent their free time at Boys & Girls Clubs, so you're investing in the hopes and dreams of future stars!
  • If we somehow miss our monetary goal, the funds will still go to the drama department. We need lights, electrical repairs, curtains and stage design and educational materials so our young thespians can continue to 'act out' in a secure environment.

The Impact

  • 95% of our Club members will be at least at grade level
  • 90% will complete an eight-week course in Drama Matters curriculum.
  • 90% of Club members expect to go to college.
  • Giving youngsters a safe place to create, imagine and 'act out' in a safe atmosphere without the 'real' world problems invading their space, is the most important reason for our Drama Club.

Risks & Challenges

Everyone knows that times are tough for the arts. We understand that philanthropic foundations took it in the shorts during the stock-market crash and have less money to give, that's why we're experimenting with crowdfunding. The good news is, that no matter how much we raise, it all goes to the kids!


    • Follow us on Facebook - Boys& Girls Club of Vista and Twitter- @BGCVista and Instagram- bgcvista- and make some noise about our campaign.
    • Tell people about our drama program and ask them to contribute anything they can afford- we'll take whatever folks can afford!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, we get that, but we can always use volunteers who can help our youngsters 'act out,' in a good way!

  • Share this page with people you know who love the arts and who have a little extra cash for our actors.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Thank you to everyone who donated, shared our link, and supported us in reaching our $10,000 goal! We are forever grateful to you for helping us to revive this rare classic play! Tickets are now on sale via Telecharge. To purchase tickets click here! Previews start November 15th and Opening Night will be on Thursday, November 29th! We can't wait to see you in the brand new 777 Theatre!

THE GREAT MacDADDY is BACK...35 years later!

One of the sexiest, funniest, and most ground breaking theatrical experiences to ever hit New York is BACK after 35 years and IT'S BETTER THAN EVER!!! Before there was Hip Hop, there was The Great MacDaddy. Considered one of the Negro Ensemble Company’s classic works, The Great MacDaddy, written by Paul Carter Harrison, was last staged at the Theatre De Lys in 1977, and is now being revived 35 years later for the enjoyment of a whole new generation! Through your donations Korner Theatricals, Alfred Preisser, Diane Batson and the Negro Ensemble Company in association with Jaylene Clark, The Hip Hop Theatre Festival, Freedome Bradley and The City Parks Foundation will present this great work at the 777 Theatre this fall (November). In this world of virtual reality that isn’t real, we want to pay homage to the rich oral tradition of story-telling through African-American folklore!

What is The Great MacDaddy?

The Great MacDaddy is a play-with-music that resurrects many of the fabled heroes of the urban storytelling tradition, including Shine, Stagolee, and the Signifyin’ Monkey.  It is a satirical romp driven by a funky Music characterization that advances the story of a young, egotistical MacDaddy, the beneficiary of his father’s illegal booze fortune during Prohibition, who crosses the American landscape on an odyssey in search of Wine, the custodian of the formula for his father’s legacy.  It is a Time-travel odyssey across the United States in the 20th Century that has the young, self-indulgent MacDaddy discovering a world of hostilities where he encounters many cautionary trials and tribulations until he discovers Wine among the ancestors in the South and becomes enlightened with a spiritual wisdom he must share with his people in the 21st Century. It is the conclusion of an often humorously raucous, yet captivating journey that galvanizes the audience to a sense of collective celebration.

Production History

When this play was originally produced in 1974 by the Negro Ensemble Company, the stellar cast included legendary actors and actresses such as Phylicia Rashad, Hattie Winston, Cleavon Little, and the late, great Al Freeman, Jr..

Phylicia Rashad has this to say about The Great MacDaddy today:

“‘The Great MacDaddy” is as relevant today as when it debuted at the Negro Ensemble Theater over thirty years ago.  Come and enjoy this revival!"

Hattie Winston says this:

“How thrilled I am to know that the Negro Ensemble is once again mounting Paul Carter Harrison's 'The Great MacDaddy.' All those years ago when I was in the original production with actors such as Al Freeman, Jr., I had no idea that we were participating in an historical event.  I had no idea, although I should have suspected it, that ‘The Great MacDaddy’ would inspire, thrive, live on and take its place in the canon of African American Theatrical Literature. I am so very pleased to know that a new generation of theatre-goers will be able to take this journey through the history of a people. My people.

The Impact

For hundreds of years it was the oral tradition that defined a culture, maintained an identity, and passed along the history of a people for generations. Through The Great MacDaddy we want to bring the excitement of storytelling to the 21st century. For 2 hours and 30 minutes we want the audience to be swept up in the music, mesmerized by the dance, entertained by the raucous humor, and engrossed in classic urban folktales with a modern twist. Paul Carter Harrison is a phenomenal playwright and with your help we can revive his great work and show the world once again why The Great MacDaddy is the “greatest MacDaddy of all the MacDaddies who can do anything in this world!”

Get Involved!

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!! The beautiful thing about technology today is that we can spread the word about this show much faster than we would have been able to do when this play first premiered in 1974. Please share information about our show with your Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, Google+, and other social media site followers! "Like" us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, subscribe to us on YouTube, join our circles in Google+, follow us on Pinterest, and check in with us on FourSquare!

Thank you!
story_txt:
Thank you to everyone who donated, shared our link, and supported us in reaching our $10,000 goal! We are forever grateful to you for helping us to revive this rare classic play! Tickets are now on sale via Telecharge. To purchase tickets click here! Previews start November 15th and Opening Night will be on Thursday, November 29th! We can't wait to see you in the brand new 777 Theatre!

Thank you!

story:
Our Story

Fighting Chance Productions has been a non-profit theatre organization in the Lower Mainland for five years. In that time more than 400 emerging and established artists have been involved in our productions. We have present 24 plays & musicals from Sweeney Todd to Rent to Hair to The Laramie Project. BC Premieres have include bare: a pop opera, The Temperamentals, some girl(s), Matt & Ben, The Distance from Here, tick... tick... BOOM!, The Musical of Musicals: The Musical, One Good Marriage, The Lieutenant of Inishmore and the (hopefully) upcoming Grey Gardens.


The Impact

At this point, Fighting Chance is looking at a deficit of approximately $20,000. While the product has been well received critically we have unfortunately lost money on every single show we have produced over the past year. Without being able to raise crucial funds necessary immediately we will be forced to postpone and/or cancel upcoming productions of Grey Gardens, Rent & Little Shop of Horrors as well as postpone and/or cancel our 2012/13 season

Other Ways You Can Help

Please let people know about our current production THE MYSTERY OF EDWIN DROOD playing until March 3rd at the Metro Theatre (1370 SW Marine Drive) tickets are available at http://www.ticketstonight.ca

story:
Our Story

Anthony McDonald and Jiles King are both currently students at Columbia University as candidates for a Master's in Theater Management and Producing.  For Anthony McDonald this is his first time producing a theatrical show.   Which as one can imagine he is learning a whole lot!  Jiles King on the other hand is a seasoned Producer who has been producing his own shows for a few years now, based out of Texas. Now they are both at Columbia producing the Colored Museum together. 


They both share a passion for producing work by people of color that comment on the Black experience.  When thinking about plays and stories to do, when the Colored Museum came up they both knew this was the one that we would collaborate on in order to spark a dialogue on the campus of Columbia about race and race matters in America. 

The Play

George C. Wolfe's THE COLORED MUSEUM is a in-your-face story that fixates the black experience and forces you to re-evaluate everything you have ever known.  From a historical perspective, living in a world with the first Black President, the conversation about race is evermore present and on one’s mind.  The issues that the Colored Museum addresses resonate just as much today as they did in 1985.  The stereotypes that have existed over time are thought to be diluted and gone.  But are they really?  This show opens and gives a platform to discuss this issue across racial lines.  By using satirical comedy to display the stereotypes it allows it to be introduced in a non-confrontational arena. 

Why Now

From a historical perspective, living in a world with the first Black President the conversation about race is evermore present and on one’s mind.  The issues that the Colored Museum addresses resonate just as much today as they did in 1985.  The stereotypes that have existed over time are thought to be diluted and gone.  But are they really?  This show opens and gives a platform to discuss this issue across racial lines.  By using satirical comedy to display the stereotypes it allows it to be introduced in a non-confrontational arena. 


From a personal viewpoint, now in my 2nd year at Columbia University, I have noticed the lack of diversity in the plays presented on campus.  I want to create theater that "theatricalizes" the Black experience which could be focusing on African Americans, to West Indians, Africans or whomever identifies as Black in the world.  With the current commercial  theater landscape in America lacking diversity, by the plays being produced that were written by people of color, it fuels my desire to create or produce the diversity that I would like to see.  As President Obama stated, “Change will not come if we wait for some other person, or if we wait for some other time. We are the ones we've been waiting for. We are the change that we seek. The Colored Museum is that change.

When and Where

The performances will take place at the Glicker-Milstein Theater on the campus of Barnard College, NYC which is located in the Diana Center. 

We will have three performances, one on Friday the 21st of October and two on Saturday the 22nd of October.

What We Need & What You Get

We really need your monetary contribution. We have production expenses, which include:

Set Budget

Costume Budget

Lighting Budget

Prop Budget

Production Rights 

Marketing Materials

Ticket Printing

Technical Costs


As a donor, you will receive

$25-$49

Recognition in Playbill


$50-$149

Recognition in Playbll

Signed Playbill and Cast Photo


$150-$299

Recognition in Playbill

2 comp tickets

VIP Seating at Show

Signed Playbill and Cast Photo


$300-$499

Recognition in Playbill

2 comp tickets

VIP Seating at Show

Signed Playbill and Cast Photo

Complimentary Bottle of Wine


$500 and up

Recognition in Playbill

2 comp tickets

VIP Seating at Show

Signed Show Poster

Complimentary Bottle of Wine

Cast Photo

VIP Meet and Greet with Cast

VIP Dinner for Two with the Director at Harlem's World Famous Soul Food Restaurant Sylvia's


Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by buying tickets, telling your friends and family, posting this link on facebook, twitter, LinkedIn, and any other social media sites.

story:
Our Story

Umberto MacDougal first reached the New York stage at Under St. Marks Theater at Penny's Open Mic. Since then, he's been around the city at Comdy Period, Sketch Block, Soul Glo, Skinny Bitch Jesus Meeting's Daddy's Basement, The Trachtenburg Variety Hour, and several other comedy and variety shows. He's still unsure why he continues to be booked for comedy shows.


In December 2010, Umberto performed in a special showcase at Horse Trade Theater Group's Kraine Theater.  Competing against 15 other shows, he won one of the three slots at Horse Trade's MiniFRIDGE festival to perform an hour long show of his very own called The Terrible Manpain of Umberto MacDougal, starring Emleigh Wolf and Mike Ogletree and directed by Bricken Sparacino.  After that successful run, Umberto won a lottery allowing him a spot in the main Horse Trade FRIGID Festival. 

The Impact

Your money could help Umberto continue to go to festivals around the world.  The first goal after the FRIGID is to get into the Edinburgh Free Fringe http://www.laughinghorsecomedy.co.uk/dynamic/fe..., bringing Umberto home to Scotland.  If Umberto can't raise enough money to do that, he'll be looking into the Winnipeg Fringe this summer instead.  Basically, he's not going to stop until he's spread the word of manpain to the world.


What We Need & What You Get

Your money will go toward promotional materials, travel and accommodation expenses for Umberto and his very sad guitarist and a tech as well as registration and venue fees at festivals.


Airfare to Edinburgh - appx. $2000-$2300

Festival Entry - appx. $600-$800

Promotional Materials - appx. $400-$800

Accommodation - ???


Want a better breakdown of funding before opening your purse to this melancholy cause?  Check back here soon!  As Emleigh collects specific information, it will be posted on this page.


Other Ways You Can Help

Come to see The Terrible Manpain of Umberto MacDougal in the upcoming FRIGID Festival at Under St. Marks Theater (94 St. Marks Place, New York, NY 10009)  

Thu Feb 23rd 9:00 PM

Sun Feb 26th 7:00 PM

Mon Feb 27th 6:00 PM

Fri March 2nd 7:30 PM

Sat Mar 3rd 2:30 PM

Discounted tickets are already on sale!  http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?showcode=ter0...

Broke and/or not in New York?  Spread the word!  Like Umberto on Facebook!  https://www.facebook.com/pages/Umberto-MacDouga...

Want to find out more?  Contact Emleigh Wolf at emleighwolf@gmail.com

story:
“Stuck in Neutral” is the story of Shawn, a teenage boy with cerebral palsy who cannot communicate with anyone except the audience.  Shawn’s parents have recently separated.  His brother Paul is barely speaking to their father.  Cindy, his sister, is attempting to keep the peace.  His father Syd becomes obsessed with a man who killed his severely disabled son.  While Shawn experiences his first real crush, he also wonders whether or not Syd is going to kill him.
 
My first encounter with “Stuck in Neutral” by Terry Trueman was during my summer vacation from middle school.  The story resonated with me because it is told through the eyes of Shawn, a teenage boy who, like me, has cerebral palsy.  Shawn has no way of communicating with his family.  Only the reader knows his thoughts and feelings.  Being a writer, I always felt like the story would translate into a more visual medium.   
 
My first play, “Sideshow,” won Honorable Mention in the VSA Arts Young Playwrights Contest and excerpts were performed at the Kennedy Center.  Clearly, I’ve kept writing.  The topic of different abilities is important to me because I don’t think it’s discussed enough in mainstream media.  Most people will become disabled at some point in their lives, it’s good to talk about it now. 
 
Being differently abled, I require assistants for my daily activities.  That’s how I met Matt Chorpenning, my writing partner.  Matt was awarded the Kennedy Center/American Collegiate Theater Festival National Playwriting Fellowship for his play "Talking to Strangers."  After working with Matt for a while, I felt like he was the perfect person to collaborate with on adapting “Stuck in Neutral” into a play. 
 
Even though we felt like getting the rights was a long shot, we went ahead and emailed Terry Trueman about our project.  He gave us his blessing to write the play, but didn’t sign over the rights.  After doing a staged reading of the first draft, Matt and I rewrote, sent it off to Terry and his publishers, and gained the rights to produce it. 
 
As writers, it isn’t always certain that our work will be performed, so just the thought of having this play produced means the world to us.  We only have a limited amount of time to produce before the rights revert back to Terry Trueman.  It’s very important that we raise enough money to rent a theater, build sets, costume actors, and make this a production that captivates audiences.  
 
Script available upon request.

story:
Short Summary

Most people know me as Burgundy Brixx - burlesque artist, producer and educator. I hold a BA in theatre arts with a minor in dance, and worked for over 10 years in New York as a theatre artist.

And then I found Burlesque.

I became extremely impassioned not only for the burlessque revival, but for uncovering and researching the history of this "bastard child of american theatre". For everyone who's ever felt like a misfit, being chastised for enjoying honest, bawdy, sexy humour that's not airbrushed into false perfection, burlesque is a much-needed oasis in today's world. A place of acceptance and joy.

I see burlesque as not just a sub-section of theatre or dance, but as its own unique artform. By delving into its rich and colorful history and presenting it onstage in a historic homage to its humanity, we hope to show as many people as possible that burlesque is worthy of artistic appreciation and enjoyment by everyone, not just the fringe of society.

And the opportunity to be a part of the Vancouver Fringe Festival is the perfect next step in this project realizing its dream.

What We Need & What You Get

We just mounted a mini version of this production for the Vancouver International Burlesque Festival to amazing response. But of course it left our cupboards bare. However, having this opportunity to be a part of the Fringe Fest suddeny presented to us is something we can't say no to, so we're on the hunt to raise funds for our fee to participate in the Vancouver Fringe Festival (a not-for profit orgainization) - $750.00


That's not much at all, and it gives us an amazing venue we could not afford otherwise, plus the support and publicity of the Vancouver Fringe Festival and its affiliates.


We plan to reach our goal! These funds will go 100% into the mounting of the full version production!

The Impact

I've been passionate about uncovering the real Gypsy Rose Lee for many years. As an important historical figure from right here in the pacific northwest, I feel it's important for  more people to really get to know her and understand her impact on the world today. As well as her huge contribution to the burlesque revival as we know it.

I moved to Vancouver in 2008 and began producing a little burlesque cabaret called Kitty Nights. Five years later, I'm still producing that hugely successful weekly show which has garnerd accolades and awards from WE Vancouver, Yelp, Lonely Planet and more. It has become the most popular burlesque show in Canada, and is a major part of the Biltmore Cabaret's business success. It also has given burlesque artists in Vancouver a place to work, hone their craft and share a sense of community within this art form.

My hope is to use my skills in partnership with LiveStage Performance and Pandora and the Locksmiths to bring this production, and the art of burlesque, out into the limelight for a new demographic of theatre-goers to truly appreciate, and by that mark, help burlesque artists and shows everywhere find more new audiences and sustainability for their passion!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love bulesque, theatre history or just great entertainment, please help spread the word!

Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools and help us reach our goal!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Most people know me as Burgundy Brixx - burlesque artist, producer and educator. I hold a BA in theatre arts with a minor in dance, and worked for over 10 years in New York as a theatre artist.
And then I found Burlesque.
I became extremely impassioned not only for the burlessque revival, but for uncovering and researching the history of this "bastard child of american theatre". For everyone who's ever felt like a misfit, being chastised for enjoying honest, bawdy, sexy humour that's not airbrushed into false perfection, burlesque is a much-needed oasis in today's world. A place of acceptance and joy.
I see burlesque as not just a sub-section of theatre or dance, but as its own unique artform. By delving into its rich and colorful history and presenting it onstage in a historic homage to its humanity, we hope to show as many people as possible that burlesque is worthy of artistic appreciation and enjoyment by everyone, not just the fringe of society.
And the opportunity to be a part of the Vancouver Fringe Festival is the perfect next step in this project realizing its dream.


What We Need & What You Get
We just mounted a mini version of this production for the Vancouver International Burlesque Festival to amazing response. But of course it left our cupboards bare. However, having this opportunity to be a part of the Fringe Fest suddeny presented to us is something we can't say no to, so we're on the hunt to raise funds for our fee to participate in the Vancouver Fringe Festival (a not-for profit orgainization) - $750.00
That's not much at all, and it gives us an amazing venue we could not afford otherwise, plus the support and publicity of the Vancouver Fringe Festival and its affiliates.
We plan to reach our goal! These funds will go 100% into the mounting of the full version production!


The Impact
I've been passionate about uncovering the real Gypsy Rose Lee for many years. As an important historical figure from right here in the pacific northwest, I feel it's important for  more people to really get to know her and understand her impact on the world today. As well as her huge contribution to the burlesque revival as we know it.
I moved to Vancouver in 2008 and began producing a little burlesque cabaret called Kitty Nights. Five years later, I'm still producing that hugely successful weekly show which has garnerd accolades and awards from WE Vancouver, Yelp, Lonely Planet and more. It has become the most popular burlesque show in Canada, and is a major part of the Biltmore Cabaret's business success. It also has given burlesque artists in Vancouver a place to work, hone their craft and share a sense of community within this art form.
My hope is to use my skills in partnership with LiveStage Performance and Pandora and the Locksmiths to bring this production, and the art of burlesque, out into the limelight for a new demographic of theatre-goers to truly appreciate, and by that mark, help burlesque artists and shows everywhere find more new audiences and sustainability for their passion!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you love bulesque, theatre history or just great entertainment, please help spread the word!
Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools and help us reach our goal!

story:
Welcome to Against the Odds, a different kind of festival.  Against the Odds celebrates artists who investigate how to overcome obstacles.  This year we were inspired by Monkeyhouse dancers who struggle with uncommon health issues and so the 2012 Against the Odds Festival, Imperfect{ive} Experiments, specifically looks at how people can make physical poetry out of imperfect bodies.  Whether developing the medical limitations set on one dancer into opportunities to create new vocabulary, exploring the relationship between two dancers when one is blindfolded or playing with a group of performers connected to each other by 16 foot sleeves, we are experimenting with the perceptions and realities of the imperfect body.

Monkeyhouse began with a promise to build a laboratory where choreographers could create, experiment and present new work.  Our mission has developed to include motivating people to move with meaning and improving communication by connecting communities to choreography.  Over the years we have mentored, nurtured and supported dozens of choreographers ranging from students first experimenting to established favorites.  We’ve had hundreds of conversations about different choreographic processes that stimulate or inspire new directions for our work and helped foster long term relationships with presenters, audience members and other choreographers.  

When we first came up with the idea to build a festival it was not about featuring our own work or even making a “dance festival” but about creating a gathering of choreographic expressions, in a wide range of disciplines.  We hunger for events that bring communities together in a way that fosters an exchange of ideas, greater understanding between participants and lasting relationships. 

 

Who are these artists you talk about?

Against the Odds will be supporting over 40 artists including Ryan P. Casey, Karen Krolak, Barry Duncan, Mariah Steele, Sarah Feinburg, Cynthia Roberts, Elliott Von Wendt, TAProject, Marty Allen, Kezia Fitzgerald, Nicole Harris, Courtney Blanch, Lacey Sasso and Kendra Heithoff Henseler of Six One Seven Dance Collective, Jason Ries, Lewis Glass, Al Cripps, Luminarium Dance, Melissa Dollman, Caitlin Meehan, Thomas Durand, Janelle Gilchrist, Dance'n Feet, Sarah Friswell, Josh Hilberman, Courtney Wagner, Matthew Murphy, Aisha Cruse, Eva Dean Dance, Stephanie Suné, Nikki Sao Pedro, Audra Carabetta and Jonathan Keith.

Where is your money going?

A donation of $25 will cover the cost of programs for one performance, fund one artist interview, or cover the travel costs of one performer.

A donation of $50 will pay the performance fee of a Monkeyhouse dancer, costume a new piece or cover the ticketing fees for one performance.

A donation of $100 will pay the stipend for one guest artist, cover the printing fees for a series of mailers or fund ten hours of rehearsal.

Why Monkeyhouse?

Donating to Monkeyhouse not only supports one local arts organization but helps us to support many, many more.  Already we have over 25 artists who will be showing work throughout the festival and another 20 who will be performing.  This is a huge undertaking and we need your help to make sure that the Against the Odds experience is one that extends beyond one night of dancing.  We want to support, celebrate and collaborate with each and every artist involved in the festival both throughout the creation process and beyond the performance.  Why not put your money to a place where it can do the most good?

 

Everybody here at Monkeyhouse understands that money isn't always free flowing so we would love to take your help in whatever form it comes in. 

First, PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!  Just because you might not be able to afford the big bucks today doesn't mean someone you know doesn't.  And don't forget, every penny really does count.  Fifteen donations of $10 are just as good as one donation of $150. 

Second, contact us (MonkeyhouseLovesMe@gmail.com) for more ways you can participate!
