story:
Flight: An Original CalArts Circus Opera

Intertwining several artists from a wide array of mediums to create a truly inspired, passionate piece of art. 

March 23rd, 2013

Sharon Disney Lund Theatre

 

Flight is a one act circus opera consisting of two parts. The first part is animation projected onto circus silks depicting a tale of a magical orchard that blooms women. When a king comes to capture the beautiful ladies they barely escape. All except one.

The second part is a live performance about this same woman who is now the queen and the relationship she forces with a bird played by Katie Gardner on trapeze.

 

Meet the Production Team:

Katie Lynn Gardner - Creator, Choreographer, Performer

I am a vocalist, aerialist, and writer originally from Massillon, OH. Currently, I am earning my MFA in Vocal Performance from California Institute of the Arts. I am passionate about incorporating various aspects of circus disciplines and theatrical elements into my original works, whether they be solo vocal performances or full scale musical productions.  My inspiration comes from research into circus history, vocal performance history, folklore, and cognition studies. Recent performances/ contracts include Disney Cruise Lines, Disneyland Parks and Resort, REDCAT, Highways at Santa Monica, and The Hammer Museum. I graduated from Kent State University with a BA in English Literature with minors in Music and Political Science.

 

Marissa Galin - Creative & Technical Director, Co-Producer

Marissa Galin is passionate about creating immersive art inspired by the beauty of the human body and human interaction.  Being engrossed in fine arts and martial arts at a young age, she developed an early understanding of an innate need for artistic expression.  She finally found a home in theatre and has since worn many different creative, managerial or technical hats of responsibility.  This led to exposure in film, circus and themed entertainment. She most recently interned at Stage Technologies Inc. in Las Vegas as a Mechanical Engineering Intern.  Marissa is in her last year of study at California Institute of the Arts as a BFA candidate in Technical Design & Direction and is currently Technical Director on a CalArts Theatre School Production of Eugene O'Neal's Long Days Journey into Night. Marissa has been working closely with Katie to help realize the vision of Flight and is incredibly excited to bring it to the CalArts community.

 

Erica Larsen-Dockray - Animator and Video Designer

Erica Larsen-Dockray is a Nebraskan native with interests in projection as a medium and issues dealing with gender, sex, age, and other human rights.  She has studied both Graphic Design and Painting and Drawing at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.  In 2003 she received a BA in Animation and Media Arts from the Art Institute of Phoenix and in 2009 a BFA and a MFA in Experimental Animation and Integrated Media from the California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) in 2012. Erica has travelled the world making wacky collaborative works  and installations involving animation, video, painting, dance, live music, games, dark rides, interactive stations, performance, and beyond.  She loves candy coating dark issues and play as a device to spark discussion and involvement.

 

Daphne Mir - Lighting Designer

Daphne is enthusiastic about the creation of immersive experiences and spectacles. Her first foray in to intimate spectacles at CalArts took the form of a theatrical magic show she wrote, designed, and performed in, "How To Make a Magician Disappear." While studying abroad at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, Daphne had the opportunity to collaborate with Circus Arts for the first time. Daphne is expected to graduate this May with her BFA from CalArts. Daphne is inspired by the serendipitous path these experiences have formed, and is looking forward to bringing the knowledge and passion from them to create the fascinating and intensely beautiful world of Flight! Her design for Flight draws inspiration from hiking in the misty, gently metallic light of Scotland, where from castles, forests, and places of fantasy materialize. Dancing with the shadow-puppet like aspects of the animation, textures and meticulously crafted shadows will wrap their wings around the world of aerial displays and musical wonder. She is excited to expand the beautiful, two-dimensional imagery the team is creating through projection in to a cohesive world for the performers to take flight in. 

 

Adeline Newmann - Video Programmer

Jaqueline Adair - Costume Designer

Daniel Greenberg - Assistant Technical Director

Lauren Davis  - Performer (The Queen)

Marc Chernoff - Aerial Rigger, Performer (The Bird Outside)

Chris Burnett - Poster Designer

Andrea Young - Co-composer

Charles Underriner - Co-composer

Hannah Dexter - Viola

Jarrett Furst- Cello

Henry Webster - Violin

 

Why We Need Your Money: 

The more money we receive, the more elaborate our designs can be.

No matter how much we raise, all funds will go towards the design to bring Flight to life.

  • Scenic
    • We are using various aerial rigging apparatuses, and they don't come cheap. The design calls for 4 aerial silks and a static trapeze. Aside from the normal use you would expect to get out of an aerial silk, we plan to use white, stretch silks as projection screens. This means we also need the proper hardware to stretch the bottom of the silks on the ground (which we cannot in any way affix into) while the silk hangs from proper silk hardware. Additionally, we need to buy all new span sets and carabineers for safety.
    • Additionally, Marissa is designing a 24', climbable, moveable, modular A-Frame ladder apparatus that will be used for acrobatics and choreography. To speak a bit further, the ladder must be modular to fit out of the 10’ shop doors and be assembled or raised in the space. Ideally the entire structure will be on casters for movement in the show, and all must be structural enough to withstand dynamic forces from the acrobatics. Meaning, in short hand; $$$.
  • Lighting
    • We plan to use CalArts stock equipment, but because there are often 6 productions going on at once, it leaves us with limited supply. With more money we could have the opportunity for rental packages that would help us achieve a gorgeous morning light look, or in contrast a dark, shadowy forest atmosphere.
    • Coupled with the lighting, we are incredibly interested in a low-lying haze effect, and hope to raise enough money to use dry ice for tech rehearsal and productions.
  • Costumes
    • The costume design is made up of full body suits to completely transform the performers into their characters. Feathers (rather expensive themselves), airy fabrics, to create brilliant bird inspired creatures.
  • Producing
    • We want to get the word out! We have a fantastic CalArts graphic design student, Chris Burnett, creating a production poster to help publicize the event! We need money to provide him with materials to make and get copies.
    • Additionally, we are interested in creating a single page, no fold program to credit everyone on all the wonderful work they will be doing, and to thank all of YOU for donating to our cause!

Circus productions are rarely if ever done at CalArts, and we are hoping this production sparks interest into such a fantastic and expressive art form.

Help us bring Circus Arts to CalArts!

Any and All contributions will help! Please help us turn our vision into a reality!

If you are interested in helping us but can't spare the cash, help us get the word out! Make some noise and tell your friends!

 

Thank you!!!

Producing

Thank you!!!

story:
Short Summary

-We are a NEW THEATRE COMPANY hoping to bring intelligent and entertaining theater to people at affordable prices , as well as plays (new as well as overlooked) that reflect on social issues of today. www.TETCNY.org . 

  • Our campaign is to raise the final $ 5,000 we need to produce this wonderful play about OSCAR WILDE called DIVERSIONS & DELIGHTS . This will be the FIRST NYC Equity production of this wonderful play in over 30 years! The play deals with how OSCAR WILDE ,the reigning wit author and playwright of his era ,was brought down because he dared to love.  
    With all the push back against rights for the LGBT community , this play has become more and more timely .  

What We Need & What You Get


  • The money we need to raise will pay for the theatre rental as well as printing costs ( programs , posters, ads ). 

  • We need to reach at least the cost of the theatre rental to lock in the space .

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Your contribution will help introduce a whole new generation to this wonderful play (unproduced in NYC  for over 30 years .
  • You will be helping start a brand new theatre company . Many theatres have closed in the past few years and many that remain are often playing it "safe" with familiar works . We hope that we may do plays both new and overlooked that challenge audiences to discuss social issues while at the same time doing it in an entertaining fashion .  We also hope that in future we may bring our productions to places that would love theatre, but for various reasons cannot afford to (homeless shelters, schools whose budgets have been slashed ,etc ). 
  • TETCNY became a 501(c)3  thanks to the assistance of Columbia Law's Legal Clinic, who worked tirelessly aiding us due to their beleif in what we are attempting to do.  
  • Also, SIR DEREK JACOBI (the upcoming film GRACE OF MONACO ; award winning actor : Tony,Emmy awards ) was our guest speaker for our first fundraiser. At the time, he was a guest at other spaces  for $1000 donations. Our fundraiser was only $35 a ticket  , and SIR DEREK graciously spent hours posing for photo ,and chatting with everyone. Again, this wonderful actor did so because he believed in what we are attempting to do.

Risks & Challenges

Theatre is risky . We know that. However, theatre can enrich as well as entertain .

Our board consists of professionals (Union and non union) performers and theatre people who have worked for decades within the business.  

  • We have applied for many grants but to get them , we need to show the grant writers that we can do great theatre at an affordable price . YOUR DONATION will make it happen  .

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can't afford to donate ,even $5  can you do us a favor and spread the word on social media ? Let your friends know what we are doing ,and how their donations will help us create GREAT THEATRE .  Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Other questions ? Check out www.TETCNY.org  or email me, Kevin G Shinnick at tetcny@gmail.com

story:
Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers Takes Flight

KYL/D is at a very exciting juncture – our first performance in Europe! We are particularly honored to be one of just three U.S. companies selected to perform at the prestigious International Tanzmesse Festival in Dusseldorf, Germany.  At the Tanzmesse, we will share our signature work, Mandala Project, for an audience of artists and presenters from Europe and beyond. But, we need YOUR help to get us there!


What We Need & What You Get

WE ARE SO CLOSE...With amazing support from our Board and other earned revenue, we have raised 80% of our costs already.  We have just $7,226 left to go!

  • When you donate, you will earn our deepest gratitude as well as some amazing perks. See the sidebar for details, but gifts include KYL/D t-shirts, private ballroom dance/Gyrokinesis sessions with KYL/D artists, a walk on our KYL/D labyrinth, and a weekend beach getaway! 

  • And don’t forget, a tax deduction -- donations exceeding the value of each prize are tax deductible. 


Your Impact

 Your donation helps share American artistry on the international dance scene, broaden our perspective, and guide us home with new insights to share with the Philadelphia dance community and the many other U.S. communities where we tour.Your generosity will help fund this performance that will open doors for future touring opportunities and the forging of relationships with other artistic collaborators. 


Other Ways You Can Help 

There are more ways that one to help us reach our goal! Go beyond by sharing the link to our Indiegogo page through the share tools and spread the word about our fundraising campaign. 

We will also be grateful for mailed donations, if you prefer. Please make checks payable to KYL Dancers Inc., mail them to our address below, and you will receive the corresponding gift for your donation level.

Kun-Yang Lin/ Dancers                                                                                                          1316 S. 9th Street                                                                                                                       Philadelphia, PA 19147


From all of us at KYL/D, We THANK YOU for your support! 



About KYL/D

Noted for its superbly trained dancers and inventive choreography, the internationally-active KYL/D probes at the limits of national identities, drawing upon Eastern philosophies while expanding the perimeter of contemporary dance. Artistic Director Lin's zen-inspired practice of dance manifests in lush works of poetic sensibility that the New York Times has said "create and inhabit worlds of their own".  Lin draws upon multicultural insights from his ongoing research throughout Asia, creating a personal movement language that is an unexpected hybrid between Western and Eastern cultures, suffused with strong spiritual underpinnings. KYL/D has performed across the United States and internationally, including at the Busan International Dance Festival in Korea, Jogia International AsiaTri festivals in Indonesia, Festival Internacional de Danza in Mexico, Victoria Theatre in Singapore, HsinChu Performing Arts Center in Taiwan, in the U.S at Interlochen Festival, Columbia Festival, Kaatsbaan International Dance Center, Jacob's Pillow Inside/Out, Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival, Dancing in the Streets Festical, Painted Bride Arts Center, Annenberg Center, Kimmel Center and the Barnes Foundation Museum. More information at kunyanglin.org.

KYL/D's artists are: Kun-Yang Lin, Jessica Warchal-King* , Eiren Shuman*, Evalina "Wally" Cain Carbonell*, Liu Mo*, Rachael Hart*, Brandi Ou*, Vuthy Ou*, Brian Cordova, Wei Wei Ma and Helen Hale. (*Denotes Tanzmesse Cast)  

Lighting Designer- Stephen Petrili

Composer/Sound Consultant: Cory Neale

Please note: The above Philo Project video contains excerpts of "to dust," a piece choreographed by long-time KYL/D artist and independent choreographer, Olive Prince. 

About Mandala Project

The Philadelphia Inquirer hailed it as “a masterwork of art, spirituality, and stagecraft”, and the curators of the Tanzmesse have described it as follows:

“Dancers flow into one another, interweaving ecstatically to meditative sounds and drawing on the trance dances of Sufi dervishes.  Seeing moves into feeling, everyday life is slowly blotted out as the performance takes us on a journey into ourselves – like the magic mandala, the holy circle of tantric Buddhism which links the viewer with cosmic powers, thereby opening the door to the soul. The Borobudur temple site on Java, which is shaped like a mandala, inspired Kun-Yang Lin's choreography.” 


About Tanzmesse

The internationale tanzmesse is a biennial festival platform for communicating and networking in the field of contemporary dance. At the Tanzmesse international dance companies and artists present their work live on stage and choreographers, dancers, agencies, presenters and cultural institutions network and present their work in a lively forum. (Courtesy of Tanzmesse)
story_txt:
Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers Takes Flight

KYL/D is at a very exciting juncture – our first performance in Europe! We are particularly honored to be one of just three U.S. companies selected to perform at the prestigious International Tanzmesse Festival in Dusseldorf, Germany.  At the Tanzmesse, we will share our signature work, Mandala Project, for an audience of artists and presenters from Europe and beyond. But, we need YOUR help to get us there!


What We Need & What You Get

WE ARE SO CLOSE...With amazing support from our Board and other earned revenue, we have raised 80% of our costs already.  We have just $7,226 left to go!

When you donate, you will earn our deepest gratitude as well as some amazing perks. See the sidebar for details, but gifts include KYL/D t-shirts, private ballroom dance/Gyrokinesis sessions with KYL/D artists, a walk on our KYL/D labyrinth, and a weekend beach getaway! 
And don’t forget, a tax deduction -- donations exceeding the value of each prize are tax deductible. 


  
Your Impact

 Your donation helps share American artistry on the international dance scene, broaden our perspective, and guide us home with new insights to share with the Philadelphia dance community and the many other U.S. communities where we tour.Your generosity will help fund this performance that will open doors for future touring opportunities and the forging of relationships with other artistic collaborators. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help 

There are more ways that one to help us reach our goal! Go beyond by sharing the link to our Indiegogo page through the share tools and spread the word about our fundraising campaign. 

We will also be grateful for mailed donations, if you prefer. Please make checks payable to KYL Dancers Inc., mail them to our address below, and you will receive the corresponding gift for your donation level.
Kun-Yang Lin/ Dancers                                                                                                          1316 S. 9th Street                                                                                                                       Philadelphia, PA 19147

(*Denotes Tanzmesse Cast)  
Lighting Designer- Stephen Petrili
Composer/Sound Consultant: Cory Neale

About Mandala Project


The Philadelphia Inquirer hailed it as “a masterwork of art, spirituality, and stagecraft”, and the curators of the Tanzmesse have described it as follows:
“Dancers flow into one another, interweaving ecstatically to meditative sounds and drawing on the trance dances of Sufi dervishes.  Seeing moves into feeling, everyday life is slowly blotted out as the performance takes us on a journey into ourselves – like the magic mandala, the holy circle of tantric Buddhism which links the viewer with cosmic powers, thereby opening the door to the soul. The Borobudur temple site on Java, which is shaped like a mandala, inspired Kun-Yang Lin's choreography.”

of contemporary dance. At the Tanzmesse international dance companies and

story:
What is Mugwumpin10?

Mugwumpin10 is a celebration of a decade of bracing live art, and a challenge for a decade more. It’s also: 2 revivals of audience-favorite shows, 5 new works, 4 workshops, 3 discussion events, tons of guest artists, and a whole heap of conviviality.

We're looking at the path that’s led us to where we are today, so that we can better understand where we are going. All along the way, that path has been a conversation and collaboration with you, our audience, so it seems only fitting to include you in the party.

If you don’t know us: Mugwumpin is an award-winning San Francisco theater and performance company. For the past ten years, we have been making live art that pushes the edges of the form outward, playfully transgressing received notions of the audience-performer relationship. And we’re not slowing down anytime soon.

Nice things folks have said: “Engrossing… magnetically performed… Mugwumpin is cutting new edges on its own, enjoyably adventurous terms.” –Robert Hurwitt, SF Chronicle

Why do we need your support?

We are graciously being supported by ACT, who are hosting us as residents in the Costume Shop Theater, and Intersection for the Arts, who are hosting several other events. But we have over 30 artists involved in making Mugwumpin10 happen. And I don’t know if you’ve heard, but the Bay Area is hella expensive (as the locals say). We need to pay these remarkable, passionate people!

For those who like specifics: This campaign will directly pay the fees for the seven performers and two directors of our two revivals, This Is All I Need and Super:Anti:Reluctant.

For those who like the big picture: Mugwumpin10 is our stake in the cultural terrain of San Francisco. Even as the financial squeeze hits more and more artists, we are standing with these fierce artists and with our community. We are continuing to make work that is not corporate, that is not easy, that cuts against the grain. And we are working creatively and furiously to build connections among the performance communities here and with the communities of other cities to build strength and health in the SF performance scene.

Your support, in any form, amplifies our call that live art—all art—in this city matters.

How can you support?

First and foremost: COME AND SEE THE WORK! We make it for you. And we have a LOT of projects that comprise this celebration. Come to as many as you can! If it’s too pricey for you, let us know, and we’ll see what we can do!

If you can afford it: DONATE TO THIS CAMPAIGN! Mugwumpin is fiscally sponsored by Intersection for the Arts, a registered 501(c)3 non-profit, so all donations are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law. And any amount helps! Be as generous as your wallet allows.

And finally: SPREAD THE WORD! Let people know about this campaign and the work Mugwumpin is doing. We’ll build a little vacation hut in our hearts for you that you can come visit whenever you like.

THANK YOU!

(Feel free to stop reading here; if you want to know more, read on!)

What are we showing in Mugwumpin10?

REVIVALS IN REP

This Is All I Need (2010): Mugwumpin digs through closets and cupboards to untangle and retangle the threads connecting our hearts, our anxieties, and our stuff. With a fractured approach to storytelling, Mugwumpin explores the fine lines separating collector from hoarder. What’s driving the American urge to accumulate?


Super:Anti:Reluctant (2006/2008): By shamelessly unmasking our obsession with the American hero, Mugwumpin investigates various heroic archetypes and their sway over our culture. Superhero, frontier settler, noir  detective—each of them is a bit more than we could ever be. We strive to be better, to strike out alone, to claim our patch of land. And that’s how a nation is built.

NEW WORKS

Blockbuster Season (in-process): Mugwumpin newest piece is a furious, darkly hilarious critique of how Hollywood regurgitates an alarmist view of disaster, undermining civil society. Disaster movie clichés of panicking masses and the heroes who bring order serves as raw material, mixed with responses to real disasters.

Ten/Ten/Ten: A decade is a mouthful, a body-full, a mind-full. We’re ready for a reckoning. In celebration of its tenth birthday, Mugwumpin invites ten performing artists from across performance disciplines to give their versions of the past ten years in Bay Area performance in ten minutes. Be prepared for the personal, the passionate, the preposterous.

3 brand new Occurrences: Three Mugwumpin collaborators create new exploratory works, presented weekly, serving as aperitifs for Mugwumpin work currently in development. Occurrences are Mugwumpin’s series of performances for non-theater spaces.

WORKSHOPS FOR ARTISTS

After a decade of devising twisty, visually-striking, hilarious pieces large and small, Mugwumpin wants to celebrate our birthday in the studio with our fellow artists. Mugwumpin company members and associates team up to lead four workshops aimed at sharing our foundational collaborative practices developed over ten years of live art-making.

SALON AND SYMPOSIA

Artists and thinkers, both local and national, discuss the most pressing topics facing Bay Area artists today and in the next ten years. With lots of amazing special guests!

story:
ABOUT US:

The End Times Cabaret uses aerial, burlesque, live dance, a brass band, multiple vocalists and more to examine a transitional moment in American history and culture through music and performance. Our team is Francesca Hoffman, executive producer/director, and Phil Andrews, musical director/arranger.

Our pilot show, Lolo & the Midnight Cabaret, took place in August 2011 -- the product of an unexpected opportunity and the talents and hard work of our producers and community. It was a surprise success; one that led us to grow and conceptualize what would become The End Times Cabaret.

Since that first steamy night two years ago, we have presented two other shows: one inspired by the infamous 1959 Buddy Holly plane crash (THE DAY THE MUSIC DIED) and the other by the end of the disco era (THE LAST DAYS OF DISCO). In 2012 we obtained fiscal sponsorship from Fractured Atlas and have since been been working on booking and putting together our next show.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

At this stage we are very excited to bring to you the third installment in our series, THE GREAT CRASH, which will explore the musical transition of the late 1920’s into the early Great Depression, exploring jazz, blues and swing, flappers, prohibition, and much more, but we need your help!

As we’ve grown, our costs have grown. We firmly believe in paying our performers what they deserve for their time, talent and energy, but that has not been possible with the payout from the venues we work with alone. We also incur many other costs in the production of this project, and so the funds raised from this campaign will cover performer stipends, rehearsal space rental, costumes, and technical support.

Your contribution will help ensure that our show runs smoothly, our performers are happy, and that the show will be the best it can be!

WHAT YOU GET

We have many perks to offer you for your contribution, from tickets to the show itself, to mix CDs of music from our last shows, to a backstage pass to hang out with our cast. Here’s the breakdown:  

(50) Shout-outs in our program and Facebook page, $5 each

(35) Your choice of CD! Choose from a soundtrack CD from our past shows (20), or an album featuring End Times performers, such as Apocalypse Five & Dime (10) or Gay Panic (5), $20 each

(20) Musical Phone Telegrams! Choose from Trombone Telegrams from End Times trombonist Sebastian Isler (12) or Vocal Telegrams from End Times Vocalist DeeDee Vega (8) $35 each

(4) Beginner Music Lessons (45 min): your choice of flute (from End Times Producer Francesca Hoffman) or banjo, trombone, trumpet, arranging or songwriting from End Times music director Phil Andrews, $50 each

(2) Professional Editorial Reads on manuscripts or Artist Statement/Website Edit, $75 each

(3) Aerial Silks Classes from End Times aerialist Rebecca Heinegg (90 min), $100 each

(3) All-Out Drag Make-Up Session by our very own Ariana Huffenstuff (drag queens and faux queens accepted), $300 each

(2) Two Backstage Passes with the cast after the show + two tickets to the show, plus soundtrack CD, $250 each

(1) 4 Backstage Passes with cast after show + four tickets + soundtrack CD, $500 each

(2) 4 Backstage Passes with cast after show + four tickets + soundtracks to past show + private End Times Brass Band performance at your next party or event! $1000

 

----

Come see "The Great Crash" at the Slipper Room, on September 19th and 22nd at 7:30PM!

story:
Our Company

A Company of Some is named after the late Canadian actor - and great uncle of our producer/playwright - Daniel Hyatt's internationally touring solo company: A Company of One. It was Daniel's practice to take well know literary works and adapt them to the stage. A Company of Some continues this tradition by re-imagining the classic "Old Woman Who Lived in a Shoe" nursery rhyme as a macabre thriller. We are fortunate enough to have partnered with the Bata Shoe Museum, who are generally hosting us for the run of the festival.

Our Production

Mrs. Mama's House is nursery rhyme magic with a Grimm twist. The show was conceived out of a fever dream and a deadline. The initial 15 minute script has been expanded and workshopped across various University of Toronto Festivals and is ready to take the Fringe this summer.

This absurd retelling of the "Old Woman who Lived in a Shoe" nursery rhyme looks at what happens when an institution has "too many children" and "doesn't know what to do". The show takes place in a home where shoes are prized possessions and treated as invaluable collector's items. By teaming up with the Bata Shoe Museum, we are staging a site-informed show in an exhibit where shoes are placed behind glass on literal pedestals. There will be a layered approach to this production, where the work informs the space and the space likewise informs the work.

Our Goal

We want to share this off-kilter adventure with as many audiences as we can, and we could use your help to make that happen. Our goal is to produce some intrepid work on a shoestring budget, thereby sending our box office earnings directly into the pockets of our performers. We also aim to ensure that our collaborating designers are fairly compensated for their efforts. We are seeking your support to help facilitate this process.

Artists fees aside, our budget is allocated thusly:

  • $1200 for rehearsal space
  • $700 for creative contracts (designers, photographers, etc.)
  • $600 for administrative and promotional costs

Any additional donations will also go directly to supporting our wonderful creative team of artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

Since shoes are such an important part of the design of this show, we are also accepting in kind donations of old shoes to decorate our space. If you have any old shoes or boots in need of a new home, please contact us at companyofsome@gmail.com. After the show's run, we will be contacting a local organization to re-donate these shoes to Torontonians in need of footwear. 

If you are unable to contribute financially, sharing this campaign would be a help in and of itself. Feel free to use the hashtag #MamasHouseTO. You can also follow us across social media at @SomeCompanyTO.

story:
Who are we?

Hi! We're BOO-Arts Productions and we are a New York City based independent theatre company.  We are dedicated to creating art which stimulates thought and provokes discussion that deepens relationships within our community.  We have a passion for the classics and philanthropy so it is our great joy to present our annual Holiday Celebration, It's a Wonderful Life, the radio show, which allows us to do a holiday classic while also giving back.  This year we are co-producing our Holiday Celebration with Gotham Radio Theatre presenting Rudolph's Tale: A 1964 Christmas.  Both Radio Theatre shows will be performed in rep at the Arclight Theatre in New York City on December 13th-15th.  A percentage of the proceeds from both performances will be donated to Habitat for Humanity New York City.

What do we need?

Last year we donated 20% of ticket sales (before paying off production costs) to Habitat for Humanity New York City.  This year we want to do even more.  Ticket sales usually cover the expense of producing a show: theatre rental, marketing, programs, rehearsal space, etc.  With $2,500 raised through this campaign those expenses will be covered right off the bat.  We can then use our ticket sales to pay our actors and team for their work, give more money to Habitat for Humanity New York City, and start off our 2014 season with a nest egg.

What is "Radio Theatre"?

Ever wonder how they made radio broadcast performances?  What did the actors with such distinctly characterized voices actually look like?  How did they make all of those sound effects?  We invite you to come watch Radio Theatre and find out!  Join us on our recording studio sound stage to see the cast perform the 1947 Lux Radio Theatre version of It's a Wonderful Life for live broadcast.  See the magic of double (and triple and quadruple and non-conventional) casting at work, enjoy timeless commercial breaks, and watch live foley sound effects being made.

Thank you!

Thanks for supporting our work!  Radio Theatre is a lost art form and we are excited to be partnering with Gotham Radio Theatre to bring it back while presenting two holiday classics for a good cause.  We couldn't do it without your patronage and we thank you for contributing in whatever way you can.

Learn more.

For more information about BOO-Arts Productions and to see photos and cast lists of previous years' Holiday Celebrations visit www.boo-arts.com.

To learn more about Habitat for Humanity New York City visit www.habitatnyc.org. 

To see more Radio Theatre check out our co-producers for this show: Gotham Radio Theatre. www.gothamradiotheatre.com.

Who are we?
Hi! We're BOO-Arts Productions and we are a New York City based independent theatre company.  We are dedicated to creating art which stimulates thought and provokes discussion that deepens relationships within our community.  We have a passion for the classics and philanthropy so it is our great joy to present our annual Holiday Celebration, It's a Wonderful Life, the radio show, which allows us to do a holiday classic while also giving back.  This year we are co-producing our Holiday Celebration with Gotham Radio Theatre presenting Rudolph's Tale: A 1964 Christmas.  Both Radio Theatre shows will be performed in rep at the Arclight Theatre in New York City on December 13th-15th.  A percentage of the proceeds from both performances will be donated to Habitat for Humanity New York City.


What do we need?

story:
NUESTRA HISTORIA, ¿QUIÉNES SOMOS?

Somos el Teatro de la Mente, la única compañía teatral de ficción sonora en vivo de Costa Rica. Nacimos en el año 2011 como un grupo no lucrativo ansioso por crear nuevas experiencias y compartir nuestra visión humana del mundo. Desde el principio, todas nuestras obras han sido declaradas de interés cultural por el Ministerio de Cultura y Juventud de Costa Rica.

Existimos para expandir cultura y crear conciencia social a través de relatos contados con la magia combinada de voces, efectos de sonido, silencios y música.

Somos una familia diversa. Al TDM lo conformamos locutores, productores de radio y actores, aficionados y  profesionales, amigos y colegas, mujeres y hombres, niños, jóvenes y adultos, que aman la ficción hecha sonido y creen, sobre todo, en el poder ilimitado de la imaginación y en la fuerza transformadora de las historias con gran contenido humano. Cada uno de nosotros dona su tiempo, talento y conocimiento para el crecimiento de la compañía.

OUR STORY, WHO WE ARE?

We are the Teatro de la Mente (TDM), the Mind Theater, the only live sound fiction theater company in Costa Rica. We were born in 2011 as a non-profit group eager to create new experiences and share our human vision of the world. From the beginning, the Ministry of Culture and Youth of Costa Rica have declared all our plays of cultural interest.

We exist to expand culture and create social awareness through stories told with the magical combination of voices, sound effects, silences and music.

We are a diverse family. TDM is made up of speakers, radio producers and actors, amateurs and professionals, friends and colleagues, women and men, children, youngsters and adults, who love fiction made sound, and who firmly believe in the unlimited power of imagination and the transforming power of stories with great human content. Each of us, donates his time, talent and knowledge to the growth of the company.

 

¿POR QUÉ NECESITAMOS DE USTED?

 “PADRINOS Y MADRINAS DEL TDM” es una campaña que nos permitirá asegurar la vitalidad y el desarrollo sostenido de nuestro proyecto cultural y permitirá también el inicio de nuestra temporada 2018 en un teatro local.

Gracias a la ayuda que recibamos, podremos realizar nuestra misión principal: crear conciencia social con obras hechas para ser vividas desde la magia única del sonido.

Al unirse a esta campaña usted formará parte de un valiosísimo cuerpo de donantes que cree en el poder del arte.  Su apoyo espiritual y monetario permitirá que muchos más puedan disfrutar de nuestras producciones y que el arte de la ficción sonora avance y crezca en nuestro país.

Al ser una organización relativamente joven y, además, que trabaja sin fines de lucro, dependemos de su generosidad para continuar con nuestro trabajo que estamos convencidos puede llevar luz a la vida de muchas personas.

WHY DO WE NEED YOU?

The "GODPARENTS AND GODMOTHERS OF THE TDM" campaign will allow us to ensure the vitality and sustained development of our cultural project. It will also help us with the beginning of our 2018 season at a local theater.

Thanks to the help we receive we will be able to achieve our main mission: create social awareness with plays made to be lived from the unique magic of sound.

By joining this campaign, you will be part of a very valuable group of donors who believes in the power of art. Your spiritual and monetary support will allow many more people to enjoy our productions and will make the art of sound fiction advance and grow in our country.

By being a non-profit, relatively young organization, we depend on your generosity to continue our work, which we are convinced will bring light to the lives of many people.

 

EN CONCRETO, ¿QUÉ QUEREMOS?

En el pasado, hemos  apoyando a otras organizaciones y queremos seguir haciéndolo; además, queremos seguir manteniendo los precios de nuestros tiquetes asequibles para la mayoría, en un país donde la producción teatral es sumamente  costosa y se debe pagar importantes sumas de dinero por el uso de los espacios. Como nuestro padrino o madrina, usted nos ayudará enormemente a lograrlo.

Con los $1,200 que buscamos, no financiaremos todo nuestro trabajo; pero podremos asegurar un alto porcentaje de nuestros costos operativos y así seguir funcionando sin contratiempos. Cada aporte que recibamos será aprovechado seriamente. 

¿POR QUÉ $1,200?

COMPRA DE EQUIPOS NUEVOS NECESARIOS

$350

ESCENOGRAFÍA

$200

VESTUARIO

$650

TOTAL

$1,200

 

IN CONCRETE, WHAT DO WE WANT?

In the past, we have supported other organizations and we want to continue doing so. In addition, we want to continue maintaining affordable prices for our tickets, in a country where theater production is extremely expensive and large sums of money must be paid for the use of the spaces. As our godfahter or godmother, you will help us enormously to achieve it.

With the $ 1,200 that we are looking for, we will not finance all our work; but we can ensure a high percentage of our operating costs and thus continue to operate smoothly. Every contribution we receive will be taken seriously.

¿WHY $1,200?

PURCHASE OF NEW NEEDED EQUIPMENT

$350

SCENOGRAPHY

$200

COSTUMES

$650

TOTAL

$1,200

 

ESTAS SON NUESTRAS RECOMPENSAS A SU COLABORACIÓN:

  • AGRADECIMIENTO: En el día de su cumpleaños, a través de nuestra página de Facebook, daremos a conocer nuestro agradecimiento público hacia usted por ser uno de nuestros padrinos o madrinas.
  • VIDEO: Una vez que haya finalizado nuestra campaña, le haremos llegar de forma privada un mensaje personal en video directamente hasta  su correo electrónico.
  • NOMBRE EN ESCENARIO: En cada una de nuestras presentaciones su nombre estará colocado en una pantalla en el escenario previo al inicio de la función y además estará impreso en un banner que llevará el nombre de todos nuestros padrinos y madrinas y que será expuesto en un lugar preferencial del teatro.
  • BOLETÍN BIMENSUAL: Usted recibirá nuestro boletín digital con información exclusiva de nuestro trabajo, cada bimestre.
  • ENTRADAS: Usted obtiene 1 o 2 entradas para el estreno de “Melico Salazar, el maestro”, obra con que arranca nuestra temporada 2018; así como acceso preferente a la compra de entradas en la mejor ubicación del aforo, según disponibilidad, durante todo el año.
  • CAMISETA: Usted recibe una camiseta con  nuestro logo; además de una nota escrita a mano por todos nosotros.
  • CLASE: Usted podrá participar de forma exclusiva en una clase maestra sobre el uso correcto de la voz hablada; con la guía personal de nuestro staff técnico.
  • RECORRIDO: En una función de su escogencia, usted podrá ir con uno de los miembros del staff tras el escenario para hacer un corto recorrido y conocer los detalles de la producción: mesa de control, arte Foley, ambientes y vestuario.

THESE ARE OUR REWARDS TO YOUR COLLABORATION:

  • PUBLIC THANKS: On your birthday, through our Facebook page, we will announce our public thanks to you for being one of our sponsors.
  • PERSONAL VIDEO: Once our campaign have finished, we will send you a personal video message directly to your email address.
  • ON STAGE: In each of our presentations your name will be placed on a stage’s screen prior to the start of the show and will also be printed on a banner that will bear the name of all our godparents and godmothers and will be displayed in a preferential place of the theater.
  • NEWSLETTER: You will receive our digital newsletter with exclusive information about our work, every two months.
  • TICKETS: You get 1 or 2 tickets for the premiere of "Melico Salazar, the master", play with which our season 2018 starts; as well as preferential access to the purchase of tickets in the best location of the capacity, according to availability, throughout the year.
  • T-SHIRT: You receive a t-shirt with  our logo; in addition to a handwritten note by all of us.
  • MASTER CLASS: You can participate exclusively in a master class on the correct use of the spoken voice; with the personal guidance of our technical staff.
  • GUIDED TOUR: In a show of your choice, you can go with one of the staff members behind the stage to make a short tour and know the details of the production: control table, Foley art, sound environments and costumes.

 

OTRAS FORMAS EN QUE NOS PUEDE AYUDAR

Ya sea que elija o no hacer una contribución financiera, lo invitamos a unirse a nosotros y ser parte de nuestro viaje. Aquí hay otras formas en que puede contribuir:

  • Síganos en Facebook y Soundcloud y comparta nuestras publicaciones.
  • Use las herramientas de intercambio de Indiegogo y cuéntele a sus amigos y familiares sobre nuestra campaña.

Realmente apreciamos  que crea en nosotros. ¡Muchas gracias!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Whether or not you choose to make a financial contribution, we invite you to join us and be part of this our journey. Here are some other ways you can contribute:

  • Follow us on Facebook and Soundcloud and share our posts.
  • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools and tell your friends and family about our campaign.

We really appreciate your belief in us. Thank you!

story:
Introducing Ourselves: 

  We are a group of young twentysomethings in college, and some fresh outta college, looking to create theatre in a way that will give back to the community. Producing Dog Sees God is our first big leap into creating a theatre company (The Fearless Theatre Collabrative) that will focus solely on teenagers. In doing so, we hope to become a theatre for young aspiring actors and actresses in the Chicago community to have a venue and an outlet for performance. We are synching up the themes in the plays we choose to explore with charities that also reflect the issues and topics in our performances. For Dog Sees God we are raising money for the Tyler Clementi Foundation. Tyler was a young musician who attended Rutgers University and was a victim of homophobic bullying that lead to his suicide. The funds for Dog Sees God will not only go to a new up and coming theatre company but to educational partnernships involved in the Tyler Clementi Foundation to raise awarness in our high schools.

What is Dog Sees God About?

Dog Sees God: Confessions of A Teenage Blockhead premiered off Broadway in 2005,  Written by Bert V. Royal (Easy A), Dog Sees God is a contemporary take on Charles Schultz’s “Peanuts” comics. When CB's dog dies from rabies, his whole world comes crashing down on him. He begins to question everything: life after death, his sexuality, and his friendships. Our familiar friends are now angst ridden high schoolers trying to find their place in the modern world. This dark comedy explores themes of sexuality, rebelling, bullying, suicide, and acceptance. 

 What We Are Asking For: 

Our goal is to raise $2,500 for the production of DOG SEES GOD, and we cannot raise the funds without your support. The money you donate will go towards the following:

  • Our performance venue at the Rivendell Theatre Company.
  • Buying the performance rights (75$ per performance).
  • Publicity Materials & Printing.
  • Scenic Elements/Props/Costumes.

***Whatever we have left over will be contributed to the Tyler Clementi Foundation. 

 

Additional Info:

DOG SEES GOD presented by the Fearless Theatre Collaborative.
WHEN: JULY 19TH-26TH (THURSDAY-SATURDAY @ 7:30PM)
WHERE: RIVENDELL THEATRE 5779 N. Ridge Avenue
TICKETS: http://dogseesgodchicago.eventbrite.com/
EMAIL: fearlesstheatrecollaborative@Gmail.com
WEBSITE: http://dogseesgochicago.weebly.com

Starring: Will Lidkie (CB), Nicholas Hyland (Beethoven) , Alison Sweat (CB's Sis) Adam Marcantoni (Van), Aubrey Brummett (Van's Sis), Caitlyn Cerza (Marcy), Hillary Horvath (Tricia)  and Alex Bagett (Matt) 

Directed by: Derek Herman

story:
A little bit about the person in need

Miss Cairo is a london based drag queen, perfoming regularly on the burlesque, cabaret and queer curcuits. She is a queen of gender deception and works heavily on gender perception, centralling her work on the fluidity of gender, oreintation and the harsh reality of saving face.

An all rounder, she sings like an angel, dances like a hooker, and strips like a bottle of turpentine. She is an insatiable host; turning heads, turning people on and turning it out, and has hosted for many fabulous events and prestigeous venues up and down the country. Mss Cairo has also appeared on TV and has many intresting projecs in the pipeline. 

As well as performance, Miss Cairo aids and teaches workshops which introduce people into the world of drag and divahood, coaxing people out of thier shells and discovering thier inner fabulousness. Miss Cairos philosophy is that everyone is fabulos, but they may just not kow it yet.

 

How can you help?

Although being a drag queen is fun and exciting, it can also be extremely difficult. Whilst we may earn enough for rent money and champagne, a lot of people may not understand that the majotiy of the money earnt has to get invested staright back into costumes, shoes, wigs, makeup and props, some of which are very expensive. In the last two years that Miss Cairo has been building up her career, she has managed to do well with the resources she's had and built up an extensive array of costumes and make up. However, a lot of it isn't perfect enough for a lot of her routines and comperig jobs. 

There are two dresses that she would like to purchase in order for her to feel that little bit more special when on stage. 

The first is a beautiful, full length red sequin dress that would be perfect for her Jessica Rabbit routine. The dress is priced at £70, but she would also need a new wig costing £60, and make up shoes and accesories which would probably cost aroud £60. If you haven't yet seen the routine, here is a link to a video of said routine...

http://youtu.be/4MdlPET8xlk

I shall be taking this routine to Finland and really want to look fabulous for The Turku Burlesque Festival!

The main reason for this pledge is for a dress she found in a shop yesterday. She hasn't yet got a dress which she sees fit enought to host in, until she found this one pictured. it is perfect for Miss Cairo as it has all the wonderful elements of an egyptian of an ancient egyptian design, the cut is perfect for her figure, and the light gold material highlights her beautifully olive skin tone. When she tried it on, it looked like a bride had just found her perfect wedding dress. The only trouble is, she doesn't have the funds to pay for it. The dress is selling for £295 and they only have one in her size left. It will be sacrilige if she doesn't own this dress. When you see her in it, you'll understand why!

 

And why would you want to help?

Not only would you like to help a drag queen out because you have a large heart, you also want to see photos and videos of her looking beautiful, and see her in shows looking ravishing... 

Without the headache of having to worry about making the rent, Miss Cairo can focus on creating more subversive wrk, projects to aid our brothers and sisters in the LGBT community, write scripts for her web series and focus all her energy pushing her work further into making an impact on peoples lives. Having the time to be able to concetrate on the harddwork that goes behind her drag is imperitive, and being helped out with costumes allows her to have the time to carry on creating new work for all of you that love a bit of Cairo!
story_txt:
A little bit about the person in need
Miss Cairo is a london based drag queen, perfoming regularly on the burlesque, cabaret and queer curcuits. She is a queen of gender deception and works heavily on gender perception, centralling her work on the fluidity of gender, oreintation and the harsh reality of saving face.
An all rounder, she sings like an angel, dances like a hooker, and strips like a bottle of turpentine. She is an insatiable host; turning heads, turning people on and turning it out, and has hosted for many fabulous events and prestigeous venues up and down the country. Mss Cairo has also appeared on TV and has many intresting projecs in the pipeline. 
As well as performance, Miss Cairo aids and teaches workshops which introduce people into the world of drag and divahood, coaxing people out of thier shells and discovering thier inner fabulousness. Miss Cairos philosophy is that everyone is fabulos, but they may just not kow it yet.
 
How can you help?
Although being a drag queen is fun and exciting, it can also be extremely difficult. Whilst we may earn enough for rent money and champagne, a lot of people may not understand that the majotiy of the money earnt has to get invested staright back into costumes, shoes, wigs, makeup and props, some of which are very expensive. In the last two years that Miss Cairo has been building up her career, she has managed to do well with the resources she's had and built up an extensive array of costumes and make up. However, a lot of it isn't perfect enough for a lot of her routines and comperig jobs. 
There are two dresses that she would like to purchase in order for her to feel that little bit more special when on stage. 
The first is a beautiful, full length red sequin dress that would be perfect for her Jessica Rabbit routine. The dress is priced at £70, but she would also need a new wig costing £60, and make up shoes and accesories which would probably cost aroud £60. story:
What is the project?

Restore premieres February 25th, in honor of The National Eating Disorder Association’s (NEDA) Eating Disorder Awareness Week. In a presentation that can be described as interactive therapy, Redeem brings the artist’s healing process to their audience. Borne Dance Company will gather a collective of musicians, speakers, and movers of varying dynamics for an evening of artistic expression and inspiration while simultaneously providing educational resources. The evening will include original works of art from the realms of dance, music, literature and visual art. In the spirit and belief that art should be made accessible to everyone in our communities, admission will be donation-based and all proceeds will go NEDA. Thanks to Indiegogo and donated pieces of art from local artists, we hope to be able to make this event a success.

Why should you help?

In 2015 the first annual Eating Disorder Awareness Show was produced by Borne co-director Katie Kilbourn.  As a recovered bulimic she felt that there was a general misunderstanding and lack of education surrounding severe mental illnesses and wanted to shed light on these topics through artistic expression. Since 2015, the show has increased significantly in size, attendance, interest and  participation. Each year we have experienced a 25% increase in audience attendance, as well as a significant increase in the amount of artists who wish to showcase their work in this event. Eating disorders affect the lives of many people and we realize it is necessary for our community to have a safe place where artists can share their voices on these disorders. We have had audience members from all types of backgrounds at our event from those who had recovered from eating disorders, to those looking for answers and education, and those who were looking to give support and receive inspiration.  While we are thrilled to produce a show that personally touches so many people, we are also faced with the financial difficulties and stress that comes with an increase in production. This year we would like to be able to host guests artists with larger companies as well as rent a larger theater than we have in the past. It is our mission to not take home any proceeds made at this show because we are dedicated to contributing the money made back to NEDA. With the generous help of supporters like you we can rent a larger theater space, afford to host more companies and artists, pay for better marketing material, and pay our artists for their dedicated time, commitment, and energy. With your help we can help share the message that recovery is possible.

Who are we?

Borne Dance Company was founded in the summer of 2015 by New York based artists Katie Kilbourn and Kianna Moye and this show will mark our two year anniversary.  Through our own personal experiences and research we strive to create thought provoking work that  sparks interest, compassion, and empathy in our audience. We believe that education and compassion can lead to the prevention and an understanding of eating disorders and other mental illnesses and we want to inspire everyone to embrace themselves despite what mental health challenges they may face.

Since its inception in 2015 Borne has performed at The Producer’s Club, Green Space, Anita’s Way, Dixon Place, and has collaborated with Cultural Workers.  In January 2018 we will give an art and mental health workshop and performance to the inpatient adolescents at Bellevue Hospital. Over the past year we have also become clothing ambassadors and collaborators with Schizophrenic.nyc and Project Heal. Schizophrenic.nyc is a clothing company created by a schizophrenic girl that is dedicated to mental health awareness in NYC.  Project Heal is a non profit company that raises funds to help those who are suffering with eating disorders go to inpatient care.

 

 

How you can help?

No contribution is too small, however we do understand that living off an artist's paycheck can be tough at times! If you are a broke and starving artist but would still like to contribute we're also accepting donated art pieces that fit the theme of Restore! For more information, please contact us at BorneDanceCompany@gmail.com. Broke but not an artist? You can help by spreading the word and sharing our campaign on your social media pages! #BorneDanceCompany  #BorneFundraiser

story:
Be a part of history! Help make December 16th a recognized national holiday by sponsoring the 241st anniversary reenactment of the Boston Tea Party on December 16, 2014.

The Boston Tea Party – the single most important event leading up to the American Revolution

Play a role in this iconic event! Join Paul Revere and Samuel Adams in a rendezvous with history!

The Boston Tea Party comes alive this December! 

December 16, 2014 marks the 241st anniversary of The Boston Tea Party. Presented by Boston’s famed Old South Meeting House, the Boston Tea Party Ships & Museum, and the December 16th, 1773, Inc. Foundation, the Annual Reenactment is an opportunity for the public to take part in one of Boston’s most important public protests. and, in the process, help make this date a recognized national holiday. 

The story of the Boston Tea Party is told in three acts:

Act I: The Body of the People: A dramatic recreation of Boston’s largest colonial town meeting at the historic Old South Meeting House. Audience members will interact with Samuel Adams, John Hancock, Paul Revere, and the Sons of Liberty as they engage the crowd in a fiery tax debate. Visitors are encouraged to join the debate, letting their voices be heard, and join in the final vote in the very place where Liberty found her allies!

Act II: Huzzah for Griffin’s Wharf: Led by multiple fife and drum corps, the attendees from the meeting join with general public and march from Old South Meeting House to the Harborwalk where Griffin’s Wharf once stood. Along the way, those marching will encounter a harassing Redcoat Regiment in Post Office Square.

Act III: Boston Harbor, a Tea Pot Tonight!: Just as the citizens of Boston did over 240 years before, thousands of people line the shores of Boston Harbor and watch as the Sons of Liberty storm aboard the ships and destroy chest after chest of East India Company Tea. Viewers are encouraged to participate and yell “Huzzah!” as they witness the dramatic conclusion to the single most important event leading up to the American Revolution. This segment includes seated VIP viewing areas and standing room for thousands of general public.

“Salt water and tea shall mix tonight!” 

On the cold, damp night of Thursday, December 16, 1773 the “tea crisis” in Boston came to a head. For several weeks, the citizens of Boston had been meeting to discuss the landing of the East India Company Tea in Boston Harbor. The Sons of Liberty had requested that the consignees, or wholesalers, resigned their positions and send the tea back to England. This tactic had worked in our sister colonies and any drastic action was avoided. The Boston consignees refused to resign. The Sons of Liberty sent Francis Rotch, owner of the ships Dartmouth and Beaver, to meet with Royal Governor Thomas Hutchinson to request that the ships be allowed to exit Boston Harbor without unloading the tea. (Boston Law stated that each ship had twenty days to unload its cargo and pay the duties upon it.) Hutchinson refused and the Sons of Liberty were left with no other choice. An undisclosed number of men went down to Griffin’s Wharf, in various states of disguise, and quickly boarded the three ships moored. In an organized operation, the men dumped 340 crates of East India Company Tea into Boston Harbor in a matter of three hours. It was said that thousands of Bostonians stood silently on the shore, watching the “destruction of the tea”. Over 92,000 pounds of tea were destroyed and thrown into the harbor. The men knew the gravity of their actions and no one spoke of this event for many years for fear of retribution. The first list of names connected to the “destruction of the tea” was not published until 1835.

The Sons of Liberty were quite different on the night of December 16, 1773. They had been fighting against “taxation without representation” for many years in the form of riots and intimidation. Through the influence of such men as John Hancock and John Adams, the Sons of Liberty began to operate in a more organized fashion. The “destruction of the tea” was more than just the actions of a chaotic mob; it was a calculated political protest.

The implication and impact of the Boston Tea Party were enormous. After years of civil unrest, the implementation of The Coercive Acts in 1774, and the meeting of the First Continental Congress, the stage was set for conflict. The country was a tinderbox ready to ignite and the match was lit on April 19, 1775, in Lexington, MA, in what would become known as the American Revolution.

Our goal is to make December 16th a nationally recognized holiday.

We firmly believe that the Boston Tea Party was the single most important event leading up to the American Revolution. The date of December 16th should be observed as a national holiday for the sacrifices that were made on that fateful night in 1773. These men willingly committed treason, punishable by death, to fight for their liberties. The “destruction of the tea” led to the creation of a new nation. We hope that through the production of the Annual Reenactment and further education of the events of December 16, 1773, this goal will become a reality. As the success of the Boston Tea Party depended upon the participation of the Patriots, so too will the establishment of December 16th as a national holiday depend on you.

Your generous contribution will go towards:

  • Local and national promotion, publicity and marketing of event
  • Stage set design
  • Production services including lighting and sound
  • Bleacher seating for viewing of reenactment
  • Costumes
  • Video and photography production of event
  • Fife and drum corps
  • Program printing
  • Volunteer expenses
  • Security
  • Permits

story:
Antic in a Drain's 'The Greatest Monkey Show On Earth' is a solo work that explores themes of captivity and freedom through character-driven, audience-interactive clown and bouffon comedy along with acrobatics and the circus disciplines of Chinese pole and hoop diving. This show fuses together the artistic disciplines that I, Ross Travis, have been researching and practicing independently for the last six years. I am combining my four years of training and performing as a Chinese pole acrobat with my six years of performing and training as a bouffon and clown.

I began the project in January 2014 with a six month window of time in which to pull it together. I am currently an Artist in Residence at the Circus Center of San Francisco where I am developing the piece. The last four months have been an incredible experience as I work on all aspects of the production; from building the costume, writing the script, building the props and getting the marketing materials ready. The community of artists that I am a part of have been incredibly supportive of me - giving me in-kind donations of time, expertise and feedback to make this show incredible. I am so grateful to them. 

I have been showing pieces of this work every two or three weeks and getting feedback from my peers. I am showing public excerpts of the work in the Fools Fury Factory Parts Festival  on July 8th and 9th, 2014. Then I will be culminating my residency at Circus Center with a showing of the full piece on August 4th and 5th, 2014 before launching off to Canada.

THIS IS WHERE YOU COME IN! 

Your support will help send me and this show to Canada where I have been accepted into the Edmonton International Fringe Festival (August 14th - 24th, 2014) as well as theVancouver Fringe Festival (September 4th to 14th, 2014.) 

The money I raise through this campaign will go to:

- Gas, camping fees and food money both on the way up to Canada and during my time there.

- Marketing materials. I need to make posters, postcards and buttons to sell my show! 

- The materials and labor to build my own set of hoops for hoop diving. I also need to buy a mat for me to land on. 

- Realistic severed body parts for an important part of my show. 

Thank you so much for your support of this project.

story:
THE UGA RED HOTZ WANT TO TAKE NATIONALS BY STORM!

The UGA Red Hotz are one of the University of Georgia's best kept secrets. We are a completely student ran dance team. We get a small amount of funding from our school and the rest is up to us! This year, we want to be taken seriously. We don't want to just compete at Nationals, we want to be considered competition. In order to be competitive you need to have the funds to do so. The funds we raise will go towards our costumes, choreography, and travel expenses. 

We have something to prove; to ourselves, to our school, and to our peers. We are more than just a club sports dance team. We are athletes. We train like athletes, and want to be treated like athletes. 

We worked extremely hard this past year to go to nationals with a great routine and we succeeded. Next year we want to work even harder. We want to surprise everyone. In order to do so we have to start the year out with nationals on our mind. We have elite judges coming in to our auditions, we are taking extra classes in order to up our technique, and we are working closely with our choreographer who knows everything there is to know about nationals and the kind of dancers we need to be to succeed at nationals. Go Dawgs!

"DO IT WITH PASSION OR NOT AT ALL" 


To get to know us a little better, click on the link below to check out the video one of our dancers made before nationals last year! 

http://rossmade.mynmi.net/publish_to_web/soundslider.swf

story:
Short Summary

In 2012, Rarely Pure Theatre started as a one-woman force of nature.

Founder Monique Renaud had a blazing ambition to write, direct and produce a piece. Being a mere 12 months out of theatre school (and 3 months pregnant), Monique made a plan, set a date, and stuck to it… all by herself.

This level of enthusiasm, dedication and passion is what created Rarely Pure Theatre, and drew the remaining of its core artists. Since its’ inception 4 years ago, the company’s seemingly short history has been coloured and crammed with 6 full productions, and 12 special events; all of which are collaborations with young painters, graphic designers, cinematographers, writers, technicians and, of course, the city’s finest young performing talent. We’ve performed in art galleries, café’s and dance studios, but not because we’ve had “no other choice”. We make these meticulous decisions based on what we feel necessary for each production. With this open structure process, we are striving to ensure that we continue to reach and touch audiences in new ways, and continue the journey towards engaging our Canadian audience.

Our next production, Choking the Butterfly, will be performed in Windsor and Toronto and is a partnership with the University of Windsor. We are trying to raise enough funds to help pay the travel expenses for our creative and production team.

We want to give back to our donors and show our appreciation to you! Check out our perks and find the package that suits you!

What We Need & What You Get

      We need to provide travel funds for our actors and stage manager as they get from our Windsor performance to Toronto. With indie theatre, the artists are often asked to pay into the production and we are trying to avoid this situation. They are professionals and deserve to be paid for their time and work.

      Check out our perks! We want to acknowledge all of our donors online through social media, our website or promotion! We know you want a DONOR TUB PHOTO. OR what about some secret BEHIND THE SCENES footage? 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Please spread the word about Rarely Pure Theatre's next production, Choking the Butterfly. Come out to The Garage Door Theatre in Windsor OR the Storefront Theatre in Toronto to experience some of the freshest indie theatre. 

You can also get to know us by visiting our website and reading about past productions, new initiatives and our vision for Canadian theatre.

Visit our WEBSITE!

Choking the Butterfly is playing in Windsor, Ontario and Toronto, Ontario. See dates below:

WINDSOR

May 27 - 7:30pm

May 28 - 7:30pm

May 29 - 2pm


TORONTO

June 9-11 - 8pm

June 12 - 2pm

June 15-18 - 8pm

June 19 - 2pm
story_txt:
Short Summary

In 2012, Rarely Pure Theatre started as a one-woman
force of nature.
Founder Monique Renaud had a blazing ambition to
write, direct and produce a piece. Being a mere 12 months out of theatre school
(and 3 months pregnant), Monique made a plan, set a date, and stuck to it… all
by herself.
This level of enthusiasm, dedication and passion
is what created Rarely Pure Theatre, and drew the remaining of its core
artists. Since its’ inception 4 years ago, the company’s seemingly short
history has been coloured and crammed with 6 full productions, and 12
special events; all of which are collaborations with young painters, graphic
designers, cinematographers, writers, technicians and, of course, the city’s
finest young performing talent. We’ve performed in art galleries, café’s and
dance studios, but not because we’ve had “no other choice”. We make these
meticulous decisions based on what we feel necessary for each production. With
this open structure process, we are striving to ensure that we continue to
reach and touch audiences in new ways, and continue the journey towards engaging our Canadian audience. 
Our next production, Choking the Butterfly, will be performed in Windsor and Toronto and is a partnership with the University of Windsor. We are trying to raise enough funds to help pay the travel expenses for our creative and production team.
We want 
to give back to our donors and show our appreciation to you! Check out 
our perks and find the package that suits you! 
   
What We Need & What You Get
 
     We need to provide travel funds for our actors and stage manager as they get from our Windsor performance to Toronto. With indie theatre, the artists are often asked to pay into the production and we are trying to avoid this situation. They are professionals and deserve to be paid for their time and work. 


 
     Check out our perks! We want to acknowledge all of our donors online through social media, our website or promotion! We know you want a DONOR TUB PHOTO. OR what about some secret BEHIND THE SCENES footage? 
  
Other Ways You Can Help  Please spread the word about Rarely Pure Theatre's next production, Choking the Butterfly. Come out to The Garage Door Theatre in Windsor OR the Storefront Theatre in Toronto to experience some of the freshest indie theatre. 
You can also get to know us by visiting our website and reading about past productions, new initiatives and our vision for Canadian theatre. 
Visit our WEBSITE!
Choking the Butterfly is playing in Windsor, Ontario and Toronto, Ontario. See dates below:
WINDSOR
May 27 - 7:30pm
May 28 - 7:30pm
May 29 - 2pm

TORONTO
June 9-11 - 8pm
June 12 - 2pm
June 15-18 - 8pm
June 19 - 2pm

story:
The Story

Our names are Rimah Jabr and Natasha Greenblatt and our play Two Birds One Stone has been selected to be part of The Riser Project this May, 2017.

We met two years ago. Originally from The West Bank, Rimah had just moved to Toronto after finishing her MA in Theatre Making in Belgium.  Natasha, also a theatre maker, was born and raised in Toronto. We became friends and decided to collaborate. 

Two Birds One Stone is the result of that collaboration. It's about our lives, our histories, and our different connection with the same house in Israel/Palestine. Most of it's true. It's personal, political, irreverent, and we're working with some amazing artists to bring it to life.

The Team

Dramaturge Guillermo Verdeccia is a playwright, director, and brilliant theatrical mind. He's worked across the globe, often tackling complex political subjects with humour and intelligence. He's originally from Argentina and hates Canadian winters with a passion. 

Production designer Anahita Debhonie is a force to be reckoned with in the Toronto independent Theatre and Film scene. Born in Tehran and raised in Toronto, Anahita has trained in California, Norway, and at the Soulpepper Academy. 

Originally from Serbia, sound designer Stefan Banjevic is a math teacher and a musician who toured Canada as one of the founding members of The Wilderness of Manitoba. He's currently working on a solo album and composing music for radio and television documentaries. Stefan will be collaborating with Canadian-born, CBC radio producer, Julia Pagel, to create a sound design with acoustic, electronic, and found sounds.

Our wonderful stage manager Dylan Tate-Howarth has worked with Jumblies Theatre, Bad News Theatre, and Theatre Smith-Gilmour, to name a few. She was born and raised in Toronto, Canada. 

The Riser Project

Two Birds One Stone is one of only 4 plays selected to be part of The Riser Project at The Theatre Centre. http://riserproject.org

Curated by the fine folks of Why Not Theatre, The Riser Project is an innovative, alternative model to help independent artists produce exciting new work. They provide rehearsal space, performance space, mentorship, and some artistic and technical support. However, most of the nuts and bolts producing is up to the artists. And that means raising funds.

The Ask

We're asking for your help to produce Two Birds One Stone. We were awarded $5000 by the Toronto Arts Council, but we need at least another $2000. This will allow us to rent a good quiet projector, build our set, print postcards to promote the show, AND pay the artists.

We know you have a lot of worthy causes to support and we're very grateful you stopped by to check us out. Please consider sharing our campaign. And please come see our show, May 3rd-13th at The Theatre Centre: http://tinyurl.com/z2jxbt8

With love, 

Natasha + Rimah
