story:
''We don't Have To Change At All!'' 


Dear Everyone! 
We are a new company ( ''Nocturne Theatre'' ) set up by a group of passionate actors and good friends - all recent graduates of  ''E15 Acting School''. We decided  to stop waiting for ''a lucky chance to fall from the sky'' and  to make the luck ourselves by working together. We're interested in creating something that would be  beautiful and meaningful to anyone regardless of their age, profession or  previous interest in theatre.

'' We Don't Have To Change At All'' is our first production - a dark  comedy about a brother and sister featuring two  clowns who portray  the  world around them. And with a little bit of help we can make it happen! 

All your contributions  will go towards  the production costs  and will provide the set, props and costumes as well as the rehearsal space and wages for the artists involved. Our play will open at Theatre N16, The Bedford, London  (Sunday 28th of February- Thursday 3rd of March) and we would love to see You there! 


Who are we:

 Daniel Bickersteth - Director /Founder

Hailing from the wild moors of Somerset, Daniel received his training at East 15 acting school, where he garnered the belief that the theatre and all art should be for everyone. Daniel has also studied film at London Central Film School. He is an experienced theatre actor, and has also worked on screen. A founder of Nocturne Theatre, Daniel is currently directing their début show: We Don't Have To Change At All.

  Will Allen- Assistant Director / Co-Founder

William has had various experiences with theatre companies, working as an Actor/Writer/Director. He attended ‘East 15 Acting School’ discovering the delights of World theatre, which further added to his repertoire. William looks to create bold, interesting theatre that draws influence from a variety of performance styles. A lover of collaborative theatre and bringing creative minds together!!!!


 Dominic Kiraly - Actor / Co-Founder

Born in 1990, Budapest, Hungary, Dominic moved to the UK in 2009 where he attended the Mountview Academy of Theatre and East15 Acting School. After finishing his studies in 2013, Dominic has started to establish himself in the theatre and film industry as well as lending his voice to various Hungarian commercials. Dominic is currently starring as Alex in Nocturne Theatre's debut project 'We Don't Have To Change At All'.

 Jane Feldberg - Actress/ Co-Founder

Friendly, adventurous and definitely a bit of a Wild spirit! Jane was born in Latvia (in the year of its independence - 1991) and after attending several different drama clubs and youth theatres, including her own, where she'd put on plays and make all her friends and family participate, Jane moved to England to study Acting and Community Theatre at East15 Acting School. She's also a frequent visitor of London film schools and absolutely  LOVES theatre,  currently playing Sofia in Nocturne Theatre's opening show.



Budget Breakdown:

  • Set -  £150
  • Costume -  £80
  • Make up (There will be clowns!) - £20 
  • Rehearsal Space - £ 600
  • Props- £50
  • Marketing  - £50
  • Wages*  - £ 2200 (4 actors x  £ 550 set fee each, for the duration of the project:  12 weeks in total)

*75% of the wages will be covered by the box office earnings and in this campaign we only require your help for the remaining 25%. (If you'd also like to support us by coming to see the show live -  That would be Amazing! )

The Impact


    There can never be enough of Good Theatre! We believe it's really important to create work that everyone involved  can be proud of and that would benefit the audience  coming to watch it. Our play is a new, company - devised piece that explores a complex relationship between two siblings and the choices they make: 
''In our black comedy, Alex, a seemingly quite young man, who lives with his controlling sister Sofia, and bullied by everyone he knows, is driven to explosive violence. With a host of bizarre characters and disobedient clowns populating the world around them, and the four small walls of their flat closing in on them, Alex & Sofia may try and regain the friendship they shared in their youth, but maybe there's nothing left to gain from remembering.''

Every little helps!  There's nothing like  friends to  encourage one  another in a time of need and  in our company we support each others projects and future ideas by helping them become true.  One of our core principles is to always pay our actors (and other creative members of a project - during our next productions) for their time and dedication. Unfortunately, it's too often a case of young artists having to provide their skills for free at the beginning stage of their career.

Diversity: Our company is a  mix of BA World Performance and BA Acting and Community Theatre graduates covering skills like Circus, Clown, Street Theatre, Storytelling, Puppetry, Chinese Opera, Balinese Dance, Commedia Dell'Arte, Music and many More (!!!) so get comfy and prepare to enjoy
the Unexpected and Imaginative!


''Baby Days''


 This is our first project as a company and we have to learn everything ''anew'' by making decisions (and mistakes!) as we go along in order to grow, but we are also confident that by working together we can overcome obstacles and improve with every single one of them! Any help (however big or small) that you can and would be happy to provide   during this early stage  will be greatly appreciated! :)

In return we're always happy to lead a free drama based workshop of your own choice (acting, improvisation, storytelling, puppetry) as a part of the campaign so feel free to get in touch!

 Other Ways You Can Help (Please, Do!) 

If at the moment You feel like giving away money is the last thing You can afford to do, that's fine, because there are many other ways You can help :)

  • Come and see the Show! (it opens on 28th of February so there's plenty of time to get a ticket);
  • Follow us on Twitter (@NOCTheatre) where we'll be posting the latest information of other smaller campaigns related to this production (sourcing extra props, costume etc. items ''in kind'')
  • Share the link of this Campaign to anyone you know who could help us by a small donation or would be interested to see the show (We offer a free drama workshop in a place & time of your own choice for all donations over £25).

story:
Who We Are: 

For 10 years now Space 55 has been one of downtown Phoenix's leading nonprofit arts organizations. We've worked alongside other local venues like The Trunk Space, The Firehouse Gallery, and The Torch Theatre to help create a diverse and thriving performance scene in the Valley. We've hosted late night comedy shows, variety shows, storytelling events, adult puppet shows, and put on several award-winning plays by playwrights like David Mamet, Greg Kotis,  Anne Washburn, and Anton Chekhov. We're committed to showcasing works by local authors as well as presenting plays from renowned playwrights that never get seen in Phoenix. We've also been recipients of the Phoenix New Times' Big Brain Award and the Mayor's Art Award.


Our Campaign:
The downside to being an independent nonprofit arts organization that's been around for a decade is that our tools and technology are woefully out of date. Over the last few years, we've had to change out our light boards on a few occasions and rewire our lights. The lights we have now are on their last legs, and our sound system has seen better days.
Over the last six months, we've begun saving up to update our tech. Our goal is to create a fully modular setup by installing easy-to-move LED lights. This will help us more effectively light our shows (which are getting increasingly more ambitious and complex) and also make it so that if we have to move to a new location in the future we'll be able to take our lights with us. While we're optimistic that we'll continue to be on 7th St. & Pierce for the foreseeable future, the truth is that downtown Phoenix is changing, gentrification is sweeping across the area, and should that tide sweep us up we want to be prepared and ready to land on our feet elsewhere. The problem is, with our current technology, if we have to move out, we can't take our lights with us. And a theater without lights isn't a theater.

What We'll Do With Our Funds:
We're asking for $10,000 so we can completely revamp our tech. We'll use that money to purchase a set of high quality, theatrical LED lights, a new light board, lighting trees, microphones, and a P.A. system. Our goal is to create a fully modular setup that can be moved into different buildings.
To be blunt: We're not huge fans of asking people for money. The truth is, we've prided ourselves on NOT doing a crowd-sourcing campaign for years. But we have no other choice: So much of our income goes into keeping our space going that we just don't have enough money left over to devote to giving ourselves a necessary and much-needed upgrade. If we could finance this project on our own, we would.

Why This Benefits The Community:
At Space 55 we don't do just put on our own shows. We also host shows for a variety of other arts organizations and groups in town, like the Storyline collective, the improvisers at The Torch Theatre, sketch comedy groups from Phoenix and Tempe, stand-up comics, and many others. We rent out our venue to other theater groups (at a much cheaper rate than most other venues in town) and help performers who don't have their own base of operations yet have a place to put on their shows. We also regularly host events like "7 Minutes in Heaven" and "9 Muses" that gives the general public and new performers a chance to get on our stage and stretch their performing wings.
Getting a new and more reliable lighting configuration in our space will make it so that not only will we put on better shows for ourselves, we'll also be able to make other people's shows better too.

What You'll Get:
Contributors to our campaign will receive a series of sweet perks, which include:
  • Admission to our "Turn On The Bright Lights" thank you show, an exclusive night of theatrical fun + karaoke afterparty that's only available to our contributors!
  • Space-55 shirts, stickers, and buttons!
  • Season passes to our shows!
  • Original chalk art prints from ensemble member Ashley Naftule! 

Our Promise To You:
Regardless of the success of our campaign and the changes sweeping downtown Phoenix, Space 55 is in this for the long haul. We've been here for ten years, building a strong center for the performing arts in our community. And we fully intend on fighting the good fight for years and years to come. Any dollar you can donate to helping us achieve our goals would be GREATLY appreciated.

story:
Help Us Bring Quality Shakespeare Across Ontario; 

and more importantly, into juvenile detention centres and the female prison system.

The Edge Productions is an independent theatre company that has been operating in Windsor, Ontario for over 7 years. We produce plays hard hitting and deeply empathetic productions in a wide variety of eras. From classical to musical and contemporary - we do it all. 

This season we are trying to bring something to communities less traveled to. We want to bring work into the juvenile detention centres and female prison systems. We believe art is inherently therapeutic, cathartic and inspiring. We believe theatre can bring hope and joy to people who may need it more than most. We believe theatre can change people for the better. 

We are touring an All-Female production of William Shakespeare's Henry V. It sounds cliché and trite to say these plays can help change lives, but they have and will continue to do so for longer than any of us will be around. Shakespeare's works have been wowing audiences for centuries. Literally CENTURIES, and still do today. Shakespeare will always be current and will always be popular.

We are touring approximately 6-8 traditional or community based venues but we would like to bring it to inmates for free. We'd like to give points of human contact through art and give prisoners the opportunity to connect with everything Shakespeare has to offer. 

What makes our company special?

We make quality theatre as affordable as possible so that everyone can attend.

We hire young, talented actors & crew members. We make paying them fairly our highest priority. When we lack funds to pay, what we view as a living wage, we offer an equal profit share agreement across the board.

We take on students to work for us, learn from us and they enter into the same payment agreement as anyone else. 

Why we need your help.

We are an independent theatre company. We receive no public/government funding. We need funding to grow, flourish, and continue to achieve our ambitious goals. This campaign is for this specific project but it is a pilot project. If we are successful it will become a financially self-sustaining annual project. 

The money you donate will help us...

  • cover the wage, travel and housing of our actors/crew for the duration of the rehearsal process and subsequent tour
  • allow us to bring this production to juvenile detention centres and female prison systems for free and allow us to provide educational drama workshops at no cost to the institutions or inmates
  • help us create the costumes, set and props we need to bring this bare bones production to life

But hey, if you can’t donate…

We understand! You can still help. Tell your friends, family, and coworkers about our campaign, and direct them to this page. Every donation helps!

And, of course, the most important way you can show your support is to come to a show! Our production will be touring Ontario during the first 2 weeks of June. 

We hope to see you along the way!
story_txt:
Help Us Bring Quality Shakespeare Across Ontario; 
and more importantly, into juvenile detention centres and the female prison system.
The Edge Productions is an independent theatre company that has been operating in Windsor, Ontario for over 7 years. We produce plays hard hitting and deeply empathetic productions in a wide variety of eras. From classical to musical and contemporary - we do it all. 
This season we are trying to bring something to communities less traveled to. We want to bring work into the juvenile detention centres and female prison systems. We believe art is inherently therapeutic, cathartic and inspiring. We believe theatre can bring hope and joy to people who may need it more than most. We believe theatre can change people for the better. 
We are touring an All-Female production of William Shakespeare's Henry V. It sounds cliché and trite to say these plays can help change lives, but they have and will continue to do so for longer than any of us will be around. Shakespeare's works have been wowing audiences for centuries. Literally CENTURIES, and still do today. Shakespeare will always be current and will always be popular.
We are touring approximately 6-8 traditional or community based venues but we would like to bring it to inmates for free. We'd like to give points of human contact through art and give prisoners the opportunity to connect with everything Shakespeare has to offer. 
What makes our company special?
We make quality theatre as affordable as possible so that everyone can attend.
We hire young, talented actors & crew members. We make paying them fairly our highest priority. When we lack funds to pay, what we view as a living wage, we offer an equal profit share agreement across the board.
We take on students to work for us, learn from us and they enter into the same payment agreement as anyone else. 
Why we need your help.
We are an independent theatre company. We receive no public/government funding. We need funding to grow, flourish, and continue to achieve our ambitious goals. This campaign is for this specific project but it is a pilot project. If we are successful it will become a financially self-sustaining annual project. 
The money you donate will help us...

cover the wage, travel and housing of our actors/crew for the duration of the rehearsal process and subsequent tour
allow us to bring this production to juvenile detention centres and female prison systems for free and allow us to provide educational drama workshops at no cost to the institutions or inmates
help us create the costumes, set and props we need to bring this bare bones production to life

But hey, if you can’t donate…
We understand! You can still help. Tell your friends, family, and coworkers about our campaign, and direct them to this page. Every donation helps!
And, of course, the most important way you can show your support is to come to a show! Our production will be touring Ontario during the first 2 weeks of June. 
We hope to see you along the way!

story:
Story

My name is Laris Macario (Producer/Henry V) Henry V has been a dream role of mine for over a decade.  In my artistic life as an actor I’ve always been drawn to stories that stretch my capabilities whilst stirring the latent tempest within the audience.  I can think of no better story for the times we live in today. It’s often easy to get caught up in our own ideologies and stay in the bubbles of our making without considering whether “the other side” is doing the same.  Henry gets caught up in his own legend, as we all do, with gross disregard for the affect his actions have on the land he’s invading. Isn’t that a major part of the human story? To impose our will on others regardless of the consequences because "we are resolute in our righteousness"?  This isn’t just a play about a war hero but a mirror into the battle between the Angels and Demons within us all and on February 19, 2019, you’ll get to find out who wins.

 

The Impact

Be a Knight!  Each $250 donation pays for a night of rehearsals.   We also have a wonderful Fight Coordinator team led by Jared Kirby & Co. not to mention lights, costumes and theater rental. Every little bit helps and the contributions really add up.

Funds raised go towards cast and production team costs, buying set materials and costumes, and marketing.  Any contribution you make is essential to our production and know that you are now part of enhancing the arts and enriching the vibrant Off-Broadway community in NYC.  You are a champion of the stage!

We need $15,000 to be used toward:

> $5,500: balance on the theatre venue + rehearsal space;

> $7,500: artist and tech fees; and

> $2,000: Costumes, Props, Scenic, Combat-Ready Weaponry.

$20 Giving Level: A social media shout out AND a ticketing discount code.

$50 Giving Level: above, plus a concession voucher.

$75 Giving Level: above, plus a cast-autographed copy of Henry V, Arden Publishing -shipped.

$100 Giving Level: above, plus a cast-autographed photo, 8x10 -shipped

$250 Giving Level: above, plus FOUR tickets to the show.

$500 Giving Level: above, plus a cast-signed *BROADSWORD* -shipped.

$1,000 Giving Level: above, plus a Laris Macario signed CROWN -shipped.

 

    Risks & Challenges

    This play hosts a cast of 20 actors plus live action sword fighting and combat.  Say what?!

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot help with funds, you can help draw an audience, spread the word about this campaign, or volunteer!  Use #KingHVmacario.

    Volunteer:  We will need helpers to manage the front of house during the show, and perhaps you have a hidden talent in costume or scenic design you'd like to make us aware of?  We welcome your input!

story:
Why In Four Movements?

This contemporary, site specific adaptation takes Chekhov's celebrated classic and sets it in a failing bar in present day downtown Toronto.  The workers of Chekhov's estate setting are now the bartenders and staff of the bar; the writers and actors the composers and musicians who perform there. 

Playwright and Director Meg Moran and Composer Sally Norris explore the collision of music and theatre while asking the questions that we ask ourselves as young artists: What is an artist’s relationship with their art?  Can an artist ever attain perfection?  Is it possible to separate your life from your work?  How do you measure success?  What is the personal cost of success?  How do you maintain hope amidst failure?  How do you deal with the gap between aspirations and ability?

Why $600?

We are incredibly lucky to have a rehearsal and performance space provided for us, in the form of the Winchester Kitchen and Bar. There are still many other costs associated with producing a play however, and we are a group of completely unfunded, unpaid emerging artists. Your donation will help us put our actors in costume, ensure they are lit, and fund our promotional materials so that we don't have to make any more videos on a digital camera that one of us had in high school.

But I don't have any money...

Neither do we! No donation is too small. If you'd like to help out, but can't do so financially, we would love to have any expertise or in kind donations you have to offer. Video skills? Photography hobby? Crew experience? Own a print shop? Let us know how you can help us! Send us an email to upstart.seagull@gmail.com  

 

Upstart Theatre is proud to present The Seagull In Four Movements. March 14th-16th and 21st-23rd 2013 at the Winchester Kitchen and Bar.

Written and Directed by Meg Moran

Music by Sally Norris

Dramaturgy by Brooklyn Doran

Stage Management by Adriana Dimitri
 
Produced by Meara Tubman-Broeren
 
Featuring:
Zack Amzallag
Aisha Bentham
Stephanie Bitten
Wesley J. Colford
Colin Murphy
Elizabeth Tanner
Enzo Voci

story:
My Story

Hello, my name is Alanna Phillips and I am currently a dancer at LaShelle's School of Dance in Detroit, Michigan. I have been dancing for 7 years and I am now 15 years old. I participate in ballet, tap, pointe, jazz, modern, hip hop and I dance 5 days a week. At the studio, I also teach an advanced tap class on Thursdays. Besides dancing at the studio I am a ninth grader at Renaissance High School and I maintain a 3.5 grade point average. I also am a member of the dance workshop at school. I am very dedicated to dance!

In July, with the help of donations, I will be attending a summer dance intensive in Buffalo, New York. The workshop is sponsored by Dance Masters of America, and is a week long dance intensive known as the S.H.I.P. Program. It is dedicated to advanced training for dancers ages 13 – 18 from all across the country. This experience will help improve my dancing and teaching skills. While in New York I will get a college experience, by staying in dorms at the University of Buffalo and taking multiple classes a day. During the workshop I can take a variety of classes such as: ballet, modern, tap, ballroom, hip hop and many more. It should be very fun and educational too.

By participating in this summer program, I believe it will help me diversify and improve my dancing. Anytime I take classes from different teachers, I realize that I am adding a new style to my dance knowledge and increasing my skills. Only with the help of your donations will I be able to achieve the goal of becoming a better dancer by attending the Dance Masters S.H.I.P. Program. I appreciate anything you can give. 

The total for my tuition, travel and lodging is $980.  So far I have raised $480 through dance studio fundraisers and the help of my friends and family but without the remaining funds, I will not be able to attend this program.  Even the smallest donation will help move me toward my goal. I hope you can help out! Thank you!

story:
Hello. 

We are Laser Dog.  We are everything and nothing.

And we are putting on a show!

Greg McCrary, cartoonist extraordinaire and Caitlin Hafer, choreographer and dance film producer, are teaming up to bring Laser Dog from the thin, 2dimensional pages of his comic book universe into the 3dimensional stage of the our world.  Thus  the concept for LASER DOG LIVE!! was born. 

LASER DOG LIVE!!  will combine film by Greg and animator Rob Carwright, live dance performed by Nicholas Stettenbenz, as well as dance film by Caitlin.  These elements will combine, like the ingredients of an evil master mind’s grand scheme to show the audience the futility of fighting against your own, true identity.

But Laser Dog and his team can’t do it all on their own. They are trying to raise $2000, and they need your help to make LASER DOG LIVE!! (and their plan for world domination) come to fruition. 

How will they spend the money you ask?

Here’s the break down:

$500 --> Dancers’ salary

$400 --> Animator’s salary

$600 --> Travel expenses to unite the team in San Francisco

$100 --> Printing post cards to draw people into their evil web

$150 --> Costuming to protect their secret identities

$100 --> Materials to project the film onto during the show

$150 --> Renting studio space to perfect their tactics for world domination

And what do you get out of this (besides the warm, fuzzy feeling of helping us make this show a reality)?

For a $10 donation you receive a copy of the show poster

For a $20 donation you receive your very own issue of Laser Dog

For a $30 donation you receive a limited edition Laser Dog T-shirt

For a $40 donation you receive your very own DVD copy of the performance

Furthermore, your donation is tax deductable through out Fiscal Sponsor Dancers’ Group! Make checks payable to Dancers’ Group (our fiscal sponsor) with C R Hafer and Dancers in the memo line.  Or you can pay online. 

The most important way you can help is to spread the word about LASER DOG LIVE!!.  Tell everyone you know and come to see the show November 1st and 2nd at The Garage (www.715bryant.org)!!

story:
Meet Simon Labrosse

Team Statement

It’s been a couple of months since we got together in order to stage this great piece of writing that is “7 Days in the Life of Simon Labrosse”, a Canadian contemporary play that speaks volumes about any creative person’s nightmare:  having lots of ideas, lots of dreams and still being penniless.

In our enthusiastic attempt at staging this play, we have reached the point where we go into production. Here is where you nice people enter the picture: since this is a partly self-funded project, the rest of the funds need to be raised by reaching out to you all theatre enthusiasts out there.

From this moment on, every day brings us closer to the opening night, in this small unconventional theatre that has so kindly agreed to host us for the performances. In order to make this happen, we will need props, costumes and equipment, as well as to cover the costs of performing rights for the text. So far we have rehearsed in our own homes, with the support of our closest friends, but we need to take this to the next level.

We believe that if there is will, there is also a way.  Independent, fringe-like theatre is a cause worth fighting for. That’s why we need you support and why, although we have all worked in state-subsidized theatres at one point or another, we largely prefer staging this particular play in an unconventional way and place. At the end of the day, it’s all about being able to fully express ourselves, without any restrictions.

“7 Days in the Life of Simon Labrosse” will be a performance merging fiction and make-believe, a puzzle-like, postmodern approach on the daily life, crises and epiphanies of a self-made man. Who also happens to be in love. Part comedy, part confessional drama, the play gives out an ultimately optimistic message about being the master of our own future. Whatever it may take.

Opening night is scheduled for early May, 2013.

________________________________________________________________________

Cast Overview

 

Vlad Udrescu 

Has a master’s degree in acting. Has played in four of the most important theaters  and on two of the most highly regarded independent stages in Bucharest.

Of the most important plays he had a part in we can count Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night, a Chekhov’s Platonov.

He finished his studies playing Aegisthus in “The Atreus Trilogy”, a performance based on ancient Greek tragedies.

About his character, Simon, Vlad says:

“Simon is a guy who struggles through life and even though things don’t go the way he planned them, he continues to be optimistic and brave. That’s why I find Simon’s part very appealing and very easy to empathize with. It also speaks about working on your own and trying to make a living out of your own ideas. Honestly, if Simon had been an actor, he would have been a very active supporter of the independent theatre movement”. 

 

Iolanda Covaci 

She also has a master’s degree in acting; on top of that she attended an intensive training class in New York at the famous acting school, Lee Strasberg Institute. She currently is a bachelor in Psychology.

As an actress she currently plays with the State Jewish Theater in Bucharest and she had parts in plays based on Strindberg’s or Matei Visniec’s  texts.

What Iolanda has to say about the character she’s playing:

“Nathalie is fascinating because she is like an iceberg:  what you see at the surface hides a much bigger universe, a colorful and conflicting inner world that requires a detective’s work to discover and reconstruct. Also, I love this part because she plays the feminine characters in the life of Simon Labrosse, parts that are very different, therefore challenging my creativity and imagination.”

  

Serban Gomoi

Just like the others, he has a master’s degree in acting and he finished his studies with the part of Malvolio in Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night.

After graduation he started working with four of the most important theaters in Bucharest. He acted in some of the texts of the best writers in the world: Shakespeare, Chekhov, Strindberg, Sam Shepard, and Ilf and Petrov.

Regarding Leo, his character, Serban (a man  of few words and plenty of action) says:

„This is a must do performance, because it’s happening between real friends and colleagues. Also, from an actor’s point of view the part of Leo is one of the hardest I’ve ever tackled. Quite challenging indeed. I think that the part of Leo speaks about the loneliness of the soul..and that’s why he has to be heard”. 

________________________________________________________________________

Where The Funds Go

  • 11 Costumes – 500$
  • Set – 400$
  • Props – 200$
  • Performing Rights – 100$
  • Advertising (posters, flyers etc.) – 200$
  • Discretionary Fund – 100$

We will try to do our best with the funds that we hope to raise. Basically, this is an optimistic budget but it’s the one that we definitely need in order to stage this play in an accurate and true manner.

 

What We Hope For

Through our project, we hope to raise awareness regarding the emerging artists in Romania and support a very important scene in the cultural life of Bucharest, that of independent theatre. Furthermore, we would like to bring forward to the public some new texts and “7 Days in the Life of Simon Labrosse” is exactly the sort of text that we happily recommend.

By contributing to our goal, you become active supporters of good, low-budget, youth-oriented theatre that brings hope for a better cultural future. 

 

Thank You! And please spread the news.

story:
Jolie's Journey

THE TALENT

By one proud dad,

Jolie was born to perform.  She has been blessed with talent and drive beyond her years. As long as I can remember she has attracted the spotlight. From the moment she was born she demanded your attention. Wherever we took her she drew people in as they adored her blond curly hair and those beautiful blue eyes and beaming smile. We knew from the moment that she was born that she was special and that the name Jolie was perfect for her. As time went by we knew that she was meant to be on a stage and to share her gifts with those fortunate to know her. 

Jolie is the complete performer, she is beautiful, intelligent, and can sing, dance, and act. But she is more than just a triple threat because she is more than just the talent she possesses. Her drive, work ethic, and moral standards are her greatest strengths. In a world of social pressures to be a part of the "in crowd” Jolie stands out and denies the influences that would jeopardize her values and her goals in life.

Jolie is just beginning to blossom and as she continues to grow and develop her talents and character there are no limits to what she can achieve. There is no denying her destiny or doubt that she was born to be in the spotlight. She is more than her name implies. 

LVA (Las Vegas Academy of the Performing Arts & International Studies) recognized her talents during her audition for their theater department and her application was accepted. Beginning in the fall Jolie will be attending LVA. We are so excited for her and the opportunity given to her. With a strong foundation and the support of family and friends, her future is bright!

 

THE PASSION

By Jolie Cope,

I began dancing at 4 years old and from the very beginning I loved to perform. From "Boogie Oogie"(with Ms. Lilian) to today dancing on the big stage and competing with my peers, I knew this is what I was born to do. When I'm on stage I get a natural high and it gives me a rush, which drives me to work my butt off and develop my skills to become the best dancer I can be. Dancing pushes me to go the extra mile and it has given me the confidence and the drive to apply my passion in all that I do. But dancing is not my only passion, singing and acting is also a part of who I am. I wake up singing and go to bed singing, I have been fortunate to have opportunities to sing, from the National Anthem at large venues, to singing in school plays, and performing solos at choir concerts, fueling my passion for performing. As for acting I love to become a character and be funny and joke with my friends and family and to hone my craft of becoming a complete performer. I want to progress in these areas everyday. I want to push myself to the limit to become all that I know I can be. My goal is not only to be the best, but also to love what I do. This is my passion! This is what I know I'm meant to do in life. I couldn't survive without these things, they're my oxygen!

THE CHALLENGE

Two years ago Jolie's dance studio was merged into a larger more competitive dance studio and with it came the opportunity for her to be a part of the studio's dance competition team. While I knew Jolie had the talent and the drive to be a part of this great opportunity, I never dreamed that it would all happen so fast. Last year was her first competition and her first solo performance on a big stage, and the rest is history. She placed 1st in her category and 1st overall in the solo performances. That performance awarded her the invitation to New York and the privilege to attend master dance classes with the Rockettes, to see Broadway and all the spectacular sights of New York City, including Radio City Music Hall. Unfortunately, this opportunity comes with a hefty expense, and this is why we are reaching out to our friends and family to help Jolie get to New York and have the chance of a lifetime.

EXPENSES: 

Your contributions will go towards the convention and travel expenses.

ITINERARY: 

Daily master dance classes with Broadway performers/Rockettes/professional choreographers 

Share the Dream

Contribute if you can, and pass this campaign along to anyone you know who can help!

story:
About This Campaign

After ten years in our previous home, a renovated warehouse at Penn Field, we found ourselves paying almost $150,000 a year in rent - and the rent was about to rise even more. We started looking for a place to build a permanent home for Austin Playhouse and found an ideal location at the Mueller Austin redevelopment. (http://www.muelleraustin.com/) 

We have been raising funds for over two years to build a new home at Mueller adjacent to the new Austin Children's Museum. We have made significant progress, raising almost $1 million in individual contributions. The project is now fully permitted and shovel ready. We expect to break ground this summer.

Thanks to a $25,000 matching grant from the Carolyn Rice Bartlett Charitable Foundation, all new building fund donors through June 13, 2013 will have their gifts matched up to our $25,000 goal! We're launching this campaign to reach new donors, especially those in the Austin arts community, who would like to see their impact doubled.

If you have the capacity and would like to donate at a higher level than those listed with this campaign, please contact us directly to hear about naming opportunities: development@austinplayhouse.com.

We welcome multi-year pledges too!

We believe that Austin needs another first-class facility, built by and for artists with a long-term stake in this community. We're asking for your support. Thank you.

As a 501(c)3 nonprofit, all donations are fully tax-deductible!

About Austin Playhouse

Austin Playhouse is a professional theatre company currently producing our 13th season.

Austin Playhouse serves as the artistic home for a core company of 27 artists under the leadership of Don Toner, Producing Artistic Director and Lara Toner, Associate Artistic Director. Our performances range from modern classics like Tom Stoppard's Arcadia, to local and world premieres like Other Desert Cities by Jon Robin Baitz and Dug Up by Cyndi Williams. Our 2013-2014 Season will open with the musical Man of La Mancha.

Our Track Record

Over the past twenty years in Austin, Don Toner and his company have proven more than capable of building theatres. He served as project manager on the downtown State Theatre renovation when he led the State Theatre Company, bringing in the $2.9 million renovation of the historic movie theatre on time and under budget. He transformed a World War I warehouse at Penn Field into a two-theatre venue, and has made a beautiful theatre in a former storefront at Highland Mall.

This time we're doing something different: creating a beautiful, functional NEW facility, built and designed from the start as a first class performance space - one that we'll own forever.

Our new theatre will have two stages, a 225-seat main stage and a 99-seat second stage. Both will be built with sprung floors for dance companies. The second stage will have digital projection capabilities. We'll have a rehearsal hall, classroom space, and an art gallery. We'll also have an Austin Java restaurant, children's theatre, and a rooftop terrace with views of Mueller Lake.

Our facility will be available for rent to other arts organizations and subsidized rent will be available for groups in need. Austin Playhouse at Mueller will be a creative hub for the greater Austin arts community.

What We Need & What You Get

Our original plan included financing up to $2.5 million. However, due to delays in the contracting and permitting process we are now only able to borrow $1.7 million. We have $1 million currently committed to the project and need to raise an additional $1 million during the construction process.

While a new construction project under $4 million is relatively modest, we still need a lot of help to make it happen. And, of course, the sooner the better.

The funds raised from this indiegogo campaign are earmarked for all the soft costs: primarily architecture (the award-winning Scott Ginder from Dick Clark Architecture is helming our project: http://www.dcarch.com/) and engineering (we have an ace team including Zapalac-Reed as project manager and Big Red Dog engineering) that are needed before we can break ground.

Our new theatre is still several months away, but we want to reward campaign contributors right now. With website recognition at every level, curtain speech announcements, an exclusive donor preview, and even shot glasses we're looking for as many ways as possible to THANK YOU for being an essential part of this project. Plus, through this campaign all new donors have their donations matched!

The Impact

Austin Playhouse employs over 100 local actors, designers, and technicians each season. For the past two seasons we've curtailed programming in our temporary venues. Our new home will allow us to return to full operations and then keep going with two stages producing quality theatrical entertainment and twice as many employment opportunities for Austin artists.

In addition, the space will be available to a wide variety of artists for film screenings, dances, concerts, exhibitions, rehearsals, and of course theatrical performances.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the campaign with your friends!

If you are unable to donate you can still help by spreading the word. This is an ambitious online effort and it will only be successful if our supporters share it with their friends.

Please share us on facebook, twitter, and through email. Together we can create a new performing arts facility that will benefit the Austin arts community for generations.

If you have any questions or would like to suggest other ways you can help the campaign, please contact us at info@austinplayhouse.com.

Thank you!

story:
CALLIOPE IS a new theatre company founded in 2011 by Will Dagger, Kate Hamilton, Maria Krovatin, and Drew Lewis. Calliope is dedicated to the production of new work, and aspires to bring a fresh face otthe age-old tradition of storytelling. Through embracing and subverting an ever-growing variety of theatrical forms, genres, and assumptions, we aim to create a place to play that is uniquely our own--one of truth, mystery, and epic exploration.

 
SIX WINDOWS PRESENTS A HERO OF OUR TIME IS a metatheatrical piece we're currently creating. Inspired by a 19th century Russian novel by Mikhail Lermontov, Six Windows follows the members of a young and restless theatre company in New York on the closing night of their latest production, an adaptation of Lermontov's work. Devised through improvisation, the piece captures in real time and rich detail a group of artists searching for meaning in their art and stability in their lives.
 
YOU ARE absolutely vital in making this happen. Putting up a show in New York City isn't easy, and every penny helps. All money donated will go towards paying for rehearsal and performance space, insurance, publicity materials, tech needs, and  compensations for artists involved.
 
If you'd like to get involved artistically, email us at calliopetheatrecompany@gmail.com and let us know how you'd like to contribute.
 
Lastly, make some noise about our cause! Tell all your friends and get the word out on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, whatever the kids are into these days.
 
AS A TOKEN OF OUR APPRECIATION, please enjoy this first installment of MINCE PIES AND LITTLE WHITE LIES, a new radio play by Maria Krovatin! Recording cast includes Lydian Blossom, Will Dagger, Nigel DeFriez, Kate Hamilton, Maria Krovatin, Drew Lewis, Matt Peck, and Kate Armstrong Ross.
 
 
 
 
SIX WINDOWS PRESENTS A HERO OF OUR TIME
July 18-28, 2013 / Medicine Show Theater
 
July 18-19, 23-26 @7:30pm, July 27-28 @7
549 W 52nd St, New York, NY 10019
 
Devised and performed by Ben Becher, Lydian Blossom, Dave Thomas Brown, Matt Crowley, Kate Hamilton, Maria Krovatin, Drew Lewis, Rania Salem Manganaro*, Matt Peck, Kate Armstrong Ross, Rachel Sachnoff, Harrison Unger, Emily Walton*, & Chris Wilson. *Appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity.
 
Written by Will Arbery, directed by Will Dagger, stage managed by Zooey Barry, set designed by Huw Roberts, lighting designed by Michael Cecchini. Inspired by a conversation with Knud Adams & a novel by Mikhail Lermontov. Equity Approved Showcase.

story:
Who We Are

Last August, Less Than Rent Theatre produced its first show at the New York International Fringe Festival. Our production, RICHARD 3, ran five nights at the Ellen Stewart Theatre at La MaMa to sold-out houses, earning numerous rave reviews, listing in NYC Fringe Guide’s Best of Fest, and taking home both Outstanding Director and Outstanding Actor Fringe Excellence Awards. And we couldn’t have done it without the support of our friends and donors.
           
It doesn’t stop there—Less Than Rent has another big summer planned. On June 24th at Theater for the New City, we open our 2011 summer Season with the NYC premiere of THE PRIVATE SECTOR by Yale grad Cory Finley. On July 22nd at The Wild Project, Less than Rent will present LITTLE TOWN BLUES, a 21st Century re-imagining of Chekhov’s THREE SISTERS. We are pulling together designers, casts, and crews, but our big ideas are already assembled—now all we need is support.


Our Shows


THE PRIVATE SECTOR 

By Cory Finley 

Directed by Charlie Polinger 

@Theater for the New City (6/25-7/3)


In the woods of rural Connecticut, Anticline Capital, the fastest-growing hedge fund in America, is holding its annual new-hires retreat. Four of the nation's best and brightest are being groomed to work--and live--the Anticline way: with total focus, radical honesty, and hearts cleansed of the sort of emotions that might slow them down--jealousy, resentment, fear, anger, tenderness. But between tent-pitching escapades and campfire dinners, those emotions prove harder to eliminate than expected. Illicit affairs linger, feelings are trampled upon, and rocks are sharpened in the dark. And Will Merritt, an English major from Princeton suddenly in way over his head, is faced with a choice between the woman he never should have fallen for and the job he never should have taken. THE PRIVATE SECTOR is a bleak comedy about growing up in a baffling age, of egos and minds falling apart deep in the woods.


LITTLE TOWN BLUES 

A modern riff on Chekhov’s Three Sisters

By James Presson and Rachel Buethe 

Directed by James Presson 

@The Wild Project (7/23-8/7)


A turbo-charged tragicomedy with a satirical edge, LITTLE TOWN BLUES takes a hard look at what it means to be a young American in the 21st century. Drawing from influences as wide-ranging and varied as Anton Chekhov, John Updike, and Aaron Sorkin, the play delves into the emotional complexities of young love, intense friendship, and the end of adolescence, while never putting aside the absurdity of living in a world governed by iPhones, laptops, and text messaging. Navigating through delight and devastation, the boarding students of Deforest-Martin Prep rage against the machine of structured academia with the fire of a teenage rebel and the depth of a Russian poet.


We Need Your Help!

We’ve got a big season ahead of us. From the headquarters of a high-powered hedge fund to a dorm room in Iowa, from camping gear to boarding school uniforms, and from building campfires to sparking the embers of young love, we have many worlds to create. Your donation would go directly towards bringing these worlds to life right here in New York. On top of that, your donation would help support Less Than Rent Theatre as a company as we enter our most ambitious season yet.  In our most crucial moment of development, you can be a part of building this fresh new voice in New York theatre.


Keep Connected!

Technology plays a major role in both shows in our season, so we’re embracing social media! Check out our website, www.lessthanrent.org, where you can keep updated on all our latest news, join our mailing list, learn about our company, and link to the websites and blogs for THE PRIVATE SECTOR and LITTLE TOWN BLUES. Check us out on Facebook at “LessThanRent,” and follow us on Twitter at twitter.com/LessThanRent. Most importantly, share Less Than Rent’s exciting summer season with all your friends! Don't forget, Less Than Rent is a 501(c)3 so your donation is tax-deductible!

story:
Our Story

We met over six years ago at the BMI Musical Theatre Workshop, where we were paired as collaborators for one of the class assignments.  It was immediately clear that we had similar instincts and a great rapport.  Since then, we've developed a fruitful writing partnership, performed together in a number of venues and continue to expand our collaboration in various directions.



Why What We Do Is Important

We believe in our work and know it can be both commercially successful and relevant.  Our first musical, Falling to Earth, is an entertaining and moving story about people struggling to maintain identity as they are changed by relationships.  Sisco’s light-hearted comedies BAIT n’ SWISH, which we perform together, warn us about the dangers of speed dating in the funniest way possible, and analyze what happens when relationships get “comfortable.”  


We understand that it’s not just about developing our own work, but inspiring future artists.  In addition to our writing and performing, we’re now teaching seminars on the art of collaboration and coaching students on how to become singing actors.   


And this is just the beginning.  We have a long list of projects we’re just waiting to dive into once we have the resources to make them happen.  


This fundraising campaign isn’t simply about asking for financial support.  It’s about the tools we need to get our work out into the world.  We know we can make an impact once we do.



What We Need

We hope to raise $8,000 to help us defray costs associated with running our business, including:


    • Hiring a professional to revamp our website to include multimedia, interviews and online sales of our songs.
    • Providing funds to cover the expense of negotiating the stage rights for a new musical. 
    • Designing marketing tools, such as joint head shots, business cards and letterhead.
    • Developing a nest egg for upcoming demo recordings and artists fees

Those of you who know us have shown genuine interest in our work and encouraged us to keep at it, especially when we didn’t know where it would take us.  With your generous gifts, you can help us help others discover Gualtieri & Sisco.


What You Get 

You’ll get the satisfaction of knowing you are supporting a promising writing team.  You’ll get a tax deduction (who doesn’t want that?).  And, if you donate $100 or more, you’ll get a CD of our work as a thank you.

All who donate will receive a newsletter with updates on all our projects.


Other Ways You Can Help

DIWO (Do It With Others)!!  In addition to making a tax-deductible donation,  tell your friends about our fundraising campaign and invite them to give.  You’ll not only be helping us meet our financial goal, you’ll be introducing other people to our work.

story:
I’m Barbara Bragg, Los Angeles actress and writer, graduate of the Yale School of Drama, and fifth generation Wyoming native, whose dad and grand-dad were both award-winning Western writers. 

My new play, TALES OF THE OLD WEST, based on my father’s award winning short stories will premiere at the Autry Museum for Western History in Los Angeles in April 2013. 

TO PURCHASE TICKETS:

http://theautry.org/programs/performing-arts/ba...

Set in Wyoming Territory, these stories faithfully portray the adventures and predicaments that Anglo, Native American and African American men and women faced following the Civil War.  My family is enormously proud of my dad’s stories and we wanted to find a way to share them with a new generation. 

Starting with dinner at 6:30 each night,  a pre-show concert of period music at 7:00pm and a performance at 7:30 pm,  audiences will travel with the company through the Western Migration galleries and experience the stories in a manner reminiscent of tales told around a campfire, just the way my dad told them to me!

Bringing TALES to the Autry has been a labor of love and I hope you can help us support the amazing talent we’re assembling to bring the stories to life.

Your tax deductible donation will be directed to our project through Pasadena Arts Council’s EMERGE fiscal sponsor program.

Your contribution will help match the support the Autry has already pledged to help pay our creative ensemble of 14.  

Thanks for your help to make TALES OF THE OLD WEST come to life.

Tales of the Old West is a project of the Pasadena Arts Council’s EMERGE fiscal sponsorship program. Follow this link to find out more. 

http://www.pasadenaartscouncil.org/emerge/tales...

Additional support has generously been given by Bill and Rita Bragg (memoriam),  Bob, Tere, Billy and Buddy Bragg, Laura and Tom Gaddis,Sen. Alan K. Simpson (Ret) and Family,Boyden Road Productions, Catherine Chapin, Deborah S. Stewart ( inRalph Schauss's name), Dee Lewis, Donato D’Alibris, Gantt Photography, Howard Meiseles, Judith Moses, Linda Besesti, Roberta Mespelt, Miles Crowell, Mark Travis, Robin Siegel, Larry Kay, Sierra Pecheur,Linda Besesti and many others.

Tales of the Old West was initially developed at Yale Cabaret Hollywood [Walt Klappert, Producer] and California Polytechnic Pomona’s Theatre Department.

 “The Ghost of Fort Laramie”, “Red Revenge” and “The Ten Sleep Mail” by Bill Bragg Jr. are used with permission of Big Teepee Productions.

story:
First, a bit about Springboard: 

 
Founded in 2001 by Alexandra Wells (Artistic Director) and Susan Alexander (Executive Director), Springboard Danse Montréal is a non-for-profit contemporary dance organization that connects mature, experienced, professional dancers and emerging choreographers with some of today's leading international and Montreal-based and dance companies (referred to as "Principal Companies"). 
 
Now in its 14th year, Springboard actively contributes to the Montreal cultural community through public installations and outreach programs. 
 
Springboard Danse Montreal is thrilled to announce our first collaboration with Place des Arts this summer. On June 18, this year's Springboard Emerging Choreographers will be showcased in a public event at l’Espace culturel Georges-Émile-Lapalme. This is an exciting opportunity for these artists to present their work in Place des Arts, one of North America's most prestigious arts venues.

Now, about the Emerging! Springboard installation by former Emerging Choreographer Danielle Russo

Springboard is committed to facilitating and showcasing the work of today's up-and-coming choreographers. Each year we offer the following unique opportunities for 7 selected artists:
 
  • Access to high-calibre dancers
  • A generous amount of studio space for exploration and creation
  • The option of one of the following: 
    - A 20-minute indoor installation 
    - An outdoor installation of varying length  
    - A 6-minute work for the stage
  • The opportunity to be on the same bill as the Principal Companies 
Every year, the process culminates in a showing of works-in-progress at Usine C, Montréal's venue for avant garde dance and theatre. This showing is attended by company directors, presenters, agents, and potential producers of work. Additionally, Springboard provides each Emerging Choreographer with mentoring opportunities and the opportunity to develop a peer network of professional artists. Former mentors include Margie Gillis, Paula de Vasconcelos and Steven Cook. 


"Emin" by 2015 Emerging Choreographer Banning Bouldin, and Ana Maria Lucaciu
Photo: Eden Frangipane

Who will you be "adopting”? 

The 2015 Emerging Choreographers are: 
  • Banning Bouldin, New Dialect (USA, Nashville)
  • Brendan Duggan and Mallory Lynn, LoudHoundMovement (USA, New York)
  • Hanna Kiel, Human Body Expression (Canada, Toronto)
  • Heather Myers, Independent Choreographer (Canada, Vancouver) 
  • Evangelos Poulinas, Eleftheri Ptosi (Greece)
  • Colleen Snell, Frog in Hand (Canada, Toronto)
  • Yin Yue, Yin Yue Dance Company (China/USA) 

"Project L" by 2015 Emerging Choreographer Hanna Kiel
Photo: Johnny Vong


So, what are we asking for? 

Our goal is $8,000. 

Past Emerging Choreographers have taken residence for three weeks of creative research and composition without financial support. Our goal is to create an appropriate stipend to assist with accrued living and professional expenses. 

How will the money be divided?
$8000 goal:
$320 = 4% Indiegogo fee
$400 = 5% Credit card and PayPal fees
$5600 = Emerging Choreographer stipends: $800 will be given to each of our 7 Emerging Choreographers to help pay for their travels and expenses accrued during the project
$1680 = The creation of an infrastructure that will be developed to sustain Emerging Choreographers in future years


"Hereafter" by 2015 Emerging Choreographer Heather Myers
Photo: Robert Benschop

Why is the Emerging Project important? 

For the Emerging Choreographers, Springboard provides: 
  • A unique, collaborative environment, in which they receive feedback from dancers, peers, and mentors 
  • A platform for their work to seen by 500+ people, including over 100 professional dancers, producers, company directors, presenters, agents, and potential producers of work
  • The opportunity to work with highest-calibre artists
  • The development of an international network, broadening their access to potential commissions, residencies, tours and festivals
  • The creation of a future job market  for dancers: every year, Springboard dancers find employment with Springboard's Emerging Choreographers and their companies


"Nightfall" by 2015 Emerging Choreographer Yin Yue
Photo: Steven Schreiber

Springboard has directly connected more than 150 participants to contracts with renowned international companies including:
  • Aszure Barton & Artists (US, CAN)
  • Ballet Theater Munich (Germany)
  • Cirque du Soleil (CAN)
  • Compagnie Marie Chouinard (CAN)
  • The Forsythe Company (GER)
  • GöteborgsOperans Danskompani (Sweden)
  • Les Grands Ballets Canadiens (CAN) 
For the complete list, click here.

The Emerging Choreographer Project has helped launch the professional careers of many young choreographers, including: 
  • Zoe Scofield, founder of Zoe | Juniper (US)
    - Named a 2015 Guggenheim Fellow for choreography
  • Kyle Abraham, founder of Abraham.In.Motion (US)
    - Named Dance Magazine's Man of the Moment
    - Winner of the 2013 McArthur Foundation Grant 
  • Sidra Bell, founder of Sidra Bell Dance New York (US)
  • Austin McCormick, founder of Company XIV (US)
  • Mélanie Demers, founder of Mayday Danse (CAN)

How will your donation help?

Springboard strives to make it realistic for Emerging Choreographers to attend the project, no matter their means. Your gift will make this possible.

Your donation will help reimburse the Emerging Choreographers for travel, food and housing during their residency in Montréal.

A small portion of all funds raised will support our infrastructure that focuses on grant writing and fundraising. This will make Springboard an organization that can provide its Emerging Choreographers with stipends.

If we do not attain our entire goal, we will divide the funds equally amongst our 7 Emerging Choreographers to provide them with the most assistance possible, while retaining a portion of the funds for the infrastructure.


Each of the 2015 choreographers will be investing an
enormous sum of money to be with us this year.

Your fiscal support makes a difference!


 Establishing oneself as an artist in any field, requires perseverance, financial sacrifice and endurance. Our goal is to ease the financial stress/burden of these artists along this extremely arduous road towards becoming an established choreographer. 
"two solitudes" by 2015 Emerging Choreographer Colleen Snell (Frog in Hand)
Photo: Brian Huynh

Here's what some people have said about the project :

“[Springboard creates] incredible artistic relationships that have informed and evolved my work as a choreographer and director.”
-Sidra Bell, previous Emerging Choreographer
 "My time at Springboard laid a groundwork of professional connections which have had a strong effect on my career. "
-Dorian Nuskind-Oder, previous Emerging Choreographer 
“An amazing resource for companies and choreographers to have access to high caliber dancers who are looking for work.” 
-Austin McCormick, previous Emerging Choreographer 
“It was just three weeks, but you don't leave Montréal empty-handed.” 
-Brian McNeil, alumni
" An ecosystem in which international artists working in the dance medium can connect, collaborate, coexist, and create new language. "
-Sidra Bell, previous Emerging Choreographer

For additional information on our Emerging Choreographer Project, please visit www.springboarddansemontreal.com/emerging-choreographers/

 PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD! 

 Every bit counts. Kindly share with your friends and families, and with struggling artists to share with theirs.

story:
Note: Waltzing is now available on Amazon, iTunes, and Kobo. Thanks for your support!

 

The waltz never quite goes out of fashion;
it is always just around the corner;
every now and then it returns with a bang...
It is sneaking, insidious, disarming, lovely...
The waltz, in fact, is magnificently improper.
                                      - H. L. Menken

 

Get ready, because waltz is about to return with a bang, in...

Waltzing: A Manual for Dancing and Living

A Book by Richard Powers & Nick Enge

 

What Is It?

Stanford social dance instructor Richard Powers has teamed up with Stanford social dance innovator Nick Enge to write a unique book on waltzing, combining instruction in the arts of dancing and living.

A Manual for Dancing

In Waltzing, you will learn the basic steps and the most popular variations of many different kinds of waltzing, vintage and new.

Here is a taste of the waltzes you'll learn:

  • Cross-Step Waltz (the newest and most innovative waltz)
  • Box Step Waltz (the classic American slow waltz)
  • Rotary Waltz (the fast, right-turning Viennese waltz)
  • Reverse Waltz (the fast, left turning Viennese waltz)
  • Redowa, Mazurka, and More!
  • Hambo (a dance in 3/4 that turns twice as fast as a regular waltz)
  • Waltz Sequence Dances and Mixers
  • How to Adapt Other Dances to 3/4 Time (Swing, Salsa, Tango, and more!)
  • How to Adapt Waltzes to 4/4 Time

As a BONUS, in addition to these waltzes in 3/4 time, you’ll also learn dances that turn and travel in other time signatures:

  • Polka (4/4 time)
  • Schottische (4/4 time)
  • Five-Step Waltz (5/4 time)
  • Seven-Step Waltz (7/4 time)
  • Zwiefacher (Unique Combinations of 2/4 and 3/4)

You’ll also get our tips for social dancing in general, including thoughts on:

  • The Three Worlds of Ballroom Dancing (Social, Competetive, and Exhibition)
  • Tips for Leading and Following
  • Tips for Developing Musicality
  • Notes on Style in Social Dancing

Whether you’ve never waltzed, or you’ve been dancing for decades, there’s something here for everyone.

And that's only half of it.

A Manual for Living

In addition to learning the how of waltzing, you'll also learn the why of waltzing.

You'll read about the philosophy and psychology of social dancing, and the many benefits that waltzing has in store for you, your partners, and the world at large.

Here are just a few of the topics we cover:

  • The Benefits of Music
  • The Benefits of Physical Activity
  • The Benefits of Touch
  • The Benefits of Social Relationships
  • The Benefits of Social Spaces
  • The Benefits of Trust
  • The Benefits of Play
  • The Benefits of Conditional Learning
  • The Benefits of Mindfulness
  • The Benefits of Acceptance
  • The Benefits of Smiling
  • The Benefits of Laughing
  • The Benefits of Giving
  • The Benefits of Gratitude
  • and much, much more!

Even if you've never considered waltzing, these topics alone are worth the cover price.

And who knows, maybe you'll be inspired to try waltzing!

Why Fund Us?

To be completely honest, the book is already funded.

Waltzing: A Manual for Dancing and Living is coming to dance floors and bookshelves soon, no matter how much we raise in this campaign.

The real reason we're on IndieGoGo is not to raise additional money, but to give you an opportunity to buy the book early and get your hands on it as soon as it's printed (before it's available to the general public).

It also gives us the chance to offer some extras, which we will be adding as the campaign progresses.

Other Ways You Can Help

Given that we're publishing the book ourselves, we're relying primarily on word of mouth to sell it.

That's where you can have the greatest impact, an impact for which you will forever have our gratitude (the benefits of which you'll learn about in the book).

Please help us share the joy of waltzing by telling all of your friends about the book!

We're on every major social network we know of:

  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow us on Twitter
  • Follow us on Google Plus
  • Follow us on Pinterest

You can also share this page directly on Facebook, Twitter, and Google Plus using the sharing tools at the top of the page.

Please make some noise about the book in your networks, and encourage your friends to do the same!

Thanks for all of your contributions - we can't wait to share the book with you!

Sincerely,

Richard and Nick

Seven-Step Waltz (7/4 time)
Zwiefacher (Unique Combinations of 2/4 and 3/4)
You’ll also get our tips for social dancing in general, including thoughts on:

The Three Worlds of Ballroom Dancing (Social, Competetive, and Exhibition)
Tips for Leading and Following
Tips for Developing Musicality
Notes on Style in Social Dancing
Whether you’ve never waltzed, or you’ve been dancing for decades, there’s something here for everyone.
And that's only half of it.
A Manual for Living
In addition to learning the how of waltzing, you'll also learn the why of waltzing.
You'll read about the philosophy and psychology of social dancing, and the many benefits that waltzing has in store for you, your partners, and the world at large.
Here are just a few of the topics we cover:

The Benefits of Music
The Benefits of Physical Activity
The Benefits of Touch
The Benefits of Social Relationships
The Benefits of Social Spaces
The Benefits of Trust
The Benefits of Play
The Benefits of Conditional Learning
The Benefits of Mindfulness
The Benefits of Acceptance
The Benefits of Smiling
The Benefits of Laughing
The Benefits of Giving
The Benefits of Gratitude
and much, much more!
Even if you've never considered waltzing, these topics alone are worth the cover price.
And who knows, maybe you'll be inspired to try waltzing!
Why Fund Us?
To be completely honest, the book is already funded.
Waltzing: A Manual for Dancing and Living is coming to dance floors and bookshelves soon, no matter how much we raise in this campaign.
The real reason we're on IndieGoGo is not to raise additional money, but to give you an opportunity to buy the book early and get your hands on it as soon as it's printed (before it's available to the general public).
It also gives us the chance to offer some extras, which we will be adding as the campaign progresses.
Other Ways You Can Help
Given that we're publishing the book ourselves, we're relying primarily on word of mouth to sell it.
That's where you can have the greatest impact, an impact for which you will forever have our gratitude (the benefits of which you'll learn about in the book).
Please help us share the joy of waltzing by telling all of your friends about the book!
We're on every major social network we know of:

Like us on Facebook
Follow us on Twitter
Follow us on Google Plus
Follow us on Pinterest
You can also share this page directly on Facebook, Twitter, and Google Plus using the sharing tools at the top of the page.
Please make some noise about the book in your networks, and encourage your friends to do the same!
Thanks for all of your contributions - we can't wait to share the book with you!
Sincerely,
Richard and Nick

story:
The Praxis Stage Company’s Production of Arthur Miller's INCIDENT AT VICHEY.

INCIDENT AT VICHY opens on Thursday, January 19.

This is our performance schedule:
Thursday, January 19. 8pm
Friday, January 20, 8pm .
Saturday, January 21-- two show day, 4pm & 8pm
Sunday, January 22, 2pm matinee
Wednesday, January 25, 8pm
Thursday, January 26, 8pm

-- Plans for Muslim Registries, and a hateful rhetoric that blasphemes a world religion framed by a “clash of civilizations” world-view. 
-- Visions of mass deportations, stoked by raucous choruses of immigrant-bashing, all engendering a wall-building sense of retribution.
-- The demonizing of the “Inner Cities” as lost spaces that demand tough “Law and Order” solutions, bringing forth calls for Stop and Frisk racial-profiling as a national law enforcement policy. 
-- Increased casual diminishing of the rights and liberties of LGBTQ people and normalizing talk of “Conversion Therapy” as social policy. 
-- A longing for torture as a tool of foreign policy.

Trump’s “Great America,” it seems is forged with a vision that seeks to control, deport, and destroy what it perceives as The Other. And the alarmingly marked post-election spike in hate crimes gives evidence that far too many of his supporters understand this and are eager to help him get started.

Into this climate the Praxis Stage Company presents Arthur Miller’s INCIDENT AT VICHY (1964) which takes place in a holding room in Nazi occupied France where several detained men wait in fear and dread to be interviewed.

We are excited to get this particular play up on Inaugural Week of 2017, because it addresses issues that are of great concern to rational people who have really been listening to Trump for the last year, and are fearful of the portents of fascism he and his movement embody.

Praxis Stage's vision is to link theater with activism. We produce plays that enter contemporary political crisis points and ongoing cultural conversations.

Our ambition is to present plays to incite dialogue to foment change. 

The Cast of INCIDENT AT VICHY 
(in the order in which they speak/appear)

Nathan Johnson (Lebeau)
Danny Mourino (Bayard)
Daniel Boudreau (Marchand)
Owen Burke (Detective)
Alexander Castillo-Nuñez (Monceau)
Alex Aroyan (Gypsy)
Hatem Adell (Waiter)
Lang Haynes (Boy) 
Tim Hoover (The Major)
Evan Turissini (Guard)
Floyd Richardson (Old Jew) 
Jake Athyal (Leduc)
Alexander Stravinski (Police Captain)
Steve Auger (Von Berg) 
David J Anderson (Professor Hoffman)
David Policar (Ferrand)

story:
Hi!

This is a campaign to raise funds so that I can get a Theatrical Publicist for my upcoming shows in 2013 because a THEATRICAL PUBLICIST can get REVIEWS which will lead me to get INVESTORS for BROADWAY.  I'd like to invite you to become a part of my DREAM. But first..let me tell you who I am.. 

My name is Qurrat and in 2008, I decided to write a one woman show.  There was only one problem...I'm an actress...I wasn't a writer.  But I was, and am still, a lover of theatre.  I love plays.  I've gone to see so many plays on Broadway, Off-Broadway and off-off Broadway.  I also realized that I am in love with the form of the SOLO PLAY.  There's something so wondefully honest about one person standing before you and revealing themselves. And my ultimate goal is to be on BROADWAY! So one night, I started free writing on what I knew best: MY LIFE. I think, now, I can definitely say, I'm a writer!

The result is a 60 minute one-woman play with 13 characters!  These characters are all based on people in my life, who either said or did something important or made me FEEL a certain way. I explored these moments by developing rich characters with monologues that delve deeper into their connection in my life.  And I learned that I am a writer because I have a story to tell.  When a story speaks from the heart -that is true theatre; with the ability to change the way you see others, the world, and most importantly, yourself.  My life has had its ups and downs: I was bullied, I dealt with death, I lost love.  But I have also been surrounded by wonderful family and friends.  This is the message of the piece: Through adversity, you can rise above and achieve anything!  I address the issues of family and cultural pressure, assimilation and acculturation, all within the context of becoming comfortable in your skin - and these themes are universal,   And I try to be funny as much as I can! 

 

More press/audience reviews at www.qkadwani.com/TheyCallMeQ

Bronxnet TV Interview http://youtu.be/x0QWvxz6Sb4

Urban Milan Review http://www.urbanmilan.com/they_call_me_q.html

They Call Me Q! - PERFORMANCES

Sept 2012: Debuted at The Chicago Theatre Festival to amazing audience reception. 

Nov 2012: Variations Theatre Group: Harvest Theatre Festival- Best Actress Award

Jan 10, 2013: The Inspired Word Special Event, NYC

Feb 1-3 2013: Maui Fringe Festival - Best Play Award

May 15-18, 2013: Orlando Fringe Festival

June 20-23, 2013: Festival St. Ambroise Fringe de Montreal 

July 18-21, 2013: Capital Fringe in Washington DC 

I am also in the process of applying to other festivals around the country and world for 2013:

All for One Festival in NYC

soloNOVA Arts Festival in NYC

NYC Fringe Festival

Los Angeles Womens Theatre Festival

Kansas City Fringe Festival

Vancouver Fringe Festival

Philadelphia Fringe Festival

Amsterdam Fringe Festival

New Orleans Fringe Festival

That's alot right?  The universe is telling me the time is NOW! That's why I'd like to invite you to BECOME A PART OF MY DREAM!  By contributing to my campaign, you will be helping with PUBLICITY costs.  You will be, in essence, publicizing my play and what it represents.  With the funds raised, I will be able to get a top publicist who will be able to market my show with various press outlets in every city I perform and bring audiences out to support.  If you've already seen my show, you know how important this is! 

What I Need & What You Get

I am trying to raise $10,000 because that will cover part of my Publicist costs.  I will have a ton of other costs relating to travel, lodging, festival fees...but this money raised will help me focus on the Performance aspects. You get perks too.  Besides being amazing, you can see what you receive with each level of contribution. Oh, you get a tax deduction too because all donations are going through my non-profit org eyeBLINK. (www.eyeblink.org)

Why do I need a publicist?  Because they have connections!  A great publicist will get press to come out to shows to review it, set up interviews and appearances...and most importantly, get the word out so that hopefully, a producing company or, rich, connected, people will help me to get to Broadway!

I hope to reach the entire goal but any amount that is raised will be used in obtaining a great theatre publicist with connections! 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help even without contributing financially.  Please share this on Facebook, Twitter, through email. 

AUDIENCE REVIEWS:

Alot of her themes are universal - growing up, not being accepted, making a name for yourself, trying to come out from your parents. Qurrat is so talented - whatever she feels on stage, you'll feel in the audience, I know I felt it. I at no time lost interest, I never faded, not for one second. She kept the storyline so smooth, it was seamless. Just an outstanding performance! -Michael Geffner, NYC Producer of The Inspired Word

Cultural differences. Racism. Bullies. Family. Identity. Religion. Self love and hate. So much to respond to...your voice needs to be heard...and I am glad it's happening, especially in this country right now. - Jen DiOrio, NYC at The Inspired Word

I think it was really impressive that she was able to amalgamate all these different characters. There's so much that's unspoken, that we're not allowed to tell anyone; there's no place to tell people we were bullied and I think its important to have figures like Qurrat to say it.- Vandana Nagaraj, NYC at The Inspired Word

I was displaced from my Panamanian community in the Bronx. It felt as if everyone connected with something in your play and I wanted to see more. - David Rey Martinez, NYC at The Inspired Word

I'm a repeat audience member and I loved it just as much as the first time. Her journey is astonishing and I love her courage! - Kathryn Brown, NYC at The Inspired Word

I loved your show—you deliver such a brilliant performance. I'm so glad that my friend suggested it to me! I'll tell all of my friends about you! Keep up the great work and talent. - Sean Mallory, NYC at The Inspired Word

It was more than just a play, it was a reality. I brought all my friends with me, we can share it together, we can discuss it, we can relate and it's great to know that we're not alone. It was phenomenal! - Arti Vaidya, NYC at The Inspired Word

I'm not an Indian woman but I love a story about being fresh out of water and someone persevering. Everyone has had that moment. I felt it. Everyone felt it. - Frank Annor, NYC at The Inspired Word

I thought her impersonation of herself as a 13 year old talking to her mom was spot on. It reminded me of myself at that age wanting to have another culture, with another identity that is more comfortable and accessible. - Anish Ayyappan, NYC at The Inspired Word

I loved the story about her parents, because I think anyone with immigrant parents can relate to that. I felt that she was speaking about my grandmother, my grandfather. - Lily Wrynn, NYC at The Inspired Word

Wow, just wow, show was awesome!!! Well done on all accounts! I feel like this could really take off! - Ruth Katz, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

The show is fantastic. Qurrat is a powerhouse.  Everyone has to go! - Heather Hume, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

Amazing show!!!! For those of you who haven't been, you're missing out!!! - Elizabeth Juenger, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

Great show! Was entertaining and fun to watch from start to end!!! - Russ Horowitz, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

I really loved it.  It is such a wonderful story. One that everyone can relate to - which is what makes it so special. I especially loved the way you drastically transitioned from character to character, and we could all tell so easily who it was that was coming onto the stage. AMAZING! - Marisa Uranovsky, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

Knowing you personally made your performance all the better, but even if we were perfect strangers, I would have thought you were completely endearing and inspiring.  Congratulations on such an amazing show. - Jamie Hanson, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

The show is PHENOMENAL! - Annie Burns, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

Great performance, I didn't want it to be over! - Erin Sloan, NYC at VTG Harvest Festival

Fantastic show! Great storytelling, depth of characters, humor and honesty. Thanks so much for the invitation and bringing the show to Chicago. (ps. my 13 yr old son enjoyed it as well!) – Tracy Fletcher, Chicago Fringe Festival

You were WONDERFUL!!! YOU'RE VERY TALENTED!! Loved the show!! – Ruby Yo, Chicago Fringe Festival

Off the chain – Kenneth Wright, Chicago Fringe Festival

I really enjoyed your show.  You're dope!!! – Joe Kollege, Chicago Fringe Festival

GREAT SHOW!!!  Loved knowing there was someone else out there with brown girl problems!!! Thought provoking and fun, I suggest all my brown queens watch this show. – Asha Mathew, Chicago Fringe Festival

The show was fantastic. I am so glad I spent the time and money to see it! Great job! – Schae Lewis, Chicago Fringe Festival

What a great performance! – Shah Riaz, Chicago Fringe Festival
