story:
The Search For Signs Of Intelligent Life In The Universe
A play by Jane Wagner
Starring Jonelle Meyer
Directed by Christopher Rutherford.

December 1-18
at The Gorilla Theatre in Tampa, FL 


THANK YOU to everyone who donated to this campaign! Your generosity has been a powerful gesture that is helping to fuel our work. In the next few days we will be throwing on our last coats of paint, plugging our lighting and sound cues into the performance and conjuring those last minute magic details that make for a fun and inspired theatrical experience.

Feel free to check this page in the future, as we will be posting pictures and updates about the production. We have already gotten an offer to take the show on the road! Though we must still iron out the details...


If you still feel like contributing:

We will be collecting non-perishable food items for Metropolitan Ministries throughout the run of the show.

But for a list of their urgent needs please refer to their website. (http://www.metromin.org) Toothbrushes and Toothpaste, deodorant, razors, diapers, in addition to food these are the things that are so desperately lacking  for families in need  this holiday season. Keep the giving going! After all, the Quantum Inseparability Principle is in effect, wherein every particle affects every other particle everywhere!

And of course the best way you can directly support us is by purchasing a ticket from www.gorillatheatre.com and then tell or text or twitter your friends and family about the show! Without an audience there would be very little point!

Thank you all for your support! We'll see you at the Theater!

Jonelle Meyer & Christopher Rutherford

story:
"It's a strange,dark, passionately drawn story and my staff and I found it morbidly fascinating. I particularly admire your ability to draw us into Jeremy's and Austin's strange attraction, despite the obvious ickiness of their meet-cute and the darkness that surrounds the relationship. The characters feel decidedly real."- Adam Greenfield of Playwright's Horizons


"Moving beyond the comfort zone and honestly exploring darker elements of humanity, Waking Up is a testament to believing in the possibility of hope even in the face of desperation. Undoubtedly this play will speak on an intimate level to scores of people and it would be no surprise to me to hear people talk of how the show actually saved them from themselves. The staged readings alone have stirred discussion, arguments, introspection and ultimately great praise, it will be thrilling to see what happens when this insightful piece is brought to the full production it more than deserves." - Nic Arnzen (Director Corpus Christi, I Am Love, Some Men)

ABOUT THE SHOW

Jeremy (Jason Heymann) is having a mid-life crisis.  He’s 27.   While attending his Uncle’s wake, he  meets Austin (Brionne Davis),  a fellow mourner.  Jeremy is instantly drawn in by this handsome stranger's mysterious charm. They connect immediately, and as their conversation progresses, Jeremy discovers an uncomfortable truth:  Austin is a “wake-hopper”. 

Lukas, Jeremy’s roommate, has a wonderful and loving relationship with his partner, Frankie.  Unfortunately,  Frankie has been in a permanent vegetative state for the last two years.

Kathy, Frankie’s sister, is living the American dream:  She has a "great" career, a big house in the suburbs with a nice lawn and a white picket fence, two beautiful children and a husband…with whom she doesn't have sex with.  Like her brother, Kathy is realizing that her marriage is in a permanent vegetative state.

WAKING UP is a commentary on the similarities between grief and love and the consequences of what happens when those lines are blurred.

Click the red for: An Interview with playwright Augusto Federico Amador

Original soundtrack by Michelle Amador and Dan Holguin

Your donation is tax deductible, yes... tax deductible! You're contribution will be toward the lauded Celebration Theatre in Los Angeles, a 501c3 organization. The Celebration Theatre is happy to be the fiscal sponsor of Waking Up Productions  and supports the full production of the new staged play, WAKING UP, by Augusto Federico Amador. 

The play has gone through considerable rewrites and a journey across the country to find itself a home with THE IMAGINED LIFE THEATRE which has been generously donated for a six week run by esteemed acting teachers Diana Castle and Steve Tiesort.  WAKING UP showcases our basic human need to love, and validates a world in which we are all connected. The production team and cast believe that this is the appropriate time for such a story.

So whether you are an arts patron or are simply looking for a tax write-off or hopefully both!  Rest assured that your generous donation is tax deductible! And will be supporting a fresh and universal story that can, through your support and donation, be experienced by large theater going audiences. Your contribution will go towards costs such as the set design, lighting design, publicity and all other necessities that will make this production unforgettable and inspired!

 WHERE: The Imagined Life Theatre:

5615 San Vicente Blvd. (at Hauser)

Los Angeles, CA 90019

Staged Reading: November 5th 2011

Full Show Production:  January 2012

Dates for receptions and parties will be confirmed soon

                                     Brionne Davis as Austin         Jason Heymann as Jeremy
story_txt:
"It's a strange,dark, passionately drawn story and my staff and I found it morbidly fascinating. I particularly admire your ability to draw us into Jeremy's and Austin's strange attraction, despite the obvious ickiness of their meet-cute and the darkness that surrounds the relationship. The characters feel decidedly real."- Adam Greenfield of Playwright's Horizons


"Moving beyond the comfort zone and honestly exploring darker elements of humanity, Waking Up is a testament to believing in the possibility of hope even in the face of desperation. Undoubtedly this play will speak on an intimate level to scores of people and it would be no surprise to me to hear people talk of how the show actually saved them from themselves. The staged readings alone have stirred discussion, arguments, introspection and ultimately great praise, it will be thrilling to see what happens when this insightful piece is brought to the full production it more than deserves." - Nic Arnzen (Director Corpus Christi, I Am Love, Some Men)


ABOUT THE SHOW
Jeremy (Jason Heymann) is having a mid-life crisis.  He’s 27.   While attending his Uncle’s wake, he  meets Austin (Brionne Davis),  a fellow mourner.  Jeremy is instantly drawn in by this handsome stranger's mysterious charm. They connect immediately, and as their conversation progresses, Jeremy discovers an uncomfortable truth:  Austin is a “wake-hopper”.  
Lukas, Jeremy’s roommate, has a wonderful and loving relationship with his partner, Frankie.  Unfortunately,  Frankie has been in a permanent vegetative state for the last two years.
Kathy, Frankie’s sister, is living the American dream:  She has a "great" career, a big house in the suburbs with a nice lawn and a white picket fence, two beautiful children and a husband…with whom she doesn't have sex with.  Like her brother, Kathy is realizing that her marriage is in a permanent vegetative state.
WAKING UP is a commentary on the similarities between grief and love and the consequences of what happens when those lines are blurred.
Click the red for: An Interview with playwright Augusto Federico Amador

Original soundtrack by Michelle Amador and Dan Holguin
Your donation is tax deductible, yes... tax deductible! You're contribution will be toward the lauded Celebration Theatre in Los Angeles, a 501c3 organization. The Celebration Theatre is happy to be the fiscal sponsor of Waking Up Productions  and supports the full production of the new staged play, WAKING UP, by Augusto Federico Amador. 
The play has gone through considerable rewrites and a journey across the country to find itself a home with THE IMAGINED LIFE THEATRE which has been generously donated for a six week run by esteemed acting teachers Diana Castle and Steve Tiesort.  WAKING UP showcases our basic human need to love, and validates a world in which we are all connected. The production team and cast believe that this is the appropriate time for such a story.

So whether you are an arts patron or are simply looking for a tax write-off or hopefully both!  Rest assured that your generous donation is tax deductible! And will be supporting a fresh and universal story that can, through your support and donation, be experienced by large theater going audiences. Your contribution will go towards costs such as the set design, lighting design, publicity and all other necessities that will make this production unforgettable and inspired!

Los Angeles, CA 90019

Full Show Production:  January 2012
Dates for receptions and parties will be confirmed soon

story:
What is the musical about?

"Courage is the price that life exacts for granting peace"

Amelia Earhart used this as the first line of a poem she wrote shortly before becoming the very first woman ever to cross the Atlantic Ocean by plane.

In FINAL APPROACH, we journey with Amelia as she uses her courage to live life as she chooses; to love as she chooses and to make her dreams a reality.

And we realize we can... we must follow her example; to rekindle and inspire in ourselves the courage to be true to ourselves and to our dreams no matter what; whether that dream is flying a plane, running a business or finding the person to spend our life with.

What ever dream you have - it can come true by having courage to be true to yourself - This is Amelia's legacy and the story of FINAL APPROACH.

 

              ************We are just about there***********

 

I know it does not look it but thanks to some very kind offline donors, we now have almost all the money we need except for about $1500 to finish paying salaries and rent a piano for the recording.

So now is the time we need you more than ever to lend a hand - donate whatever you can to make this dream come true - to bring all the amazingly talented people listed below together to create a new musical.

 

FIANAL APPROACH PERFORMERS

Don Richard - Two time Broadway actor to play George
Lauren Braton - Amazing Triple Threat to play Amelia (check her out on youtube)
Tim Noland - Former new York actor
(And Claudia will be singing the role of Dorothy)

FINAL APPROACH'S CREATIVE TEAM

Laurie McLaughlin: (Bookwriter) Everyone knows about Amelia Earhart. Although she disappeared in 1937, people are still fascinated by her. After spending ten years researching her life and the life of her husband George Palmer Putnam, this musical will go behind the scenes to show the truth of her life; discovering what has inspired and captivated people about her for so long.

When I was 6, I remember my father taking my to my first air show. I remember the power and the beauty of the planes and it was then I fell in love with aviation. Also that same year I first remember sitting in the theatre watching rehearsals for a production of Oklahoma my parents, uncle and aunt were in and from that moment, I was hooked on a life long love for musical theatre and my destiny was set for a career in the theatre. I spent all told 30 years in theatre (25 professionally) mostly as a stage manager, production manager and lighting designer. Through those years, I have been fortunate enough to work with Donald O'Connor, Shirley Jones and Terrence Mann and work on the workshop of Heart's Desire with Sergio Trujillo and be involved in the out of town pre-Broadway production of Teddy And Alice with Len Cariou and helped give Andrew Harrison Leeds his big break.

Claudia Schmidt: (Composer/lyricist) Michigan native Claudia Schmidt has covered a lot of musical ground, beginning with a stirring rendition of Tammy at age 4 around a neighborhood bonfire. More than three decades as a touring professional have found her traversing North America as well as Europe in venues ranging from intimate clubs to to festival stages in front
of 25,000 rapt listeners.

A musician who has always hated categories, she has recorded fourteen albums of mostly original songs, exploring folk, blues, and jazz idioms featuring her acclaimed12 string guitar and mountain dulcimer playing. She has performed on radio and TV, including regular stints on Public Radio International's A Prairie Home Companion in its early incarnation, and starring in an hour-long documentary called I Sing Because I Can't Fly produced by KTCA TV in St. Paul. She participated in Les Blank's delightful movie Gap-Toothed Women. She wrote the award-winning score of the Goodman Theatre's 1992 Chicago production of Brecht's Good Person of Szechuan and she performed along with Ruth McKenzie and Prudence Johnson in The Gales of November, a musical retelling of the Edmund Fitzgerald tragedy. And she just finished a new album with Sally Rogers.

Marge Adler: (Arranger) An Ohio native, Marge is classically trained on piano and harpsichord, and former Organist for the Cleveland Indians! but is definately no stranger to the world of musical theatre. She has been musical director for over 60 professional shows as well as being the musical director for the Cleveland production of the Forbidden Broadway SVU national tour. Audiences and critics nationwide are raving about Marge's versatility, humor, virtuosity and her signature mix of musical styles. creating musical bridges between styles, between traditions, between old and new, sacred and secular -- all blended together to form stories to bring people together, to unite us
in our human experience.

In 2007, Marge won the Unsigned Recording artist of the Month award from Keyboard Magazine (she was their Miss April) for her inspired CD called Balm in Gilead, causing Jim Brickman called it "inventive, like nothing else out there".

Marge's amazing talents have allowed her to work with such artists as Anton Coppola and David Lockington, to Broadway's Dee Hoty.

What We Need & What You Get

So, once you donate, you will be kept up to date about the progress of the show and will see where the money you donate today will eventually lead.

And not only will your money go to getting our demo disc made which brings our (yours and ours) musical Final Approach one step closet to Broadway, but if you look to the right, you will see that because we cannot climb right through the monitor and kiss you on the lips in gratitude, you will have to settle for these very cool perks as a token of our immense thanks for making this dream a reality.

 Other Ways You Can Help

So, please share this with anyone you can think of - you don't even have to know them very well - if you think it is good enough to donate money to, others will too.

 Use this as a conversation starter with other cool people you want to get to know.

Impress your friends by telling them you are investing in a musical that might go to Broadway, and have them invest too.

 Facebook, Myspace, Tweet, start a Meetup group, blog.... go Viral on us!

 No amount is too small

 And on behalf of Claudia, Marge and myself, thanks again so much.

QUESTIONS: 

E-mail Laurie at Dustymiss@aol.com

.

Marge's amazing talents have allowed her to work with such artists as Anton Coppola and David Lockington, to Broadway's Dee Hoty.
What We Need & What You Get



So, once you donate, you will be kept up to date about the progress of the show and will see where the money you donate today will eventually lead.
And not only will your money go to getting our demo disc made which brings our (yours and ours) musical Final Approach one step closet to Broadway, but if you look to the right, you will see that because we cannot climb right through the monitor and kiss you on the lips in gratitude, you will have to settle for these very cool perks as a token of our immense thanks for making this dream a reality.
 Other Ways You Can Help
So, please share this with anyone you can think of - you don't even have to know them very well - if you think it is good enough to donate money to, others will too.


 Use this as a conversation starter with other cool people you want to get to know.
Impress your friends by telling them you are investing in a musical that might go to Broadway, and have them invest too.
 Facebook, Myspace, Tweet, start a Meetup group, blog.... go Viral on us!
 No amount is too small
 And on behalf of Claudia, Marge and myself, thanks again so much.
QUESTIONS:

story:
Twenty undergraduate theater students have a once in a lifetime opportunity to perform and attend workshops in Bangkok, Thailand in May 2016. These students will present two original devised pieces at Chulalongkorn University and participate in workshops in joint with Thai students. 

Pace University is providing the students with this amazing experience by covering the costs of travel, lodging and other accommodations. However, the students are hoping to take full advantage of the unique artistic and cultural opportunities that Thailand has to offer and this is where they need your support. Each individual student is hoping to raise $500 to ensure they get the most the experience has to offer, resulting in a goal of $10,000. Your contributions towards this goal will go towards any in-country fees while abroad. This fundraising campaign is independent of the university and the amount raised will go directly to the students.

All twenty students are grateful and ecstatic for this artistic experience and are excited to get to share their two beautiful pieces on an international level. The two shows, UPHORIUM! (we made this) and youexistrightnow, have been growing in development for over a year.

UPHORIUM! (we made this) features experts, singing, dancing, research, references to puppies, meaningful gestures, muffins, and much, much more. We're not quite sure what's going to happen but we know it's going to happen. Our fingers are crossed!

In youexistrightnow, a man writes a book, a woman climbs a bridge railing and nine people's lives spanning 65 years wrap around each other. A meditation on life, death and connection, youexistrightnow is an ensemble based magic realism play that explores the impact of existing in your given Present and the desire to affect the Future.

Below are photos from the New York premiere of both pieces (February 2016), as long as photos from the workshop presentations of May 2015.

May 2015 Workshop: (Mara Rothman Photography)

February 2016:

story:
Who are we?

Cave Painting Theater Company was founded in 2012 as Anam Gan Ainm Theater; our name changed in 2013 to honor humanity's oldest form of recorded storytelling. Our mission is to explore the human experience and promote honesty and empathy in the human community through timeless stories and mind-expanding language. Now in our fourth season, previous productions have included The Player Queen, Andromache, The Dark Is Light Enough, As You Like It,The Tragedy of Lear, and Sudden Vanishings: A New Works Festival. We tend to move around a lot, but Land of Never-Lack will take place at the Frontier Theatre in Chicago's Edgewater neighborhood. You can learn more about us at www.cavepaintingtheater.com.


What’s the play about?

Land of Never-Lack combines W.B. Yeats’ 1889 play Land of Heart’s Desire with a new story written by Harold Jaffe and Gwen Kelly-Masterton in a melange of dream-like bitter-sweetness and energetic whimsey. In 18th Century Sligo, newlywed Maire wishes for an escape from her stifling new life-- could the strange child that arrives at her in-laws house be the answer? Meanwhile, elsewhere and elsewhen, a mischievous Sprite gets more than she bargained for when she tries to “replace” Siobhan, the human child she kidnapped by accident.

Many human cultures have developed a mythology of “anti-humans”-- gods, spirits, ghosts, faeries-- as an important part of understanding what it means to be human. Land of Never-Lack’s intertwining stories juxtapose the uncertainty and contradictions of an adult’s search for independence and the black-and-white moral landscape of an eleven-year-old. As each protagonist must choose between Humanity and Faery, the stories ask: if you had a chance to leave behind all pain, hunger, and loss, and live forever in a world where you’d never want anything you couldn’t have, would you take it? If suffering and mortality make us human, what is being human worth? Is it better to be wise, or happy? Would you rather give up freedom, or love?

Land of Never-Lack is being directed by Gwen Kelly-Masterton and features returning cast members Gabriel Howard (The Dark Is Light Enough, As You Like It, The Tragedy of Lear), Sandra Howard (The Tragedy of Lear), and Stephen McClure (Andromache, As You Like It, Sudden Vanishings); new faces Michael Dwiggens, Gabriela Fernandez, and Therin Miller; the design talents of Kristen Ahern (Costume), Rebecca Bartle (Lights), Christina Hubbard (Set) and Ben Masterton Sound); and original music by Ben Masterton (As You Like It).


Where's the money going?

Your gifts will help us bring you this delightful piece of theater. Here's a breakdown:

Minimum Goal: $1,375+: Covers our rent at Frontier Theatre.

Stretch Goal 1: $1,775+: Also covers set and costume budget.

Stretch Goal 3: $2,200+: Also covers additional production expenses and marketing.

Your gifts give us the ability to continue operating on a shares system. Once cost of production is funded by YOUR generous donation, we will divide all the money we receive from ticket sales between the actors, artists and crew involved with the show! We firmly believe art is worth money and artists should be paid. Help us make that happen-- and bring you a truly magical piece of theater!


What do I do now?

Get involved-- donate! Every bit helps. Give early. Give often! And share, share, share. Tell your friends, tell your enemies, tell your ravening hordes of Social Media fans if you have them. Tell your parents, they could probably use a call anyway. With your help, we can make this happen. We even have a few perks for our backers! Look to your right. There they are.

PLEASE NOTE: Indiegogo has made some changes to their site-- they no longer let donors customize their gift amount if they select a perk. But don't worry! If you'd like to give more than the designated amount for a perk, please choose "contribute now" (no perk) and donate your custom amount. We'll thank all "visible" donors on social media, and at the close of the campaign we'll contact all "No perk" donors so you can let us know which perk you'd like.

Thank you, with all our hearts, for your gift. And see you at the show!

story:
WHO WE ARE!  WHAT WE'RE DOING!

     Hello!  My name is Shirin June and I am in the final quarter of my MFA at CSULA!  The culmination of my time there will be my thesis project.  I have chosen to write, produce and perform an original theatrical production, E.

  I have had the opportunity to be exposed to a lot while pursuing my Masters of Fine Arts: different mediums of entertainment, different areas of creativity, and different experts and mentors in each of these areas. However, after each interaction, I was always left wanting something more. After three years at California State University, Los Angeles, I do not feel that I have left my mark on this campus or in this program. I did not want to leave with only a degree in my hand. I wanted to create a piece of art that not only showcased my talents as a matured artist but also one that spoke to and of what drives me as an actor, artist and human being.

     Joined by my best friend in life and my best friend in this program, I have been able to surround myself with people that inspire me.  Together, we will work to challenge one another and strive to bring out the best of our talents.

 

     Using the myth of Eurydice and Orpheus as well as the tragic history of Eva Braun and Adolf Hitler, I've attempted to deconstruct the question “what does it mean to love?”  Between these two ruinous stories, the audience should be able to deconstruct the effects of love on women.

 

WHAT WE NEED! WE NEED YOU!!

     Taking many things into consideration, I've written the piece to be staged in a Black Box Theater. However, that said, there are still many elements and creative ideas that we would like to explore. The play and the text are merely the canvas for our art. With your help, we can bring the words to life and leave the audience with imagery that will invoke and ignite.

 

Where Your Donation Goes

  •      In addition to the logistical elements that go into producing a show – posters, flyers, programs – we would like to expand the quality of the design elements. There are a few props in particular that the piece would not be complete or possible without, namely the Lyre of Orpheus. Coincidentally, this is not a prop that is readily available on a typical college campus. We have found a few instruments that would be fantastic and with your donation, we will be able to purchase this symbolic item.

 

  •       After attending the 42nd KC/ACTF in Ogden, Utah this past February as an Irene Ryan Nominee and having the opportunity to attend a week's worth of productions and workshops, I would like to submit the production for consideration in the 43rd Annual Festival. As a new, original production, and as an actor, I would like to have the play adjudicated by a festival respondent. The process would include a talkback following the performance as well as the opportunity to have the play, the production, the cast, and the crew nominated for numerous achievements, including the chance to remount the production for a larger, collegiate audience. Your donation would help cover the entrance fee and would get us one step closer to this goal!

 

  •      Logistically, we know we will be incurring a lot of fees just to keep up with good “housekeeping”. We've determined these to include dry cleaning costs for the costumes that we will be borrowing, charges for using equipment and locations for rehearsals and performances, as well as transportation. In these dire economic times, every cent helps -- especially when it comes to transportation! We will do our best to commute via the Metrolink trains as well as carpool when necessary but the distance is ever mighty!

 

  •       CONTINGENCY PLAN!: If I've learned only one thing from my ARTS MANAGEMENT course with Professor Paul Graham it's to always have a contingency plan!! Ten percent of our budget will be put aside for any unforeseen and emergency expenses that may come up during this process!

 

 

      Our goal is to have four performances during the weekend of May 18-20, 2012. We would be honored and pleased to have you in our audience. The cost of attendance is free as we are not working for a profit; we only wish to create good work and to establish a foundation for discourse, dialogue and discovery.



Every Help Helps!

     Any donation helps get us closer to our goal! Even if we are unable to reach $1700, all funds will be put to the best of use to create a memorable and meaningful project. If you would like to personally donate your contribution, we would be more than happy and humbled to meet with you.



Other Ways You Can Help

     Please consider donating ONE SECOND of your time! It's as simple as “sharing” our IndieGoGo link, “liking” our show's page, and of course, attending a performance! We would love to hear what you have to say! The project doesn't end with the performances! I am working on the companion thesis research paper and your feedback and response would be invaluable to this process!



PICK MY BRAIN :)

     For over the past year, I've lived, breathed, dreamed, and sometimes even nightmared E. If you have any questions about the production, about the people, or about the process, please feel free to ask any one of us! We would love to hear from you!
story_txt:
WHO WE ARE!  WHAT WE'RE DOING!
     Hello!  My name is Shirin June and I am in the final quarter of my MFA at CSULA!  The culmination of my time there will be my thesis project.  I have chosen to write, produce and perform an original theatrical production, E.
  I have had the opportunity to be exposed to a lot while pursuing my Masters of Fine Arts: different mediums of entertainment, different areas of creativity, and different experts and mentors in each of these areas. However, after each interaction, I was always left wanting something more. After three years at California State University, Los Angeles, I do not feel that I have left my mark on this campus or in this program. I did not want to leave with only a degree in my hand. I wanted to create a piece of art that not only showcased my talents as a matured artist but also one that spoke to and of what drives me as an actor, artist and human being.

     Joined by my best friend in life and my best friend in this program, I have been able to surround myself with people that inspire me.  Together, we will work to challenge one another and strive to bring out the best of our talents.
 
      Using the myth of Eurydice and Orpheus as well as the tragic history of Eva Braun and Adolf Hitler, I've attempted to deconstruct the question “what does it mean to love?”  Between these two ruinous stories, the audience should be able to deconstruct the effects of love on women.
 
WHAT WE NEED! WE NEED YOU!!
     Taking many things into consideration, I've written the piece to be staged in a Black Box Theater. However, that said, there are still many elements and creative ideas that we would like to explore. The play and the text are merely the canvas for our art. With your help, we can bring the words to life and leave the audience with imagery that will invoke and ignite.
 
Where Your Donation Goes

     In addition to the logistical elements that go into producing a show – posters, flyers, programs – we would like to expand the quality of the design elements. There are a few props in particular that the piece would not be complete or possible without, namely the Lyre of Orpheus. Coincidentally, this is not a prop that is readily available on a typical college campus. We have found a few instruments that would be fantastic and with your donation, we will be able to purchase this symbolic item.
 

      After attending the 42nd KC/ACTF in Ogden, Utah this past February as an Irene Ryan Nominee and having the opportunity to attend a week's worth of productions and workshops, I would like to submit the production for consideration in the 43rd Annual Festival. As a new, original production, and as an actor, I would like to have the play adjudicated by a festival respondent. The process would include a talkback following the performance as well as the opportunity to have the play, the production, the cast, and the crew nominated for numerous achievements, including the chance to remount the production for a larger, collegiate audience. Your donation would help cover the entrance fee and would get us one step closer to this goal!
 

     Logistically, we know we will be incurring a lot of fees just to keep up with good “housekeeping”. We've determined these to include dry cleaning costs for the costumes that we will be borrowing, charges for using equipment and locations for rehearsals and performances, as well as transportation. In these dire economic times, every cent helps -- especially when it comes to transportation! We will do our best to commute via the Metrolink trains as well as carpool when necessary but the distance is ever mighty!
 

      CONTINGENCY PLAN!: If I've learned only one thing from my ARTS MANAGEMENT course with Professor Paul Graham it's to always have a contingency plan!! Ten percent of our budget will be put aside for any unforeseen and emergency expenses that may come up during this process!
 
 
      Our goal is to have four performances during the weekend of May 18-20, 2012. We would be honored and pleased to have you in our audience. The cost of attendance is free as we are not working for a profit; we only wish to create good work and to establish a foundation for discourse, dialogue and discovery.

Every Help Helps!
     Any donation helps get us closer to our goal! Even if we are unable to reach $1700, all funds will be put to the best of use to create a memorable and meaningful project. If you would like to personally donate your contribution, we would be more than happy and humbled to meet with you.

Other Ways You Can Help
     Please consider donating ONE SECOND of your time! It's as simple as “sharing” our IndieGoGo link, “liking” our show's page, and of course, attending a performance! We would love to hear what you have to say! The project doesn't end with the performances! I am working on the companion thesis research paper and your feedback and response would be invaluable to this process!

PICK MY BRAIN :)
     For over the past year, I've lived, breathed, dreamed, and sometimes even nightmared E. If you have any questions about the production, about the people, or about the process, please feel free to ask any one of us! We would love to hear from you!

story:
Hi!!

We're Browncoat Bellydance, a professional geek bellydance troupe from Canton, North Carolina.  "Hold on a second."  You might say.  "Geek bellydance?  Is that a thing?"  Why, yes it is!!  We're a group of dancers who geek out on bellydancing and various fandoms.  We bring both our loves together in an awesome show.  We've performed at Comic Conventions in multiple states and are going on tour this summer across North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia.  

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the breakdown:

  • We're raising money for two airbrush machines. ($149 and change each)  We love to give our audience the most real experience possible, which sometimes involves turning ourselves green, grey, blue, or a myriad of other colors.  
  • We're also raising money for quality paints for the airbrush machine.  We get a great deal on body paint through a company, but we go through a lot.  It costs approximately $100 a gallon, which covers us (literally) for 3 performances.  We'd like to pick up 3 gallons at a cost of approximately $300.
  • Any extra money raised will go into providing mirrors for the studio.  We're currently making due with old closet sliding door mirrors.  They work, but boy it would be nice to have something a little nicer.
  • Remember, 8-10% of the funds we raise go to Indegogo (hey, they have to make a living), PayPal, and the credit card processing companies.
  • "Wait a second, what do WE get for helping you?"  Well, we're excited to offer you our unique swag, even at the $5 level!!  There's no only receiving "heart felt thanks" here.  We start with an awesome button that you can wear to display your BcBd pride and go up to a private show for you and your friends at our top level.  You also have the satisfaction of knowing you've supported something awesome in the geek arts community.
  • We've set the bar at the bare minimum we need.  Unfortunately, if we don't reach our goal, we don't get the funds.  Any little bit helps and we are grateful for every contribution!

The Impact

Why you should contribute to our campaign:

  • We are the fans.  We love the same things you love.  We work our butts off to bring you the best in geek dance.  We put tons of time, effort, and love into each piece all for you.
  • We hate asking for money, which is why we're bringing you a campaign in which YOU get something at EVERY SINGLE LEVEL.  

Challenges

As everyone is become more and more aware, large corporations are buying up the smaller, fan-based cons.  What used to be an immersive experience is turning more into meet and greets with a shopping experience.  This means we've got to show how valuable and high-quality geek entertainment can be.  We're fighting to keep the con an experience-based event. We're using our medium to entertain and celebrate geek and nerd culture in a professional, flashy and entertaining manner.  We know that everyone has had experiences with enthusiastic performers who are weekend warriors and want to share their arts (there also are lots of other awesome groups out there).  We strive to take that to the next level by creating and performing a full-realized theatrical-style show. 

We know that this is difficult and requires a lot of time and resources.  We're devoted to the mission and appreciate the enthusiastic fans we have performed for.  We're thrilled to be moving forward and expanding, upping our game with each performance.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out about this campaign and Browncoat Bellydance.  Share this on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, whatever other awesome Social Media tools you use!  Be our biggest fan!  We already are yours!
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!  They're already here waiting for you!

Thank you for taking the time to boost the signal.  Stay shiny! <3

story:
ABOUT THIS PROJECT:

Bringing Terry Quinn's Bad Evidence to Los Angeles for the West Coast Premiere six week Stage Production to open November 2012.

I have laid it all out in massive detail below. Feel free to scan, glance, peruse, take in all in one sitting or come back for more.

Update Aug. 21, 2012- I will be dedicating my performance to Tony Scott. A man I worked for, knew and loved. Sadly,  I never got to watch him direct and he never saw me act but I know he would love the passion, sex, drugs & profanity in this show. Sorry TS no guns, fast cars, trains, planes, cigars etc. but hopefully we will bring some rock n roll too!

Bad Evidence - A drama in two acts

A faltering marriage compels a husband and wife to make a pact – they will disclose searing truths in the heat of passion. The exposure leads to a confrontation with four of their friends, and deeper revelations.

Backstory:

Bad Evidence is a play that struck me instantaneously when I read it in April 2011.

Have you ever had that happen? You watch a movie, tv show, read a book, hear a song, look at a painting and are just stabbed in the heart and not even because you overtly relate or have had that exact experience or even understand what you are seeing, hearing, feeling but you just know that you are deeply connected to this piece. That's what happened to me with Bad Evidence.

If I had just one goal with this project it would be to get as many people as possible to experience this play so that maybe just maybe one person will be as affected as I was when I read it for the first time.

Now:

So how did I get from deeply connected in NYC to co-producing/starring in the West Coast Premiere in LA?  

The short version or rather the shorter version: I auditioned for the World Premiere at The Cell Theatre in NYC last spring, got a call back which was the best call back experience I have ever had for anything, went to see the show out of love for the play even though I didn't get the part, ran into the playwright, kept in touch with him and then 4 months later with no new creative projects pending I got this wild voice  in my head that wouldn't leave me saying DO BAD EVIDENCE! PRODUCE IT.  ACT IN THE ROLE YOU LOVED. SHARE THIS BOLD PLAY WITH THE WORLD! OK? But how?  GET THE RIGHTS. DO IT IN LA. YOU KNOW SO MUCH TALENT THERE AND THERE'S GOT TO BE SOME REASON YOU HAVEN'T BEEN ABLE TO LET GO OF YOUR HOLLYWOOD APARTMENT AFTER TWO YEARS IN NY, NOT TO MENTION YOUR CAR? Terrified and thrilled, at the start of the New Year, I thought of the old quote from Risky Business "Every now and then say, 'What the fuck.' 'What the fuck' gives you freedom. Freedom brings opportunity. Opportunity makes your future. " So I went for it and emailed the playwright requesting  the rights to a West Coast Premiere production.  I got a resounding yes and the project was pregnant and on it's way...So now 7 months later, unlike a baby that will be born whether you have the money or not this baby needs more than a helping hand and lots of pushing but a healthy dose of cash.

So please help me give birth to this beautiful child of love. Thanks in advance for your support.

How much is this show gonna cost? 

Our Budget is at $28,500 though my producer would be happier if we had over $30,000. 

 "But Glory it's 99 seat waiver theatre in LA, why do you need so much money?"

It's 99 seat theatre not 99 cent theatre. I have produced a show for under a grand and also one for under five grand but no one was being paid and you get what you pay for- in stress if nothing else. With this project my desire is to offer a professional experience of talent, love, respect and commitment. To offer respect means to value people I am working with and pay them something for their talent, not expect it for free just because one can, in Los Angeles land of dreams and mirages as well as miracles and surprises.

"I'm confused why are you asking for 12.5K when the budget is 28.5K?"

I crunched the numbers and 12.5K is double the number I thought I could achieve here, and one that scares me and pushes my edge. It's also just enough to get the show started.

I am using 5K from my own hard earnings... will probably be getting the rest through  blood, sweat, tears and more sweat. It's very hot and humid in New York and I cook for a living so...sweat is plentiful.

There will also be a few fundraising events such as a spinning class taught at a top studio in Los Angeles - TBA. Check back for info or I will stalk you with it : )

 

"But you still haven't said where the money is going?"  Hold your horses! It's going oh so many places, none of which are my new shoe budget despite the fact that New York Kills Espadrilles and other flat shoes and I am seriously in need of new footwear.

Theatre Rental- This is a lot folks and in looking it hasn't even gone up much since the first show I produced in 1998 which is sad for theatre but good for us since even then it was pricey.

Producer's Fee- This is professional theatre or theater if you prefer and it's hard to produce a show alone from New York after you've been away for two years and oh are also starring in the show and raising the money.

Director's Fee- See above where I said you get what you pay for and I am offering a professional experience. Enough said. 

Actors' Fees- Actors who get paid show up and feel respected. I am not doing community theatre in Saugatuck, Michigan. Though it's a beautiful city and you should go to the film festival there next summer: http://www.waterfrontfilm.org

Full Budget List:

Producer, Director,Playwright, Actors, Stage Manager,                                              Set Designer, Lighting Designer, Sound Designer, Costume Designer, Press Photographer, Graphic Designer, Theatre Rental, Rehearsal /Audition Space Rental, Liability Insurance,  Light/Sound Rentals, Set materials, Costume materials, Props/misc, Postcards Printing & Distribution, Programs Banner/signage at theatre, Pre-show/show advertising, LA Stage Alliance, Opening night gala, Box office , Concessions

*If you want hard numbers, email me. I don't want to advertise the rates of those working for me as it can affect the rates they are paid for future work, but am happy to share that information privately with donors upon request and with permission of those working for me.  

 **If  the entire goal is not reached all funds will go to my director, my producer and I going on a ski trip to Mammoth. Just kidding but you are welcome to contribute separately to my travel fund. This play is happening whether I reach the goal or not. I would just prefer to avoid extreme credit card debt and tax evasion so help me do this the sane way.

 Other Ways You Can Support the Project

First off no amount of money is too little. If I could find 1000 people to give me $2.50; I would be 20 percent there. But if you can't give money and still want to show support all I ask is that you share the news via twitter, facebook, googleplus, OKCupid, Match.com, your blog, your church, your acting class, your yoga class, your bank, your instagram etc. Rise and Shine and Give God your Glory Glory or just share your Glory Glory or my Glory Glory.  Here's the link to share: https://www.indiegogo.com/badevidencela

 

TOP TEN REASONS TO CONTRIBUTE TO BAD EVIDENCE

10. You love me- (which means you don't want the IRS and Credit Card companies chasing me. You would prefer I live a happy joyous and debt- free actress, producer, chef  life: )

9. You love theatre that involves challenged interpersonal relationships and sex.  Yes, I said Sex and yes I meant challenged sex.

8.You wish you could say you made more charitable donations than money that goes to your ex-wife or your bartender if you live in New York or to your trainer or your life coach in Los Angeles. 

 

7. You hate to cook and shop and fear walking into bakeries but love home cooked meals and fresh baked cookies. 

 

No, I did not steal these photos. They are all my creations and there are more in the gallery!

 6. You like to see people achieve their dreams and get to be a part of that. Aw yes, I mean that you too can make a difference.

 5. Starbucks has enough money.

 * Ramona does not support or oppose Starbucks nor is she a reason to donate. She's just cute and meant to subliminally stimulate empathy, vulnerability, generosity and kindness

 4. Did I say Cookies? MMMN Cookies.... Yum. I will even make them gluten free, vegan and sans sugar if you wish.

3.  You are not a douchebag and I love you. Oh well that's kind of two reasons but they go together. I also love Duck Bacon which has little relevance here.

 

2. You've always wanted to say you were a producer (Or you want to finally say it and be able to prove it.)

1. You will get a boobie hug.  No, I won't hug your boobs but if I hug you it will be boobilicious and who doesn't love a boobie hug? (It's ok Dad this doesn't apply to you. Sherri cover his eyes.)

 

*If you would like to share better reasons I am happy to amend and post this top ten list on updates cause I am that kind of gal and I finally figured out how to upload photos into this gosh darn thing!

 

Perks/Rewards:

It was suggested by a close female friend that I offer a photo shoot with my boobs but apparently that falls under pornography and sexually explicit material so alas that will not be a perk.  But I do have some tasty delights to offer you to your right.

Why do you want me to cook for you and what is Sweet Glory?  I am a trained culinary professional, currently working as a personal chef in NYC and one that will allow you make substitutions and have complicated dietary restrictions and cook for you with love and care.  I have references to boot. You can see photos above and in the gallery. Sweet Glory is the name for my upcoming line of cookies that will have both decadent and dietary restriction friendly choices. 

 

More About Bad Evidence:

The Team:

Director: Katie Sabira http://www.katierubin.com/

Playwright: Terry Quinn  http://terryquinn.com/

Producer: Racquel Lehrman

http://www.theatreplanners.com/index.html

Actress ( Leah)/Producer: Glory Simon and bio

http://riseshineglory.blogspot.com/

http://glorysimon.com/- website being rebuilt launching Fall 2012

More Cast and Crew TBA 

Review Exerpts from the World Premiere of Bad Evidence at The Cell Theatre in NYC:

Review from Fix.com

 Bad Evidence keeps its realistic tone with partial nudity, language and topics that aren’t afraid to push the envelope... The power and the intensity of the dialogue keep the audience hanging on every word as deep dark secrets are revealed...

Audiences will love Bad Evidence because it’s so relatable and realistic. Anyone who has been in a relationship, or is married will understand the volatile yet loving relationship Leah and Richard have and root for them to work it out.

 WCBS Radio 880 / The City Life  Reviewed by Stuart Lewis

I love some good New York theater that hits you straight in the gut and breaks free of convention. Case in point is the extremely honest and searingly clever play Bad Evidence, now playing at The Cell in Chelsea.

The play asks the question: Can you bury the ugliness of the past and start fresh with a clean slate in a relationship? In the first scene the couple plays a game – what if one of them was dying. What sort of truths would you uncover? What seems like very evolved behavior quickly deteriorates into psychological warfare, and the tension in the theater was palpable.

It’s sort of like a modern-day Whose Afraid of Virginia Wolff, but instead of wanting to off yourself in the end, there is a shimmer of hope that resonates in the last line and leaves you wondering about the fate of these somewhat tortured but very much alive people.

But if you can't give money and still want to show support all I ask is that you share the news via twitter, facebook, googleplus, OKCupid, Match.com, your blog, your church, your acting class, your yoga class, your bank, your instagram etc. Rise and Shine and Give God your Glory Glory or just share your Glory Glory or my Glory Glory.  Here's the link to share: https://www.indiegogo.com/badevidencela
 
TOP TEN REASONS TO CONTRIBUTE TO BAD EVIDENCE
10. You love me- (which means you don't want the IRS and Credit Card companies chasing me. You would prefer I live a happy joyous and debt- free actress, producer, chef  life: )

9. You love theatre that involves challenged interpersonal relationships and sex.  Yes, I said Sex and yes I meant challenged sex.

8.You wish you could say you made more charitable donations than money that goes to your ex-wife or your bartender if you live in New York or to your trainer or your life coach in Los Angeles. 
 
7. You hate to cook and shop and fear walking into bakeries but love home cooked meals and fresh baked cookies. 
 
No, I did not steal these photos. They are all my creations and there are more in the gallery!
 6. You like to see people achieve their dreams and get to be a part of that. Aw yes, I mean that you too can make a difference.

 5. Starbucks has enough money. 

 * Ramona does not support or oppose Starbucks nor is she a reason to donate. She's just cute and meant to subliminally stimulate empathy, vulnerability, generosity and kindness
 4. Did I say Cookies? MMMN Cookies.... Yum. I will even make them gluten free, vegan and sans sugar if you wish.

3.  You are not a douchebag and I love you. Oh well that's kind of two reasons but they go together. I also love Duck Bacon which has little relevance here.
 
 2. You've always wanted to say you were a producer (Or you want to finally say it and be able to prove it.)
1. You will get a boobie hug.  No, I won't hug your boobs but if I hug you it will be boobilicious and who doesn't love a boobie hug? (It's ok Dad this doesn't apply to you. Sherri cover his eyes.)
 
*If you would like to share better reasons I am happy to amend and post this top ten list on updates cause I am that kind of gal and I finally figured out how to upload photos into this gosh darn thing!
 
Perks/Rewards: 
It was suggested by a close female friend that I offer a photo shoot with my boobs but apparently that falls under pornography and sexually explicit material so alas that will not be a perk.  But I do have some tasty delights to offer you to your right.
Why do you want me to cook for you and what is Sweet Glory?  I am a trained culinary professional, currently working as a personal chef in NYC and one that will allow you make substitutions and have complicated dietary restrictions and cook for you with love and care.  I have references to boot. You can see photos above and in the gallery. Sweet Glory is the name for my upcoming line of cookies that will have both decadent and dietary restriction friendly choices. 
 
More About Bad Evidence:
The Team:
Director: Katie Sabira http://www.katierubin.com/
Playwright: Terry Quinn  http://terryquinn.com/
Producer: Racquel Lehrman 
http://www.theatreplanners.com/index.html
Actress ( Leah)/Producer: Glory Simon and bio
http://riseshineglory.blogspot.com/
http://glorysimon.com/- website being rebuilt launching Fall 2012
More Cast and Crew TBA 
Review Exerpts from the World Premiere of Bad Evidence at The Cell Theatre in NYC: 
Review from Fix.com
 Bad Evidence keeps its realistic tone with partial nudity, language and topics that aren’t afraid to push the envelope... The power and the intensity of the dialogue keep the audience hanging on every word as deep dark secrets are revealed...
Audiences will love Bad Evidence because it’s so relatable and realistic. Anyone who has been in a relationship, or is married will understand the volatile yet loving relationship Leah and Richard have and root for them to work it out.
 WCBS Radio 880 / The City Life  Reviewed by Stuart Lewis I love some good New York theater that hits you straight in the gut and breaks free of convention. Case in point is the extremely honest and searingly clever play Bad Evidence, now playing at The Cell in Chelsea. The play asks the question: Can you bury the ugliness of the past and start fresh with a clean slate in a relationship? In the first scene the couple plays a game – what if one of them was dying. What sort of truths would you uncover? What seems like very evolved behavior quickly deteriorates into psychological warfare, and the tension in the theater was palpable. It’s sort of like a modern-day Whose Afraid of Virginia Wolff, but instead of wanting to off yourself in the end, there is a shimmer of hope that resonates in the last line and leaves you wondering about the fate of these somewhat tortured but very much alive people.

story:
The Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2013

The Max Bell Theatre Company is currently preparing to mount The Gypsybird Speaks, an original play by Derek Mitchell at the 2013 Festival Fringe in Edinburgh, Scotland. We're currently in the first phase of our fundraising, and we need your help to make it happen!

The Company

The Max Bell Theatre Company is composed mostly of theatre artists who met at Lester B. Pearson UWC in Victoria, British Columbia. Following the successful mounting of The Gypsybird Speaks in the spring of 2012, some of those involved have moved to perform the show in Edinburgh this summer, under the creative direction of Derek Mitchell. With the incorporation of producers Lauren Howe and Kaśka Nowacka, as well as several crewmembers and technicians from Edinburgh universities, the company has grown and transformed to meet the needs of this unique production.

More information regarding history, productions, and ticketing can be found at http://www.maxbelltheatre.com/

Where This Money Will Go

The Max Bell Theatre Company is alread contracted at C Venues, a large venue popular at the Edinburgh Fringe. The funds raised from this campaign will first go to fulfill guaranteed installments insuring our space at the venue, but they'll also cover additional production costs, as well as the expense of housing international cast and crewmembers through the months of July and August. This campaign will not cover all of our production costs; we'll also rely on arts-oriented grants and corporate sponsorships to fund our show. Here is our working provisional budget:

  • Venue Hire (66%) - $10,100
  • Housing (Int'l Cast & Crew) - $2,500
  • Food & Drink - $2,500
  • Transportation (Van Rental) - $1,000
  • Costumes - $300
  • Props & Puppets - $500
  • Marketing & Publicity - $1000
  • Music Licensing Fees - $100

The Show

The Gypsybird Speaks is an exploration of an outlandish group of characters whose immediate disparity is gradually softened, so that the bonds between each coalesce and blur narrative lines. The preliminary action takes place as a dialogue in a forest clearing; as a writer, a painter, a director and a witch banter and recall a young woman named Philena, a fictionalized reimagining of real-life 'gypsy moths' ravages the forest about the clearing. Across three acts, the dialogue becomes action compelled by unreliable narration, and the operation of puppets who act as mirrors for some of the distorted characters.

The narrative questions loneliness in the face of catastrophe, the fineness of hope, and the means by which we choose to escape.

Other Ways You Can Help

We at the Max Bell Theatre Company thank you for any and all monetary support you're able to provide; however, we understand that many of you are unable to contribute financially to our compaign. Regardless, we'd so appreciate your help spreading the word about our project via Facebook and Twitter! You can like our page, Max Bell Theatre Company, on Facebook, and help by spreading the link to this Indiegogo page in a status update or a tweet.

 

Thank you so very much!

Derek Mitchell, & The Max Bell Theatre Company

story:
FELT LEFT OUT tells the story of how some of the most beloved, cute, and colorful characters on television all ended up on “the street”. 

In this dramatic parody, we find answers to questions like why does he live in a garbage can, who turned that guy on to cookies anyway, and, of course, are those two roommates or “roommates”? 

Set in New York in the late 1960s when the show premiered, FELT LEFT OUT takes these puppets and treats them as real people with real problems like drug abuse, sexuality, violence, and family dysfunction. In this origin story for the ages, these characters start out at war with themselves and end up with a brand new family.

WHO?

For the longest time, FELT LEFT OUT’s playwright, Brett Crandall, has been called Bert by his family and close friends. Brett, longing to find the Ernie to his Bert, wondered how the iconic duo met, which expanded into the idea of an origin story for eight characters you know from the show. 

Thanks to the love and support surrounding this idea, the play was accepted into the Riant Theatre’s Strawberry Theatre Festival, where it will make its world premiere this February.

Brett Crandall is an actor/playwright from Kansas now living in New York City. Experiencing both the small town and big city lifestyle has given him an open mind when it comes to the way other people live their lives. Since graduating from the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York, Brett has worked in theatre, on web series, and somewhere in the mayhem, picked up a love for writing.

WHAT?

The Strawberry Theatre Festival is an extension of the Strawberry One-Act Festival, in which Full Length Plays, Musicals, Short Plays and Staged Readings of new works are showcased.

WHEN?

February 20th at 7:30pm February 22nd at 3:00pm

WHERE?

Theatre at St. Clement’s 423 West 46th St, NYC (Between 9th and 10th Avenue)  

HOW?

We are confident in our ability to create something audiences will love, but we can’t do it alone! We need your help to get this show at its very best! 

The Strawberry Theatre Festival provides the venue and ticketing, but (just like PBS) the rest is made possible with contributions from viewers like you!

Your donations will help us in making the following happen:

Lights/Props/Set

We want to make this play a world all its own. Mixing both the real emotion and depth of the characters with a fun and cooky set. And since this play is being presented in a festival, all props and set pieces must be easily set up and removed in less than 15 minutes, which comes at a price.

Costuming

Our actors are working hard in rehearsal to bring these characters to life: with just a little help from the right wardrobe our stars are bound to amaze!

Promotional Materials

Posters, programs, etc. 

The entire cast and crew is dedicated to getting this show going and spreading the word throughout New York City and beyond!

Thank you for your consideration and generosity!

story:
An Evening of Happenings

Sparrow Dance Productions is excited to announce its first full-length production, An Evening of Happenings, on September 27th! Sparrow has been a growing contemporary dance company in Albuquerque, New Mexico that has been making small impacts on the community through its freelance work and guest appearances in various venues. However, as a company, Sparrow has never had its own show solely dedicated to its dancers and its own choreography. For the first time ever, audiences will truly get to see the depth and range of the Sparrow company in a jazz-blues themed two-part evening, featuring choreography by Christina Daly and Devon Adams. The performance will take place at the Wheel Museum in Downtown Albuquerque September 27, 2015.

The Company

Sparrow Dance Productions is a multifaceted contemporary dance company based in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The company was originally founded in New York City in 2010 by director and choreographer Christina Daly. Since then, the company has moved to Albuquerque and has continued to grow artistically. Sparrow productions and the dancers of Sparrow demonstrate versatility and adaptability that the company prides itself on. Freelance venue-specific projects have allowed Sparrow to rehearse and perform in a wide and exciting variety of venues, such as the bank of the Rio Grande River, Zendo Coffee, The African American Performing Arts Center, consecutive years with Santa Fe Fashion Week, and TEDXABQ.

Even though Sparrow Dance Productions is becoming a recognized name in the Albuquerque area, it's time for Sparrow to become a full-fledged company and produce a performance entirely devoted to Sparrow.

Your Support
With your contributions and support, Sparrow Dance Productions can finally reach its goal of creating its own full-length show. The choreography is already in motion, the production is in development, and now we just need the funds to actually put on An Evening of Happenings. The funds will go towards the venue rental of the Wheel Museum, costumes, the purchase of lighting and prop elements, and dancer and choreographer salaries. We can make this entire production happen for $5,000; now we just need your help to raise it!

In order for Sparrow to afford these production costs, we're relying on your generous donations to help Sparrow soar. Every dollar helps, and the directing team, dancers, and audience members thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

Every individual who donates any amount to our fundraiser will receive a shout out of the company's love and gratitude on all forms of Sparrow Dance Productions social media. Additional perks for increasing donation amounts include coupons for $5/off tickets, mentions in the program, free tickets to An Evening of Happenings, and an autographed photo of the company.

The Impact
This dream of creating a full-length production is finally becoming a reality, and we need your help and support for Sparrow Dance Productions to grow into a full-fledged dance company. We are so excited to reveal the possibilities of Sparrow in this jazz-blues-themed evening of dance, and hope you can make it to Sparrow Dance Productions' first full-length performance!

story:
What's the show about?

Animals Out of Paper follows Ilana Andrews, the world-famous origamist, as she becomes the unwitting mentor to a troubled young prodigy, all while struggling with her own loss of inspiration. A subtle, elegant, yet bracing examination of the artistic impulse and those in its thrall.

Animals Out of Paper goes up May 1-3 in Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University.

Where is my money going?

Animals Out of Paper is entirely nonprofit and student-produced. As a donor to the show your money will help fund various aspects of our production. A donation from you may help us in building our set, or it may help us in acquiring costumes and lights, or it may help us fill the performance space and Northwestern with origami. Our cast and team are working incredibly hard to create a beautiful piece of theatre, and every dollar donated will help us realize this vision. 

Who is working on this project?

Our cast features:

  • Cordelia Dewdney as Ilana
  • Wyatt Fair as Andy
  • Adarsh Shah as Suresh
Who's working behind the scenes:
  • Producer: Tristan Chiruvolu
  • Director: Michelle Schechter
  • Assistant Director: Maddi Ginsberg
  • Stage Manager: Meredith Shadle
  • Dramaturg: Olivia Cygan
  • Set Designer: Melissa McSweeney
  • Costume Designer: Emily Martin
  • Props Designer: Bex Siegel
  • Origamist: Andre Sguerra
  • Lighting Designer: Tatyana Aravena-Getzinger
  • Assistant Lighting Designer: Kali Skatchke
  • Sound Designer: Matt Kania
  • Master Electrician: Alex Freedman
  • Graphic Designer: Alex Heller
  • Publicity Queens: Emily Fishkin, Kate Leggett
  • Fundraising Team: Anna Civik, Dhwani Jain, Charlie Oh

How else can I help?

If you are unable to donate, or if you just want to keep helping, here are some other ways to support our show:

  • Come and see the show! 
  • Spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, and tell your friends and family about the show!
Thank you so much!

story:
UPDATE: Check out our image gallery for rehearsal photos and snapshots from our most recent visit to the sculpture park

UPDATE 2: We've got one week left to raise funds! Even if you are unable to contribute monetarily, please share this page on your social media. Any publicity you can give greatly helps our efforts to bring Shakespeare to Franconia. 


What We're Doing

Twin Cities theatre giants Harry Waters, Jr. and Barbra Berlovitz are teaming up to co-direct a racially diverse cast in William Shakespeare's "The Tempest." This epic tale of love, magic, and forgiveness is made larger-than-life by the sculptures at Franconia Sculpture Park, the setting for the show. With support from Bedlam Theatre, Franconia Sculpture Park, Macalester College, and the Minnesota State Arts Board we've established a firm foundation for the production, but additional support is necessary to make our shared vision a reality. 


Why We're Doing It

  • We believe that artists of color deserve opportunities to tackle large Shakespearean roles. In a traditional theatre production, you probably won't see a black or brown body play Prospero. Our production, however, provides opportunities for actors of color to address the reality of race in Minnesota through Shakespearean text and artistic expression.


  • Franconia Sculpture Park inspires performance. Walking the 25 acres of the park, stories come up out of the earth. The sculptures invite play and spark the imagination. But in its 18 years of inspiring audiences, Franconia has never hosted a live, full-length theatre production. "The Tempest on Franconia Island" hopes to change that. And, in changing that history, we will bring high quality theatre to a rural population- increasing access to the arts and encouraging a new form of collaboration.


  • The life affirming power of forgiveness. As director Harry Waters, Jr says "The better course to revenge is forgiveness." Our production aims to address the fundamental problems in Shakespeare's handling of race and gender, and to respond in a spirit of hope. We seek healing and reconciliation through our art, working together towards a more just reality.


    How You Can Help


    Donations to this campaign are extremely important to the success of our project. The show described above will not happen without donations from people like you. 

    Follow Franconia Sculpture Park & Bedlam Theatre on Facebook for updates and information regarding the production.

    And, of course, please come see the show at Franconia Sculpture Park on September 4, 5, and 6th.

story:
Short Summary

Ever hear a song or an album and wonder "What was happening in that person's life when they wrote this?" Exploring that idea was the inspiration for writing team Amber Cassell & Kristy Hanson's passion project SING ME HOME.

A brand new, contemporary original musical, SING ME HOME tells the story of singer/songwriter Lexi Angel, a former teen idol who vanished mysteriously from the spotlight at the peak of her career, with no explanation as to why. Almost a decade later, Lexi resurfaces and steps back onto the stage, much to the media's delight and curiosity. But on the eve of Lexi's auspicious comeback concert, a face from her past appears in her dressing room in need of help. As Lexi embarks on this new phase of her career, the demands of her future and shadows of her past collide, taking Lexi on a hilarious and heartfelt journey to a place she’s never been before… home.

SING ME HOME has the honor of being selected to participate in the renowned New York Musical Theatre Festival (NYMF) this July, and will be offering TWO concert performances at the Laurie Beechman Theatre on July 20th & 21st. The remarkably talented singer/songwriter Kristy Hanson has written 13 fantastic songs for this piece, and the team is so humbled and thrilled to announce that Broadway stars MANDY GONZALEZ (Wicked, In the Heights, Aida...) and TELLY LEUNG (Godspell, Wicked, Rent...) will be performing them.

Participating in this festival is a tremendous honor and opportunity. NYMF is where Broadway favorites like [title of show] and the Pulitzer-Prize and Tony-winning NEXT TO NORMAL got their start. We are also so fortunate to have two of Broadway's finest lending their talents to this project, and our hope is that the exposure from these NYMF concerts will lead to full productions of SING ME HOME in the near future.

From the bottom of our hearts, thank you so much for all of your support and for helping us achieve what is absolutely a dream come true!

xoxo,

Kristy & Amber

What We Need

Unfortunately, as we all know, dreams aren't cheap and for a team of California girls putting on a show in the Big Apple, we are at a slight disadvantage compared to some of the other NYMF teams, who are based on the east coast.

Your contributions will help us with:

- Festival entrance and production fees

- Musicians

- Cast

- Travel and board

- Rehearsal studio rentals

- Playbills and printing


The Impact

**Please note that absolutely ZERO of your contributions will go towards a salary for the creative team, incidental expenditures, or with the intent of making a profit. This fundraising campaign is strictly to cover production costs.**

The exposure from this opportunity is our sole objective with these concerts and the hope that it will lead to future productions with reputable theater companies.

Risks & Challenges

Producing new musicals is a risky endeavor for any theatrical company, and companies are taking less and less chances on new musicals that aren't derived from stories with a familiar and popular track record (i.e.  the latest batch of [insert popular movie title] the Musicals). Our challenge is to prove that something completely new and original is worth taking a chance on and can gain traction with audiences. 

Part of our goal with these concerts is to present a catalog of songs that are versatile, contemporary, and stand on their own. These are songs you might hear on the radio and never know that they were written within the context of a book musical. It's just good music...sung by some of the most impressive voices you'll hear ANYWHERE.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word! Follow us at @SingMeHomeShow on Twitter, and like our FB page! Retweets, shares, emails, town criers and carrier pigeons are all very much appreciated!

Check out our cast, they're amazing! Give a listen to Kristy Hanson & Angela Parrish (our remarkable Musical Director & singer/songwriter extraordinare!) and go see them live!

Speaking of seeing things live, obviously you should come see us at NYMF on July 20th & 21st! Tickets go onsale here on June 16th: http://www.nymf.org/tickets/2014-events/sing-me-home/.

Can't make it to New York? Don't feel left out! We'll be doing a preview concert here in Los Angeles at Rockwell Table & Stage on July 13th, featuring a lineup of our favorite talents from the Broadway & L.A. music and theater scene!

And please, continue to support live music and live theater! There's truly nothing better.

story:
Not Your Grandpa's Strindberg.

An Eclectic New Company Brings to Life Forgotten Dramatic Work


Detroit Theatre Collective is now fundraising for a full-length theatre event, made up of three short plays by the great Swedish playwright, novelist and painter August Strindberg.

We are a small group of actors and directors originally from the Detroit area.  We've also studied, lived and worked in other cities but at some point have returned to metro Detroit in order to make a creative nest.  We are always looking for something bigger and more enticing in the theatre ... something that demonstrates why we were pulled into this world in the first place.  These plays do just that.

By helping us with a donation, you will put into motion a project that has been years in development.  You can make this process move!

But first, a bit about the inspiration ... 


lithograph by Edvard Munch, 1896

Born in 1849, JOHAN AUGUST STRINDBERG was a pioneer of both realism and dreamlike super-realism in the theatre. Often branded a misogynist, he was deeply troubled by the gender roles and taboos of his time. Surprisingly, he supported women's equality in ways such as having the vote and equal opportunity in education. 

He struggled with mental stability much of his life. This reached a climax during an infamous 'Inferno' period, when he experimented with the occult techniques of Franz Mesmer and Emmanuel Swedenborg (dabbling in hypnosis, psychic phenomena and alchemy - yes, he tried to make gold).

He was deeply intrigued by the workings of the Unconscious Mind.


The Town, painting by Strindberg 1903


So, Why Now?

Just after the 100th anniversary of his death, it is a fantastic time to rediscover this genius!  But milestones aside, why now, and why in Detroit?

Strindberg's great influence on American drama is well documented.  Eugene O' Neill gushed about him during much of his Nobel Prize speech in 1936: "For me, he remains . . . the Master, still to this day more modern than any of us, still our leader." 

"They call it love-hatred, and it hails from the pit" ... This Strindberg quote was found written in the back of one of Tennessee Williams school books as a young man, and one could say that such a vision of sexual torment is the driving force of his plays.

In other words, we would like to travel back to where it all started  ... with the intent of bringing Strindberg's theatrical vision to life.  We will also resurrect these plays anew, calling on our collective experience and the visual culture of the last 100 years.


Our Needs

The $4,000 we are raising will put this project into production - by reserving a performance venue in Detroit and allowing a budget to be created.  We are committed to making a streamlined theatre event without excess.

However, certain foundations must be provided for such as:

  • theater rental
  • rehearsal space
  • advertising
  • a quality production team
  • equipment costs

For a donation of $20.00 or more, you will receive ticket(s) to be used any time during the run of the show, as well as a thankful mention ... so you are really just purchasing your tickets in advance.  Any amount you're able to give is greatly appreciated!

You have our promise that your donation will go 100% toward creating a remarkable piece of theatre.  You will be helping a dream to be realized.

Our goal is to mount this production in the city of Detroit by Fall of 2014.  We will move into production as soon as we are financially able to do so.

The Process


THE BIG GRAVEL SIFTER


                  THE STRONGER


                                     PLAYING WITH FIRE

Three directors and an ensemble cast will join forces to mold these plays into a unified performance piece. This evening of theatre will combine dance, multimedia, storytelling, sexual tension, fiery drama and surprising comedy.

Over the last several months we've conducted workshops of these plays, exploring themes and circumstances while finding new ways to bring the stories to life.  Here is a glimpse at these sessions ...

Improvising on THE STRONGER  and  PLAYING WITH FIRE :



Group experiment for THE BIG GRAVEL SIFTER :

        (Actors using a video mirroring technique)


Fundraising for a production for the 2014-2015 theatre season.

Venue: To Be Announced


Detroit Theatre Collective is an ensemble dedicated to unearthing a new realism in the theatre - one that pushes our senses and perceptions and challenges how we experience the world through performance. We are excited to dive into this material for the official launch of the company. 

If you are unable to help out at this time with a donation, please consider passing the link to this page along to friends and family who may have an interest.  *Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools above*. 

Thanks a bunch!
