story:
Little Matchstick Factory’s
THE OTHER MOZART

Acclaimed by the New York Times as, "Strikingly beautiful", The Other Mozart is the true and untold story of Nannerl Mozart, the sister of Amadeus - a prodigy, keyboard virtuoso and composer, who performed throughout Europe with her brother to equal acclaim, but her work and her story faded away, lost to history.

After critically acclaimed Off-Broadway run in NYC last summer, and performances at theaters around the US and in Europe, we are thrilled to bring the play for a run of 10 performances at the New Orleans Fringe Festival - a fantastic festival in a city that is welcoming to extraordinary ghosts.

More than a one-woman show, it is a full production - and more than that, it is a mission: we believe that to introduce this other Mozart to people's minds is to inspire them, to bring women into the history of the great and to recognize the inequality that still exists today.

But, since it is an original production, with commissioned music, designed costumes and lighting, period choreography, original script and an acclaimed Off-Broadway run all financed by us and our IndieGogo nobility, we need your help in raising the necessary funds to make this festival possible.


WHAT IT ACTUALLY COSTS

Plane tickets - $320 x 2 people
Rental of the performance space/housing - $1,000
Festival fee: $250
Printing of fliers and posters: $150
------------------------
               = $2040

The good news: your donation is TAX DEDUCTIBLE (and look at the perks!)

The Other Mozart is the first project by Little Matchstick Factory - Sylvia Milo's and Nathan Davis' theater production company. Little Matchstick Factory is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Little Matchstick Factory must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Please share this campaign on your facebook, twitter, via email, etc.
https://www.facebook.com/TheOtherMozart
http://instagram.com/othermozart
https://twitter.com/NannerlOMozart
https://twitter.com/TheOtherMozart

And  come see the show in New Orleans!

PRESS

"Strikingly beautiful. ...excellent sound design... Ms. Milo’s Nannerl is charming and funny... Ms. Milo has a balletic grace, and it’s easy to imagine her slender hands at the keys of a clavichord." - New York Times

"The Big Stars of Experimental Theater" - The Wall Street Journal

"...fascinating and irresistibly intelligent... it is beautiful." - Theatermania

"The Other Mozart is the most dynamic, theatrical, and moving one woman show I have ever seen... If you love the art of the theatre, the history of music, the conflicts of gender roles, or the power of storytelling, you simply must see this production before it moves on to the next lucky city." - Theater is Easy

"One of the most remarkable theatrical presentations I saw in 2013... Sylvia Milo has brought off a tour de force in creating such an absorbing, intelligent, and sure-footed entertainment on such a subject... The costumes and hair are both seductive and disturbing... eloquent lighting... sophisticated and well-judged score... sureness of the direction... most brilliant and absorbing." - New York Arts

"Best Theatre of 2013" - Berkshire on Stage

"Beautiful? The word isn’t adequate. Unique? A cliché. Powerful? Immensely. Emotional? Deeply. Funny and fun. Sad and desperate... You’re witnessing the full force of a kind of synergy. A perfect storm. A rich combination of events and talents coming together, resulting in a performance of rare magnitude... So much brilliance in one night... only one thing left to say. BRAVO!" - Opelika-Auburn News

"Sylvia Milo’s luscious depiction... eschews the dreaded bio-adaptation problem – and it does so with class and evocative energy. ... elegantly minimalist production. ... graceful sophistication. ... a surprisingly deep and penetrating analysis of the life of Wolfgang’s older sister... She sometimes resembles the dancing girl in the center of a music box, an impression that’s underscored by Nathan Davis and Phyllis Chen’s tinkling score.” - Stage and Cinema

"Miss Milo is quite mesmerizing... She is also quite the vixen with a sharp sense of humor... Sylvia Milo is breathtakingly beguiling as Maria Anna." - Oscar E Moore


HISTORY

Sylvia Milo discovered the existence of Nannerl Mozart in 2006. She spent the next few years researching, writing, workshopping and gathering the extraordinary team.
The 18-foot dress was made, original music composed, lights, choreography and hair designed.
In March 2013 The Other Mozart had its first performance at the Smith Museum of Fine Art in Auburn, Alabama. From there the play was presented at various festivals in the US - Charleston’s Piccolo Spoleto, NYC’s All for One Theater Festival at the famous Cherry Lane Theater, the Berkshire Fringe Festival in Massachusetts (the play named “Best Theater of 2013” by Berkshire on Stage), et. al - and in Austria - at the Mozarthaus Sankt Gilgen, at the DIVA Monodrama Festival (under patronage of UNESCO) in Tux and at the Mozart Wohnhaus in Salzburg (at the invitation of the MOZARTEUM). In the summer of 2014 the play had it's critically acclaimed Off-Broadway run at HERE Arts Center in NYC. From there it traveled on to Munich, Estonia, and Salzburg again. In Kingston Sara Florence Fellini debuted in the role of Nannerl. In New Orleans both Sylvia Milo and Sara Florence Fellini will perform, alternating.

THE TEAM

We believe in this project with all our hearts.

Created and Written by: Sylvia Milo
Performed by Sylvia Milo or Sara Florence Fellini
Directed by: Isaac Byrne
Music composed by: Nathan Davis and Phyllis Chen
Additional music by: Marianna Martines and Wolfgang A. Mozart
Period Style Choreography by: Janice Orlandi
Costume by: Magdalena Dąbrowska and Miodrag Guberinic
Lighting design by: Joshua Rose
Hair styled by: Courtney Bednarowski

Please read more about our impressive team here: http://www.theothermozart.com/about

For more information please visit www.TheOtherMozart.com.

story:
Our Burlesque History 

The 85th year in Cleveland Burlesque History has seen great support for our ever so delightful artistic movement. To us, the Remarkable Memory Project represents the historical  commemoration of two of the most popular areas in the Cleveland of Yesteryear.   Please take a moment to watch our short video presentation which gives more detail to the importance and geographical location of the proposed Marker.

What We Need & What You Get

We need a Permanent Historical Marker and the means to maintain its beauty for future artists.  Your donation will see you get many one of a kind, unique and priceless rewards.  Including but absolutely not limited to ...

  • A Remarkable Memory Project T-shirt.
  • LeFemme Mystique Stickers.
  • Authentic Roxy Memorabilia.
  • VIP Admission to a Commemorative Burlesque Show.

The Impact

We will be the first State to have a marker of this nature in our state.  This marker represents the diverse and unique historical background here in Cleveland.  Here are some fun facts :-

  • Burlesque and Vaudeville played a very important part in entertainment history in the United States.  We want to remember those who came before us and give our future artists pride and ambition in their skill.

  • Short/Vincent was the very first entertainment district of Cleveland.  The history behind it is so interesting and unique and we wish to pay those Jazz Legends a lasting and meaningful tribute.

  • The Remarkable Memory Project has a team who have been curating for several years and the reality of this marker will come to fruition if you contribute to our campaign.

  • This year, Ohio Burlesque received not only a Scroll Of The City but also a Letter of Recognition from The Ohio State House of Representatives.  Cleveland is behind us.  Ohio is behind us.  Are YOU behind us?

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is ensuring that the Marker remains for future generations.  The Marker will require regular maintenance and a replacement should it be disrespectfully defaced, subject to vandalism or damaged it will cost $6200.00. We must fund excavation of the street and fund all necessary permits it will cost $2600.00 the $1200.00 left would be for maitanance, storage and emergacies. 

Ohio Burlesque being able to raise funds will assist covering costs for all City permits, excavation company and application fees.

Spread the word.  Share with your friends and family.  Be a part of something that your children and their children will be proud to say their loved ones helped create.

Please help us with the Remarkable Memory Project.  Cleveland and our amazing residents deserve to have the entertainment industry recognized for being as unique and special as our City.

Thank You So Much.

Ohio Burlesque

Our Burlesque History The 85th year in Cleveland Burlesque History has seen great support for our ever so delightful artistic movement. To us, the Remarkable Memory Project represents the historical  commemoration of two of the most popular areas in the Cleveland of Yesteryear.   Please take a moment to watch our short video presentation which gives more detail to the importance and geographical location of the proposed Marker.   What We Need & What You GetWe need a Permanent Historical Marker and the means to maintain its beauty for future artists.  Your donation will see you get many one of a kind, unique and priceless rewards.  Including but absolutely not limited to ... 
A Remarkable Memory Project T-shirt.
LeFemme Mystique Stickers.
 Authentic Roxy Memorabilia.
VIP Admission to a Commemorative Burlesque Show.
   The Impact We will be the first State to have a marker of this nature in our state.  This marker represents the diverse and unique historical background here in Cleveland.  Here are some fun facts :- 
Burlesque and Vaudeville played a very important part in entertainment history in the United States.  We want to remember those who came before us and give our future artists pride and ambition in their skill.

Short/Vincent was the very first entertainment district of Cleveland.  The history behind it is so interesting and unique and we wish to pay those Jazz Legends a lasting and meaningful tribute.

The Remarkable Memory Project has a team who have been curating for 
several years and the reality of this marker will come to fruition if 
you contribute to our campaign. 
 This year, Ohio Burlesque received not only a Scroll Of The City but also a Letter of Recognition from The Ohio State House of Representatives.  Cleveland is behind us.  Ohio is behind us.  Are YOU behind us?

  Risks & Challenges Our biggest challenge is ensuring that the Marker remains for future generations.  The Marker will require regular maintenance and a replacement should it be disrespectfully defaced, subject to vandalism or damaged it will cost $6200.00. We must fund excavation of the street and fund all necessary permits it will cost $2600.00 the $1200.00 left would be for maitanance, storage and emergacies. Ohio Burlesque being able to raise funds will assist covering costs for all City permits, excavation company and application fees.Spread the word.  Share with your friends and family.  Be a part of something that your children and their children will be proud to say their loved ones helped create.Please help us with the Remarkable Memory Project.  Cleveland and our amazing residents deserve to have the entertainment industry recognized for being as unique and special as our City.Thank You So Much.Ohio Burlesque

story:
Spread Laughter Across The World

  • My name is Jayson "Avocado" Acevedo and I'm an up and coming stand up/improvisational comedian from the beautiful city of Chicago.
  • I recently just turned 21 but knew from the age of 6 that I wanted to be making people laugh for the rest of my life.
  • At just 21, I was given the opportunity to showcase my talents in the beautiful city of Paris, France. 
  • I'm still 21, and a new opportunity has come up! I've been invited to perform at the world's largest arts festival: The Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland!
  • Getting to perform at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival would be another milestone in my young comedic career. With this experience comes the opportunity to learn, create, reflect, love, and enjoy on an international level!

Join Team Avocado: What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Funding will go towards: purchasing the round-trip flight to Scotland, hotel accommodations, and other travel expenses (more importantly food).
  • If you give, you will receive. Perks include: a unique Instagram Shoutout (video or photo), a signed avocado, a 1:00 minute song about you from me using the only instrument I know how to play: my mouth or a Skype session live from Scotland!

    The Impact

    • Help me grow as a comedian by taking my comedy to parts of the world I never thought possible.
    • Help me spread the art I pour my heart and soul into in order to hear someone laugh and to help every audience momentarily forget all the unpleasantness that life has to offer.
    • Help me take over Scotland!

    Support Team Avocado (I Need You Either Way)

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, and E-Mail (Do people still use that?)
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
About this project

ATV is the first Chinese TV station in the world. The ATV Miss Asia Pageant has also been around for 30 years and it’s one of the biggest international pageants in the world, drawing contestants from over 20 different Asian countries. This year we had the honor to bring this pageant to Boston! 

We are ATV Miss Asia Pageant Boston, a regional competition for the largest pageant in Asia. We aim to cultivate independent, caring, elegant and confident female Asian leaders in the community.

Last year, our ATV Miss Asia Pageant US East Coast was very successful. Contestants went through months of intensive training and were very closely involved with bringing positive impacts to events in the community. Contestants not only learned how to stand in 6-inch heels, how to walk, sit, smile and speak and interview in front of a camera, they also worked closely with the NYPD to promote traffic safety to the public.

This summer in Boston, contestants are participating in various community service projects to bring measurable positive impacts to the community. In the Acadia National Park project, we volunteered for two days to help maintain the environment for future sustainable tourism.

We believe young ladies should not only be judged based on their outside looks or inside kindness, they should be respected as strong, persistent and responsible contributors to the society!

To ensure fair selection, there is no entry fee nor training costs to applicants to this pageant. During the pageant competition, contestants will go through 5 different rounds of speeches, talents and performances, and the top 3 contestants will have the opportunity to go to the next competition. All funding from Indiegogo will go into the expenses of this pageant, including our grand final location renting costs and event costs. Your support of any amount is greatly appreciated!

story:
Hi, my name is Alexander Paris and I'm a playwright living in Brooklyn, NY. I'm a Virgo with a Cancer stellium in my moon, venus, and mars. (which in short, means I'm super emotional.) Cancer Cancer Cancer is my brand new play which is also my first ever full length production. We've assembled a super talented and amazing group of people to put this show up for ANT Fest at Ars Nova (511 W 54th St, NY) on June 25th at 7pm. 

Our Crew: Written by Alexander Paris. Directed by Michael Leibenluft. Produced by Bailey Williams. Stage Managed by Krista Jarboe. Sound Design by Peter Mills Weiss. Lighting Design by Kate McGee. Scenic Design by Joo Kim.

Our Cast: Jamar Williams*, Gregory Georges, Issa Best, Starr Busby, Liba Vaynberg*, and Patrick Reilly*

ANT Fest is Ars Nova's annual, month-long celebration of All New Talent, when New York City's premier hub for emerging artists throws open its door to a wide variety of artists to present dozens of cutting edge music, theater, and comedy shows, with a focus on blurring the boundaries between them. Out of hundreds of projects submitted, Ars Nova has selected 28 shows (INCLUDING THIS ONE!) for a jam-packed month filled with New York's most exciting emerging talent! Over the last ten years, ANT Fest has become known throughout the industry as a key stop to discover new talent, and several recent Off-Broadway productions including Underground Railroad Game, The Woodsman and Eager to Lose were all born out of ANT Fest productions. Being a part of ANT Fest is a SUPER BIG DEAL and we want to create the best show possible while being able to honor the great contribution that our performers and team members put into making this show. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $4500 for this show! Over 60% of the funds will go towards ensuring that all actors are paid for their time, and that all team members (our various designers, stage manager, producer, director, and the playwright) will get compensated for the hours they poured into this production. The rest of the money will go towards the design of the show and its posterity (a nice video recording and photography of the performance), as well as incidentals like transportation, script printing, etc.
  • We don't have super crazy perks because we are trying to operate at minimum overhead, but we want to make sure you are thanked for your contribution! I'm a pretty decent visual artist along with being a playwright, and I'll be happy to draw your pretty faces, post them on social media, and send them to you. I also believe that it's important for this work to be seen by those who can't be present for our single evening of presentation, so a $100 contribution will get you a digital copy of the show once it's been edited nicely by our videographer.
  • If we don't reach our goal for funds, the money we made will be divided among all team members who worked on the production.

The Impact

  • I could not imagine that a play I've worked on could get this sort of traction and attention this early on in my career. I'm truly humbled to be a part of Ars Nova's All New Talent Festival, and I want to make this production as good as it can be.
  • Supporting this production ensures that it will get up on its feet and be seen by a lot of people, some of which may be deeply affected by it personally, some which will want to provide more opportunities for the actors involved, and some which may have interest in giving the production a longer life somewhere else.

Risks & Challenges

  • Producing a show is nearly always a risk, but we have plans in place for our worst case scenarios. There is a contingency fund built into the budget and it is our highest priority that money goes first to personnel, then to design. The show will happen no matter what, and I have an experienced and dedicated team behind me to help it along the way. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't afford to support this show financially, that's totally okay! I understand and have been there too (in fact I'm still there.) But if you still want to support it, feel free to spread the word about it! Let people know it's happening by sharing this campaign or info about the show via Facebook, Instagram, or here on Indiegogo.

Overall, this play is my first big venture into theater! It's the first time I've presented a full length and the first time that I have worked with this many people on a production. I want to honor them for their time and commitment to me and this production, and we want to honor you by making it the best show possible for its first time on its feet.

story:
We Need Your Help!

After performing our 2nd Workshop Production of "The Afflicted" Off-Off Broadway in New York City at the Access Theater's Gallery this June 7-16th, The Wandering Theatre Company will be taking this new piece down to our nation's capital!  The US Premiere of “The Afflicted” will be presented as part of the 2013 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe.

We need your help to raise enough money to make this dream a reality! It is a huge honor for us to be able to perform in this festival and share our art with both NYC & D.C audiences. We are hoping to raise $8,000 to cover a variety of expenses, which are listed in detail below.

By contributing even just $5, your donation will make a tremendous difference and help to make “The Afflicted” a success at this year's Capital Fringe Festival.

Who is the Wandering Theatre Company & What is “The Afflicted”

The Wandering Theatre Company is a collection of American theatre artists dedicated to creating and sharing ensemble theatre with the world. We are a new company that came together in April of 2012 and have since been on a journey to create a new theatrical piece.  

In our pursuit of creating a strong American theatrical identity we chose to focus on an important unsolved event in American history, The Salem Witch Trials.  "The Afflicted" is a contemporary exploration of the accusing girls of the Salem Witch Trials. Not quite history yet not completely fantasy, this piece of theatre examines the internal psychology of confinement, fear, hysteria, female oppression and religious extremism. 

In August of 2012, we welcomed audiences to see the very first workshop production of "The Afflicted" Off-Off Broadway at the 133rd Street Art Center.  We have since re-vamped our script, further developed characters and are ready to return Off-Off Broadway for our second workshop production this June 7-16th at the Access Theater in their beautiful Gallery Space.

The new cast includes Becky Baker, Caitlin Berger, Josh Bubar, Claudia Givings, Joelle Golda, Laura Kiser, Roni Laytin, Libby McKnight, Rin Olsson and Adriana Spizuoco.

The Wandering Theatre Company wants to invite audience members to be a part of this creation, by inviting them to see the second workshop production of "The Afflicted" Off- Off Broadway this June, running the 7-16th at the Access Theater in NYC!  Tickets on sale now at http://www.smarttix.com/Show.aspx?ShowCode=AFF1

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to bring this amazing piece of theater to DC! Any contribution great or small truly helps us a great deal.  Please keep in mind that we are a HUGE ensemble of actors, 11 total, plus we have our creative team that will be running the show once we get down to D.C.

Here is a breakdown of how your donations will be used

      $700 - Travel to D.C
      $1,000 - Set
      $3,200 - Artist Compensation
      $300 - Transportation while in D.C
      $700 - Advertising
      $1,000 - Programs & Postcards
      $300 - Additional Costumes
      $800 - Rehearsal Space
            Total: $8,000

We have created some AMAZING perks for your donations, including:

-Personalized thank you notes from the cast and creative team

-Shout-outs on our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram accounts

-Posters of “The Afflicted” signed by the cast and creative team

-Wandering Theatre Company tote bags and t-shirts

-Tickets to “The Afflicted” this June 7-16th at the Access Theater

-Invitations to Viewpoints workshops with the cast

-Invitations to “The Afflicted” Opening Night Gala

-Producer credit

-4 lucky donors will be able to take a piece of "The Afflicted" home with them! We are giving away our set pieces, four Japanese Maple Trees!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute right now? We understand, and have no fear- there are still other ways you can help us achieve our goal!

First and foremost, please come check out “The Afflicted” this June 7-16th at the Access Theater in NYC!! Tickets on sale now at www.smarttix.com

Another great way to contribute is by sharing this campaign and urging your friends and family that can contribute to check us out and open their hearts to new artists.  

Please, please, please use the Indiegogo share tools, post our campaign on your Facebook, tweet about us and email your friends a link to this page. We need all the support we can get! 

Like us on Facebook

Follow us on Twitter

Follow us on Instagram

Follow us on Tumblr

Subscribe to us on YouTube

story:
Ballet East

Ballet East (BE), formally Susan Lyle Studios, under the artistic direction of Chelsea Nasby has been a professional dance training institution for the past 43 years. Program graduates have continued their training with The Juilliard School, Boston Conservatory, SUNY Purchase, The University of the Arts (UARTS), Marymount Manhattan, The Ailey School, Florida State University, Joffrey Ballet and Cirque du Soleil to name a few. Our goal is to offer the highest quality of dance training to prepare children for professional opportunities. Students that are selected for the Pre-Professional program are trained thoroughly in technical ballet classes on a daily basis. The accelerated ballet training is reinforced through structured Modern, Contemporary, Jazz, Acrobatics and Tap classes that assist in the development of movement quality and dynamics.

Ballet East Mission Statement

Our mission is to provide the highest quality of dance education through an accelerated training program. Ballet East seeks to produce students with superior artistic qualifications to enhance future employment and to enrich the cultural growth of our community.

Ballet East Vision Statement

Ballet East aims to be one of the best training facilities in America. Students are trained by the highest quality of dance educators and professional productions seek to educate dancers and audiences alike.

Ballet East Contact Information

2365 Vista Parkway Ste 7 WPB, FL 33411 -  www.BalletEastFL.com - 561.966.3650

We need your help!

Each year Ballet East raises funds to help purchase ballet tutus needed for school productions, performances in the community and variations for competitions that require a professionally made tutu. Tutus range in price from $500-$800 per costume. The purchase price of the costume includes material, construction and adornments of the bodice and tutu. Accessories such as tiaras are purchased or made as well. The financial expense associated with tutus can be overwhelming for students and parents that are have the honor of performing these roles.

Tutus used in the event of a production or variation are made for a specific role or character. Classical ballets call for certain types of costumes. For instance, Sleeping Beauty calls for Princess Aurora to wear a pale colored classical tutu adorned with crystals, beads and a tiara to make her royal role come to life. We strive to provide students with opportunity to wear professionally made costumes that will be maintained and preserved for Ballet East's future generations. BE is therefore striving to expand our costume inventory for current and future students of the school!

The Impact

BE Tutus for Ballerinas Campaign is important to continue to provide our professional semiannual productions, provide students with the opportunity to perform classical repertoire/variations for prestigious ballet competitions and to perform in the community. A professionally made tutu gives students the opportunity to feel like a beautiful ballerina should. To watch the young students admire and attempt to emulate older students is a gift that is truly rewarding. Pointe shoes and magnificent tutus are what every ballerina strives to have in their future!  

(Below: Student Sophie I. playing the role of the caged Peacock at home, the blue bin acting as her cage. Aspen B. played the role of the Peacock in the 2013 Production of Arabian Nights. We know where to find the student to do this role in the future!)

(Below: Carley A. in a classical tutu used for the role of Princess Jasmine, Arabian Nights 2013 Production. A BE student preforming a variation from the ballet of La Bayadere or Le Corsaire will wear this tutu for the 2014 Grand Prix and American Dance Competition)

Other Ways You Can Contribute

If you are unable to contribute in the form of donations, please spread the word! Here are some ways you can help:

  • Please spread the word to BE families and friends
  • Please utilize the Indiegogo share tools to share via social media (Facebook, Twitter, Emailing, etc)

Thank you in advance for your support. BE faculty and the students of the school sincerely appreciate you helping shape our future!

We need your help!

Each year Ballet East raises funds to help purchase ballet tutus needed for school productions, performances in the community and variations for competitions that require a professionally made tutu. Tutus range in price from $500-$800 per costume. The purchase price of the costume includes material, construction and adornments of the bodice and tutu. Accessories such as tiaras are purchased or made as well. The financial expense associated with tutus can be overwhelming for students and parents that are have the honor of performing these roles.Tutus used in the event of a production or variation are made for a specific role or character. Classical ballets call for certain types of costumes. For instance, Sleeping Beauty calls for Princess Aurora to wear a pale colored classical tutu adorned with crystals, beads and a tiara to make her royal role come to life. We strive to provide students with opportunity to wear professionally made costumes that will be maintained and preserved for Ballet East's future generations. BE is therefore striving to expand our costume inventory for current and future students of the school!The ImpactBE Tutus for Ballerinas Campaign is important to continue to provide our professional semiannual productions, provide students with the opportunity to perform classical repertoire/variations for prestigious ballet competitions and to perform in the community. A professionally made tutu gives students the opportunity to feel like a beautiful ballerina should. To watch the young students admire and attempt to emulate older students is a gift that is truly rewarding. Pointe shoes and magnificent tutus are what every ballerina strives to have in their future!   
(Below: Student Sophie I. playing the role of the caged Peacock at home, the blue bin acting as her cage. Aspen B. played the role of the Peacock in the 2013 Production of Arabian Nights. We know where to find the student to do this role in the future!)


(Below: Carley A. in a classical tutu used for the role of Princess Jasmine, Arabian Nights 2013 Production. A BE student preforming a variation from the ballet of La Bayadere or Le Corsaire will wear this tutu for the 2014 Grand Prix and American Dance Competition) 

Other Ways You Can Contribute
If you are unable to contribute in the form of donations, please spread the word! Here are some ways you can help:

Please spread the word to BE families and friends

Please utilize the Indiegogo share tools to share via social media (Facebook, Twitter, Emailing, etc)

Thank you in advance for your support. BE faculty and the students of the school sincerely appreciate you helping shape our future!

story:
Short Summary

I'm Kate Leggett and I am the producer for the Jewish Theatre Ensemble's production of The Diary of Anne Frank at Northwestern University. The director and I fell in love with the script when we read it last spring and knew that we were presented with a very special opportunity. Since then, we have compiled a production team and cast currently include over forty incredibly talented Northwestern undergraduates from all different ages and academic disciplines. We are endlessly humbled by Anne's words and are both excited and honored to be bring her story to campus this winter. 

What We Need & What You Get

Because of the unique challenges of staging an adaptation of a nonfiction period piece, we find ourselves with a budget that is slightly higher than normal student theatre productions. The price of components such as historical costumes and period props tend to run higher. Furthermore, because the play is entrenched in a sense of realism and we are committed to retelling Anne's story in the most honest way possible, one of our main goals is to recreate the infamous attic in which Anne lived for two years. These costs tend to add up and, because the Jewish Theatre Ensemble is a student-run non-profit, we look to generous donors to help fund our show and cut production costs. 

Any contribution that you can give would be deeply appreciated and would directly support the show. All donations are recognizes in our program, unless anonymity is preferred: a Donor contributes $60 or less, a Patron $61-$150, and a Benefactor donates $150 or more. Also, if you have a student you would like to leave a note for in our program, please contact me at katherineleggett2016@u.northwestern.edu for more information!

The Impact

The Diary of Anne Frank is the story of a family united under the most terrible circumstances. It is a story of perseverance, of hope, and most importantly, of faith. We are endlessly captivated and humbled by Anne’s wisdom and ability to find light in the darkest of circumstances. In honoring Anne’s story, we are dedicated to staging the play in the most honest way possible. We feel both capable and excited to take all of this on, but we need help from our friends to make it possible. Our production is designed, directed, produced, and performed entirely by Northwestern undergraduates. As a fully functioning theatre company, JTE relies heavily on the charity of others to produce high quality productions. By donating to our production, you are helping to not only keep Anne's memory alive, but also helping to remind the world of the importance of tolerance, hope, and faith. 

Other Ways to Get Involved

Join us for one of our performances! We are incredibly excited to be going up in Northwestern's Shanley Pavilion this winter and will be having performances from February 27-March 1. 

Contact Kate Leggett at katherineleggett2016@u.northwestern.edu to reserve tickets today!

story:
Celebrate with us!

"Estado Ingravitto" will be presented as an excerpt of a potentially larger production, based heavily on the Mexican traditional holiday, "Dia De Los Muertos (Day of the Dead)." Showcasing the stories of characters such as La Reina, La Flor, Viento and many more, allow us to take you through a journey, transcending time and the unknown variable of our afterlife.

    Our Vision

    This production will not only educate the audience on the Mexican holiday traditions, but engage those present into a story unlike any other. Through the brilliant works of well-known international choreographer, Ashlé Dawson, "Estado Ingravitto" is an eclectic piece of universal art, guaranteed to leave you awe-inspired and wanting more.

    What We Ask Of You...

    • Donations reaching $1500 or more, covering budget costs (rehearsal/performance space, costumes & make-up)
    • Any additional donations will go towards the future, full-length production

    Interested in More?

    Keep up with us on Facebook at Breaking Conformity Productions, Inc.!

    https://www.facebook.com/pages/Breaking-Conform...

story:
Vuoi fare un regalo originale e non sai cosa fare? Seleziona una dedica (perk) e gli attori dei Naufraghi inversi la realizzeranno per te! La Divina Commedia è piena di passi celebri che parlano d’amore (Paolo e Francesca) di coraggio e sfide da affrontare (Ulisse) ecc. ecc,. con cui potrai celebrare occasioni di ogni tipo. I Naufraghi InVersi reciteranno il brano che avrai scelto e te lo invieranno con la dedica che avrai pensato per la persona a cui vorrai donarlo. Un modo originale e “unico”  per fare un regalo di valore, contribuendo nel contempo a una buona causa: il progetto ItinerDante – Italian Street Tour.
 

 Dedica 33 versi alla persona che desideri! Reciteremo per lei i versi da te scelti! 


 

----------------------
 

Qualsiasi sia la selva, l'essenziale è ritrovare la via. 

 

Per celebrare il 700esimo anniversario della morte del sommo poeta abbiamo dato vita a «ItinerDante - Italian Street Tour», un’iniziativa che porterà i canti dell’Inferno dantesco in performance itineranti per le regioni italiane. Scopo del progetto è quello di coinvolgere il maggior numero di persone possibili per riscoprire, insieme, i fondamenti della nostra cultura. Per farlo, attraverseremo l’Italia in un percorso lungo 700 km che coinvolgerà città, piccoli comuni, località turistiche e «luoghi danteschi». Sarà un modo per celebrare i tesori del Bel Paese con la più importante opera letteraria di tutti i tempi, ma anche un’occasione per riflettere, collettivamente, sulla nostra umanità al tempo del Covid.


Attraverso la declamazione dei canti danteschi in versione originale e in italiano attuale, le nostre performance di piazza consentono, infatti, di riscoprire tutta l’attualità della Divina Commedia che, parlando dei vizi e delle aree oscure dell’animo umano, parla di tutti noi e della società di oggi, sollecitandoci a ripensare le nostre vite per tornare, tutti insieme dopo la pandemia, “a riveder le stelle”.
 


 

Lo Street Tour di ItinerDante ha raccolto l'interesse di numerose realtà culturali nazionali e ottenuto il patrocinio dell'Associazione Italianisti - Gruppo Dante, la Società Dante Alighieri, dell'Hypermedia Dante Network e dell'ENAC (Ente Nazionale Attività Culturali).
Hanno già parlato di noi (tra l’altro):

  • Vogue
  • ilSole24Ore
  • La Repubblica
  • IoDonna

Qui puoi trovare la rassegna stampa completa.
 


 

Perché sostenerci

Per darci una mano a portare i canti di Dante e le riflessioni che esse sollecitano nel maggior numero di piazze italiane. Più persone potremo coinvolgere, più emozioni riusciremo a generare, più grande sarà il contributo che riusciremo a dare (nel nostro piccolo) alla ripresa culturale del nostro Paese dopo i mesi bui della pandemia. Il progetto non ha fini di lucro e il viaggio (700 chilometri in 7 regioni italiane) sarà per noi impegnativo in tutti i sensi. Col il tuo aiuto puoi aggiungere “benzina” al progetto e allungare il nostro percorso per l’Italia. Noi ci impegniamo a viaggiare finché avremo benzina. Nel momento in cui finirà torneremo a casa.  
 

 

Cosa ti offriamo

Abbiamo pensato a dei regali-premi di ringraziamento personalizzati. Si parte da una foto digitale autografata, passiamo alla locandina dell'evento e si arriva fino a una traccia audio con uno spezzone di Canto della Divina a tua scelta e con dedica personalizzata.
Insomma, mica pizza e fichi. 

 

Il tuo aiuto 

Per il momento abbiamo già alcune tappe programmate per il nostro tour, ad esempio: 

  • Milano - Lombardia
  • Dervio - Lombardia
  • Torri del Benaco - Veneto 
  • Ravenna - Emilia Romagna
  • Bagnacavallo - Emilia Romagna
  • Poppi - Toscana
  • Castagneto Carducci - Toscana
  • Piombino - Toscana
  • Roma - Lazio
  • Assisi - Umbria 
  • Volterra - Umbria
  • Policoro - Basilicata
  • Accadia - Puglia 

 

► Consulta QUI tutte le date del tour!

Grazie al tuo supporto, saremo in grado di continuare il tour verso nuove mete, allacciarci la cintura, mettere in moto e partire alla conquista di città, capoluoghi e regioni! 

La lunghezza del nostro percorso è nella nostra volontà di non arrenderci, nei chilometri di strade asfaltate (e non) che percorreremo, nelle vie assolate in cui reciteremo e nelle tue mani che ci aiuteranno a camminare più lontano. 
 

 

Rischi e Sfide

Portare avanti un progetto culturale è sempre impegnativo, in questo periodo di pandemia ci è stato detto che siamo coraggiosi a provarci (e forse un po' incoscienti?).

Vogliamo essere sinceri con te e ti assicuriamo che il progetto lo realizzeremo, a prescindere dagli aiuti che riceveremo. La differenza? Faremo meno tappe, meno chilometri percorsi con il nostro furgoncino (affittato), meno persone incontrate (tra cui, magari, anche te). Aiutaci, quindi, a rendere ItinerDante un progetto di portata nazionale e un piccolo passo per tornare "a riveder le stelle".
 

 

Altri modi in cui puoi aiutarci

Lo scopo del progetto è generare momenti di commozione, riflessioni ed esperienze di valore collettivi grazie ai versi della Divina Commedia. Lo faremo nelle piazze e per le vie dei borghi e delle città Italiane per tutte le persone che vorranno assistere, gratuitamente, ai nostri spettacoli di piazza. Ma possiamo anche personalizzare le nostre performance e farle, su richiesta, proprio per te! Sempre per aiutare la nostra causa e consentirci di fare qualche chilometro in più, puoi donare un brano a tua scelta dedicandolo alla persona che vorrai!

E ancora! Se sei un “vip” ? e vuoi realizzare un momento “Divino” tutto tuo, e puoi permettertelo, i Naufraghi Inversi possono mettere in scena, solo per te e per le persone che vorrai invitare, uno spettacolo riservato e personalizzato. Il format messo a punto dalla compagnia consente di generare rappresentazioni in spazi di qualsiasi tipo e dimensioni (nel rispetto delle norme di distanziamento Covid19). Basta chiedere!

 

 

Non puoi donare? Non ti preoccupare, capiamo perfettamente che potrebbe essere un periodo duro anche per te.

Puoi darci una mano in altri modi:

  • Condividi questa iniziativa con amici e parenti utilizzando i bottoni di condivisione di Indiegogo
  • Seguici sui nostri social: INSTAGRAM e FACEBOOK
  • Segui le nostre live settimanali su TWITCH! 

Te ne saremmo grati :)

 

 

Chi Siamo 

I Naufraghi Inversi sono un'Associazione Culturale nata oltre 6 anni fa con l'intento di portare la Divina Commedia nuovamente a una dimensione popolare. 
Dante ha parlato della vita dopo la morte perché sognava di rendere migliori gli uomini in questa vita. Ecco perché scrisse la Divina Commedia in volgare: per renderla comprensibile a un pubblico ampio e «di massa». Utilizzando la metafora del passaggio attraverso gli inferi, voleva far riflettere l’umanità sui propri vizi e i propri peccati, affinché ritrovasse il sentiero che l’avrebbe condotta a essere un’umanità migliore.

Mossi dallo stesso desiderio, i Naufraghi Inversi utilizzano i canti danteschi per rileggere la contemporaneità, anche nei risvolti drammatici di questo ultimo anno, dimostrando tutta l’attualità della Divina Commedia che, dopo 700 anni, si rivela ancora in grado di restituire una fotografia più che realistica del mondo che ci circonda.
 

 

Membri del Team

Eugenio di Fraia - Co-fondatore, Attore
Diplomato al corso di Recitazione al Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia di Roma. Tra i lavori che l’hanno visto impegnato come attore "L'Amica Geniale" di Daniele Luchetti, "Trust" di Danny Boyle, "Fedeltà" (serie Netflix), per un anno primo attore nello spettacolo "Giudizio Universale", creato da Marco Balich con i Musei Vaticani.
Da sempre appassionato di Dante e della Divina Commedia decide di fondare più di 8 anni fa, insieme a Riccardo Sozzi, l’Associazione Culturale “Naufraghi Inversi” con l’intento di diffondere la sua passione per i versi danteschi al grande pubblico.

Riccardo Sozzi - Co-fondatore
Da sempre appassionato di letteratura e teatro è fondatore di due Associazioni Culturali attive in questo ambito. Insieme a Eugenio di Fraia è il creatore del concept “Siamo Inferno” e del tour “ItinerDante”. Laurea magistrale in Digital Marketing Management attualmente ricopre il ruolo di Analytics Specialist presso una delle agenzie più rinomate d’Italia nell’ambito della data analysis digitale. 

Angelo Marrone - Musicista
Orchestrazioni virtuali, trascrizione di spartiti, concerti, lezioni, produzioni audio, uso di software di riproduzione musicale. Laurea specialistica di II livello presso il Conservatorio “L. Cherubini” di Firenze in Musica e Nuove Tecnologie, premiato al Los Angeles Cinefest.

Maria Vittoria Casarotti Todeschini - Attrice, Writer
Diplomata al corso di Recitazione al Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia di Roma. Si avvicina alla recitazione attraverso i Musical grazie alla sua passione per la musica e il canto. Fu una delle protagoniste principali in due film sul secondo dopoguerra italiano, Il Segreto d’Italia (regia di Antonello Bellucco) e Terra Rossa (regia di Giorgio Molteni). Attualmente ricopre un ruolo nella serie TV su Canale 5 Svegliati Amore mio (regia Simona Izzo e Ricky Tognazzi).

Roberta Blarasin - Costumista e Performer
Esteta del contenuto, si occupa di costumi per cinema, TV, videoclip, web e teatro, principalmente a Roma. Occasionalmente anche performer, coreografa, truccatrice, asseconda qualsiasi necessità creativa.

Nicoletta Senzacqua - Writer
Nata a Roma il 9 settembre 1991 ha da sempre adorato scrivere. terminati i 3 livelli di narrativa della Scuola di Scrittura Omero, si diploma al Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia in Sceneggiatura. Il suo cortometraggio di diploma "Così in terra" è stato selezionato al Festival di Cannes Cinéfondation e al Festival di Venezia - I Love GAI, oltre decine di candidature in festival nazionali e internazionali, vincendo il premio come miglior sceneggiatura al Phealgrean Festival. Finalista al premio Rodolfo Sonego per la sceneggiatura di "Sailor Girls" e finalista al Premio Franco Solinas 2017 con il soggetto e la sceneggiatura "Lo scambio equivalente". Sceneggiatrice per il documentario in produzione "Dimenticata Militanza: un ritratto politico di Gian Maria Volontè" e autrice con la compagnia Naufraghi inversi dello spettacolo "In battello con Dante" oltre che professoressa di sceneggiatura presso il Liceo Banzi di Lecce.

Pietro Federico - Writer
Scrittore e traduttore. Laureato in lettere classiche con un master in sceneggiatura e produzione cinematografica. È copy e script writer in campo pubblicitario e story editor per sceneggiatori televisivi e scrittori. Scrive racconti e poesie, ricevendo riconoscimenti nell’ambito di premi nazionali e internazionali (Premio Raduga, premio Antonio Fogazzaro, premio Città di Pistoia, Premio Subiaco). Nel 2020 è uscita la sua raccolta di poesie "La maggioranza delle stelle" (Ensemble editore - 2020)

 

Patrocini

  • Associazione Italianisti - Gruppo Dante
  • Società Dante Alighieri
  • Hypermedia Dante Network
  • ENAC

E ancora! Se sei un “vip” ? e vuoi realizzare un momento “Divino” tutto tuo, e puoi permettertelo, i Naufraghi Inversi possono mettere in scena, solo per te e per le persone che vorrai invitare, uno spettacolo riservato e personalizzato. Il format messo a punto dalla compagnia consente di generare rappresentazioni in spazi di qualsiasi tipo e dimensioni (nel rispetto delle norme di distanziamento Covid19). Basta chiedere!
 

 
Non puoi donare? Non ti preoccupare, capiamo perfettamente che potrebbe essere un periodo duro anche per te.
Puoi darci una mano in altri modi:


Condividi questa iniziativa con amici e parenti utilizzando i bottoni di condivisione di Indiegogo
Seguici sui nostri social: INSTAGRAM e FACEBOOK

Segui le nostre live settimanali su TWITCH! 

Te ne saremmo grati :)
 

 
Chi Siamo 
I Naufraghi Inversi sono un'Associazione Culturale nata oltre 6 anni fa con l'intento di portare la Divina Commedia nuovamente a una dimensione popolare. Dante ha parlato della vita dopo la morte perché sognava di rendere migliori gli uomini in questa vita. Ecco perché scrisse la Divina Commedia in volgare: per renderla comprensibile a un pubblico ampio e «di massa». Utilizzando la metafora del passaggio attraverso gli inferi, voleva far riflettere l’umanità sui propri vizi e i propri peccati, affinché ritrovasse il sentiero che l’avrebbe condotta a essere un’umanità migliore.
Mossi dallo stesso desiderio, i Naufraghi Inversi utilizzano i canti danteschi per rileggere la contemporaneità, anche nei risvolti drammatici di questo ultimo anno, dimostrando tutta l’attualità della Divina Commedia che, dopo 700 anni, si rivela ancora in grado di restituire una fotografia più che realistica del mondo che ci circonda. 

 
Membri del Team
Eugenio di Fraia - Co-fondatore, AttoreDiplomato al corso di Recitazione al Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia di Roma. Tra i lavori che l’hanno visto impegnato come attore "L'Amica Geniale" di Daniele Luchetti, "Trust" di Danny Boyle, "Fedeltà" (serie Netflix), per un anno primo attore nello spettacolo "Giudizio Universale", creato da Marco Balich con i Musei Vaticani.Da sempre appassionato di Dante e della Divina Commedia decide di fondare più di 8 anni fa, insieme a Riccardo Sozzi, l’Associazione Culturale “Naufraghi Inversi” con l’intento di diffondere la sua passione per i versi danteschi al grande pubblico.
Riccardo Sozzi - Co-fondatoreDa sempre appassionato di letteratura e teatro è fondatore di due Associazioni Culturali attive in questo ambito. Insieme a Eugenio di Fraia è il creatore del concept “Siamo Inferno” e del tour “ItinerDante”. Laurea magistrale in Digital Marketing Management attualmente ricopre il ruolo di Analytics Specialist presso una delle agenzie più rinomate d’Italia nell’ambito della data analysis digitale. 
Angelo Marrone - MusicistaOrchestrazioni virtuali, trascrizione di spartiti, concerti, lezioni, produzioni audio, uso di software di riproduzione musicale. Laurea specialistica di II livello presso il Conservatorio “L. Cherubini” di Firenze in Musica e Nuove Tecnologie, premiato al Los Angeles Cinefest.
Maria Vittoria Casarotti Todeschini - Attrice, WriterDiplomata al corso di Recitazione al Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia di Roma. Si avvicina alla recitazione attraverso i Musical grazie alla sua passione per la musica e il canto. Fu una delle protagoniste principali in due film sul secondo dopoguerra italiano, Il Segreto d’Italia (regia di Antonello Bellucco) e Terra Rossa (regia di Giorgio Molteni). Attualmente ricopre un ruolo nella serie TV su Canale 5 Svegliati Amore mio (regia Simona Izzo e Ricky Tognazzi).
Roberta Blarasin - Costumista e PerformerEsteta del contenuto, si occupa di costumi per cinema, TV, videoclip, web e teatro, principalmente a Roma. Occasionalmente anche performer, coreografa, truccatrice, asseconda qualsiasi necessità creativa.
Nicoletta Senzacqua - WriterNata a Roma il 9 settembre 1991 ha da sempre adorato scrivere. terminati i 3 livelli di narrativa della Scuola di Scrittura Omero, si diploma al Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia in Sceneggiatura. Il suo cortometraggio di diploma "Così in terra" è stato selezionato al Festival di Cannes Cinéfondation e al Festival di Venezia - I Love GAI, oltre decine di candidature in festival nazionali e internazionali, vincendo il premio come miglior sceneggiatura al Phealgrean Festival. Finalista al premio Rodolfo Sonego per la sceneggiatura di "Sailor Girls" e finalista al Premio Franco Solinas 2017 con il soggetto e la sceneggiatura "Lo scambio equivalente". Sceneggiatrice per il documentario in produzione "Dimenticata Militanza: un ritratto politico di Gian Maria Volontè" e autrice con la compagnia Naufraghi inversi dello spettacolo "In battello con Dante" oltre che professoressa di sceneggiatura presso il Liceo Banzi di Lecce.Pietro Federico - WriterScrittore e traduttore. Laureato in lettere classiche con un master in sceneggiatura e produzione cinematografica. È copy e script writer in campo pubblicitario e story editor per sceneggiatori televisivi e scrittori. Scrive racconti e poesie, ricevendo riconoscimenti nell’ambito di premi nazionali e internazionali (Premio Raduga, premio Antonio Fogazzaro, premio Città di Pistoia, Premio Subiaco). Nel 2020 è uscita la sua raccolta di poesie "La maggioranza delle stelle" (Ensemble editore - 2020)
 
Patrocini

Associazione Italianisti - Gruppo Dante
Società Dante Alighieri
Hypermedia Dante Network
ENAC

story:
Damien Seperi as Bruce, Dixon Phillips as Vern in Ransom, Texas

Virago Theatre Company, a champion of new plays by SF Bay Area playwrights, just wrapped a 3 week run of award-winning playwright William Bivin's twisted dark comedy Ransom, Texas at Tides Theatre in San Francisco. Now we have the opportunity to bring it to Hollywood for a 3 week run! 

Ransom, Texas will perform at Theatre Asylum, in the heart of Theatre Row, home to the most award-winning and critically acclaimed live theater companies in Los Angeles.

Bivins's Ransom, Texas is a "twisting game of one-upmanship" (SF Gate) that grabs hold and never lets go. Set in a small West Texas town, a father and son locked in the office of a factory battle for power using whatever they've got: manipulation, mind-games, lies, and brute force. Keeping us off-guard with twists and reveals, this emotionally compelling dark comedy is "tense, terse and unremitting. The acting is brilliant, the staging perfect." (The Writer's Block, SF). Ransom, Texas stars Dixon Phillips as Vern, "a man of deep truth, violent, tender" and Damien Seperi as Bruce, "violent, perceptive...treacherous" (The Writer's Block). Ransom is directed by Bay Area visionary Jon Tracy, known for his masterful work in the Bay Area and beyond, with set design by superb scenic designer Nina Ball.

We need $2700 to get to Hollywood

Here's where the $$ will go!

  • TRAVEL: We need to get two actors and a stage manager to Los Angeles and back for 3 weekends. $900
  • THEATRE RENTAL: The deposit on 3 weeks rental at Theatre Asylum $800
  • HOUSING: These artists need a place to sleep!  $1000

Why are new plays important? 

It is Virago's mission to produce new Bay Area plays and bring them to greater audiences in bigger cities. It's important to get other voices in the room, voices that challenge social hierarchy, our culture, our government, even our existence, and bring new perspectives to the table. Without a stream of new voices and new perspectives, it's too easy to get stuck in mediocrity and stagnation. We believe in shaking it up! Help us bring new perspectives to new audiences by donating. 

What if you can't donate? 

If even a small donation hurts, we get it! Please help us get the word out by posting the link to our Indie Go Go on your Facebook and Twitter! And please tell friends. Thanks! 

MEET THE PLAYWRIGHT

William Bivins is an award-winning playwright whose productions include The Education of a Rake (Central Works),The Apotheosis of Pig Husbandry (SF Playhouse), The Position (PianoFight) and The Afterlife of the Mind (Virago Theatre Company), among others. He won the  2010 Hyperion Project Original Play Competition for a workshop production of Ransom, Texas, and the 2009 Bay Area Theatre Critics Circle Award for Pulp Scripture. Bivins was the most produced playwright of the 2009/2010 San Francisco Bay Area season, and was one of twelve Bay Area playwrights chosen for the 2008 Theatre Bay Area/TheatreWorks Playwrights Showcase. He is a two-time winner of Playground's Emerging Playwright Award and the recepient of a 2014 Playground Fellowship.

 Dixon Phillips as Vern, Damien Seperi as Bruce in Ransom, Texas
photos by Luis A. Solorzano.
CAST & CREW
William Bivins....Playwright
*Jon Tracy.....Director, Lighting Design
**Nina Ball......Scenic Design
Gary Quinn.....Stage Manager and Technical Director
Katie Robbins....Assistant Director
Hannah Birch Carl....Sound Composition & Design
Brooke Jennings....Costume Design
Julie Gillespie.....Properties Design
Dennis Chowenhill....Dramaturg
Dave Maier....Fight Choreographer
Edna Cabcabin Moran....Graphic Designer
Laura Lundy-Paine....Producer
Luis A. Solorzano....Photographer
Amy Demmon....Videography
*Member, Stage Directors and Choreographers Society
**Member, United Scenic Artists Union

story:
Short Description

Concept based off of Mr. FSU 2011 - http://www.youtube.com/watchv=YOGzUVIRCcU

LYLH: We've all been angry. We've all been sad. We've been scared, confused, lonely and curious, however, these emotions are often hidden by a mask. This mask that we wear is simply a smile. In the attempt to find ourselves, through our lowest moments, we just may end up stumbling upon genuine happiness.

What We Need & What You Get 

Funds will go towards DVRs, the making of programs and posters, costuming, set/dressings, equipment, copyright, respondents, and transportation to festivals.

Our perks for donating include: a free ticket, a signed poster, LYLH t-shirt, DVD copy, early show viewing, and an extended Q&A/cocktail party following the Sunday matinee.

Any left over funding will go towards cancer research.

The Impact

This show is a new type of theater that may open many doors for the art form in the future. In addition, the message behind this show is one that has, and currently is, changing lives. With your help, we will be able to spread the message in a sincere and genuine way to as large an audience as possible. The more you give, the more people we will reach.

Thomas Karner, as well as most of the crew of LYLH, have worked on multiple award winning shows in the Fitchburg State University Main Stage program. All of the students involved are excited to expand their repertoire and work on an individual project like this one. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to give financially, you can assist the project. Publicize when you can, come and see the show, and bring your friends!


Tickets are available at the Hammond Campus Center front desk (Fitchburg State University) from now through the week of performance. They are also available through donations here.

The performances will take place in Percival Hall at FSU. It runs October 22th - 26th at 7pm. There will be one matinee showing Sunday, October 27th at 2pm.

story:
We are Theatre Street Performing Arts - a social enterprise based on the border of Abbey wood and Thamesmead in South East London. We run a weekly Glee Choir and we have eleven of our senior singers who have successfully auditioned and got through to the Regional finals of this years Jack Petchey Glee Club Challenge. If they are successful again at the Regionals then will get the amazing experience of performing at the o2 London in the finals at the end of November. They have to perform 2 songs in both the regionals and finals so all need 4 costumes each. As well as this we would love to provide them with a uniform for the competitions to give them an extra confidence boost and feeling of belonging. They are a fantastic group of Children from all sorts of different backgrounds who share the love of singing. Our first song is a Love medley with some great classics. Aswell as this we have approx 20 more Children who are under 11 so can't take part - however we are planning to put together a showcase 'all about love' they will sing group numbers and solos and it will be a wonderful event for them - some of which have never had any experience like it and will give them such a sense of achievement and confidence. we need to be able to purchase mics, materials for the Children to make props and also ideally Tshirts with our choir name 'Glee Street' on them.

The area we are in is not affluent and the families of the Children and the Children would be incredibly grateful for any support that you can give to help them have these experiences. A little goes a long long way and thanks so much for reading and considering supporting our campaign.

Many thanks

Claire and the 'Glee Street' Children

 

Short Summary

My name is Claire and I am the Artistic Director of Theatre Street. Having had many experiences as a Child of performing and also as a young Adult I know what a difference it can make to a Child's confidence and life to be full of wonderful moments and experiences that will stay with you for a life time. I loved it so much that now I spend all my time sharing my knowledge and experiences with others so that they to can build moments of their own like it. 
The Children who attend our Glee Choir come because they love to sing, build friendships and feel part of something special. Each Child to me is different and unique and it is important to me that they all feel valued and rewarded for their positive contribution to the group. The days we are in with distractions of technology etc makes it even more important that we support and encourage Children who come out and take part in activities either for the pure enjoyment of it or they wish to make a career from singing and performing. Having a variety of ages in the group makes it extra special as the little ones look up to the older Children and our Glee group has a real family feel about it but also with a big exciting buzz of creativity. 
With your support the Younger Children will gain from seeing the older ones take part in the competition ,'it will give them something to aspire to. Also the older Children benefit from the experience and can teach the younger ones what they have learnt from it. Also it will give the older ones more confidence to continue. Then hopefully they can all join together to present a performance which is all about the 'Human Heart' a showcase based on Love! I am sure you agree that the World can always do with a little more Love!!!

story:
What Is This About?

and then: a sciene fiction folk event

“Life’s but a walking shadow, a poor player

that struts and frets his hour upon the stage

and then is heard no more.”

8 people, 6 instruments, billions of stars... you're in for a Science Fiction Folk Event! A hearty group assembles a gripping tale, accessorized with folk music, to explore the never ending questions. A 60-minute journey you don't want to miss! It's fun, it's heartfelt, and you'll leave looking up at the night with new eyes.

Who Are You?

This group of artists almost all just graduated from Tisch School of the Arts from the Atlantic and Experimental Theatre Wing studios. One member is not an NYU student, and one child is entering her senior year. Our fearless leader, Will Davis, wrote, composed, and directed this piece as his final project at ETW in December 2015. With his love of love of folk music, and his innate visionary way of actualizing bodies in space on stage, he has created a tender, fun, and engaging piece that the entire group is now stepping forth to share with the FringeNYC.

The ensemble is thrilled to have this new opportunity to share the story they love and work with a team they love. A new stage, a new world, and all they need is support.
The Cast- Molly Brog, Vincent Cinque, Will Davis, Aaron Glaize, Samuel Im, Leo Koorhan, Yeujia Low, and Leanne Velednitsky
Stage Manager- Ryan Hudzik
Lighting Designer- Kelley Shih
Costume Designer- Audrey Ketchell
Artwork- Nathalie Elzayn

Producer- Leanne Velednitsky

Asst. Prodcuer- Zac Porter

Director- Will Davis
With special thanks to the Kobalt Music Group and M. Ward
 

What We Need & What You Get

We need space and pizzaz. The bottom line is we need rehearsal space, we to finance the registration to the fringe, and we need to cover costs of all the little bits and ends (photos, venue tips, marketing printing, etc.). On top of that, if we happen to make a profit off our ticket sales, we are hoping to have stipends available for the incredible people who are working on this piece. We’ve got some top notch talent, and are mainly all recent graduates. So getting even a travel stipend goes a long way!


Other Ways You Can Help

COME SEE THE SHOW!!!! We are counting on our reach of possible audience to come out and support this crazy adventure! And we'd love to see you there. We'll also be hosting a fundraising party on July 31st (the last day of this campaign) so mark your calendars if you're in town!

story:
Six innovative dancers, and percussionist Adam Starkopf, generate a new platform for art making in the Bay Area. Alumni of Alonzo King LINES Ballet BFA & Training programs, dancers: Courtney Armani, Khala Brannigan, Shareen DeRyan, Amelia Eisen, Amy McMurchie and Liv Shaffer are committed to cultivating communal cohesion by sharing responsibility in both the creation and production of original dance works. This project offers an alternative to the traditional dance company environment by fostering opportunity for freelance artists to make, share, and show work in collaborative settings. This process engages artists' inquiry regarding the relevancy of their own work in relationship to the work of their peers, while simultaneously connecting to a diverse and expansive audience. By building highways for emerging artists to gain experience, the project carves new habits for community momentum, and intergenerational art making dialogue. Bay Area Dance Collective seeks funding to help empower a dynamic shift from director to artist driven processes that create positive interpersonal skills for artist and audience both inside and outside of the studio. 

We need your help!

Bay Area Dance Collective premiered their first work at ODC Theater this July, and have upcoming residences at SAFEhouse Arts through Fall 2016. The generous donations made will go towards rehearsal space, costumes, marketing materials, grant applications, paid rehearsals, and performance stipend for this upcoming season. A $5,000.00 goal will perpetuate future works made, contributing whole heartedly to the development of a lustful artistic community. 

Proposing a new system...

In this era, a career in the arts has become decreasingly sustainable without the support of preexisting institutions or our communities. We are reaching out to you for help continuing a lineage of curiosity and creativity that was laid before us. Our mentors and predecessors taught us that the West was where artists came to explore and make change. By donating to our campaign you are allowing that kind of pioneering philosophy to be a living component of the Bay Area arts community. A generation of dance artists torn as dance companies fold throughout the United States, and organizations left standing are exclusive in mold or oppressive in modality, we seek to forge new paths. Help us build new systems of working, which at large, is helping us design the culture around dance and art making of our future.
story_txt: Six innovative dancers, and percussionist Adam Starkopf, generate a new platform for art making in the Bay Area. Alumni of Alonzo King LINES Ballet BFA & Training programs, dancers: Courtney Armani, Khala Brannigan, Shareen DeRyan, Amelia Eisen, Amy McMurchie and Liv Shaffer are committed to cultivating communal cohesion by sharing responsibility in both the creation and production of original dance works. This project offers an alternative to the traditional dance company environment by fostering opportunity for freelance artists to make, share, and show work in collaborative settings. This process engages artists' inquiry regarding the relevancy of their own work in relationship to the work of their peers, while simultaneously connecting to a diverse and expansive audience. By building highways for emerging artists to gain experience, the project carves new habits for community momentum, and intergenerational art making dialogue. Bay Area Dance Collective seeks funding to help empower a dynamic shift from director to artist driven processes that create positive interpersonal skills for artist and audience both inside and outside of the studio. We need your help!Bay Area Dance Collective premiered their first work at ODC Theater this July, and have upcoming residences at SAFEhouse Arts through Fall 2016. The generous donations made will go towards rehearsal space, costumes, marketing materials, grant applications, paid rehearsals, and performance stipend for this upcoming season. A $5,000.00 goal will perpetuate future works made, contributing whole heartedly to the development of a lustful artistic community. Proposing a new system...In this era, a career in the arts has become decreasingly sustainable without the support of preexisting institutions or our communities. We are reaching out to you for help continuing a lineage of curiosity and creativity that was laid before us. Our mentors and predecessors taught us that the West was where artists came to explore and make change. By donating to our campaign you are allowing that kind of pioneering philosophy to be a living component of the Bay Area arts community. A generation of dance artists torn as dance companies fold throughout the United States, and organizations left standing are exclusive in mold or oppressive in modality, we seek to forge new paths. Help us build new systems of working, which at large, is helping us design the culture around dance and art making of our future.

story:
The No Stakes Theater Project began with a staged reading of Jim Cartwright's "The Rise and Fall of Little Voice" in August 2014 at The Foxhole Chicago.  The reading was directed by Erin Shea Brady, and featured Rebecca Sohn, Scarlet Sheppard, Marssie Mencotti, Ian Michael James, John Mobley, and Blake Montgomery.  From this reading, two exciting projects were born. 

The first: a full-fledged production of Cartwright's "Little Voice", produced by the No Stakes Theater Project at Theater Wit, August 14-September 6, 2015.  The production will be directed by Erin Shea Brady and stars Scarlet Sheppard as "Little Voice" and Rebecca Sohn as "Mari Hoff".

The second: a reading series, to be launched in 2015, that will serve as a development opportunity for post-graduate directors who are looking to explore work that excites and challenges them.

No Stakes is about taking risks.  It's about challenging yourself and playing hard and thinking big.  We hope that you will consider contributing to this exciting work, and we thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

Your contribution (big or small!) will help provide the following:
- Space Rental (Theater Wit, rehearsal space)
- Design Budgets (It's a two-story set!  And we've got some kick-ass designers on board, like Grant Sabin, Mike Durst, Moriah Turner, and Joe Court)
- Stipends (Help us pay our actors and our designers.  They're awesome, they work hard, they deserve it!)
And other odds and ends like sheet music, posters, programs, etc.

We really, really appreciate any help that you can give!


Special thanks to Caleb Fortune for creating our promotional video!  Photography by Liz Scheiner, Graphic Design by Charity Weishar, Staged Reading Footage by Noah Drewke.

story:
We are two North West based performers GiIlian Hardie and Keddy Sutton.

We met whilst appearing together in Willy Russell’s remix of ‘Stags n Hens,’ during The Capital of Culture at The Royal Court Theatre, Liverpool 2008. With a combined love of improvisation, comedy and Musical Theatre we began creating our own material shortly after and showcased it as part of Liverpool based, Spike Theatre's fundraiser. We got laughs and our alter egos Caz 'n' Britney were born. 

We developed these characters whilst touring the comedy/cabaret circuit including, Lavender Girls (Homotopia), Unity Theatre, Women in Comedy Arts festival Manchester, Miss Alternative Liverpool, L Fest, Liverpool Pride, L Talent on The HMS President London, The Everyman Theatre Liverpool farewell Cabaret, Laughing Cows, Frog and Bucket Manchester, Lodestar, Spike Theatre, Walking with Giants, The Tate Modern, Come on Girls, Dolman’s Disco, Funny’s funny, The Palm House, Crosby Comrades, Theatre Royal St Helens with special guest star ‘Margi Clarke,’

We wanted to develop the act into a full scale show and were given the opportunity by Unity Theatre based company 'Homotopia' 

Their support helped us to write 'SCOTTIE ROAD THE MUSICAL', the tale of pyjama wearing, pastie scoffing 'the inimitable ‘Caz n Britney,’ and their life-changing journey from Primark to Prison, a heartfelt tale and homage to the wonderful world of musical theatre. 

The show was a 'cell' out success, (with an extra date being added to accommodate the demand) at the Unity Theatre, and again at The Epstein Theatre, Liverpool.

We were given further help and support from HOMOTOPIA the following year which gave us the opportunity to develop Scottie Road's sequel 'MIS LES - A REVOLUTION IN ROLLERS. Again the show sold out, resulting in us being invited back by the Unity's Graeme Phillips for a seven night run in their studio space. This was immediately followed by an invitation from Claire Bigley at The Brindley, Runcorn to appear for two nights at their studio. Both runs were again sold to capacity.

We are so grateful for the support we have received from professionals, friends and families and we want nothing more than to take it further afield and sample the unique experience of the wonderful Edinburgh Festival. 


http://www.whatsonstage.com/liverpool-theatre/reviews/01-2014/scottie-road-the-musical-liverpool_33133.html

http://www.liverpoolsoundandvision.co.uk/2014/01/11/scottie-road-the-musical-theatre-review-unity-theatre-2014/


We know money is tight like an old Clarke's shoe. If you can help Thank You! if you can't thanks for reading. Gill and Keddy x

story:
"WHO IS HILLARY CLINTON?" 

- A PLAY BY LUCY CAMPBELL


This show is a spotlight on a woman dealing with betrayal, public humiliation, private struggle and what it takes to put the world before yourself.

My name is Lucy Campbell, I'm an Australian living in New York City. My purpose as an actress and writer is to inspire people, open their hearts and connect with their humanity.  Right now I am on my own journey, doing everything in my power to create an amazing life and to have a positive impact on people and the world around them no matter what it takes. 

My aim is to reach out and touch people in a way that propels them to take action and live their lives in a way that makes a difference.

Hillary Clinton lives from this place.  She is a woman that screams humanity, transformation and change.  Not only is she a political animal but she is also a mother, a woman, a wife and a friend.  

I am calling on YOU to be part of this show by contributing, to help me create this miracle and bring this show to the world.
