story:
Voir plus bas pour la version Française

A quest for meaning

I am a French dancer, actress, writer and knitter currently living in New York. After graduating from theater school, I found the endless game of auditions and rejections to be draining and not at all exciting creatively. Around the same time, I was dealing with a serious case of homesickness, and found myself pondering the plight of the first immigrants, that often had no hope of ever going back home. 

More and more creatively restless, I decided to start working on a one person show that would involve both acting and movement, and would intricately bind my own experience with that of my Russian great grandmother, who emigrated to France with my great grandfather and ended up losing her mind. As I began working on the project, the concept of exile broadened, and I found myself wanting to address the feeling I've had ever since I was a child, to be exiled on Earth from "another place", one I can't quite shake the nostalgia of.

Therefore, the piece became an allegory using both my ancestor's story and my own relationship with God and the Divine throughout my childhood and adolescence. It's a very personal show for me, and it allows me to stretch my creative muscle in three directions at once, writing, performing and choreographing it. 

How you can help!

Woman seeks God has been selected to participate in the Emerging Artists Theater New Work series in May. As of now I have about 20 min that are solid and have been workshopped in front of an audience. The other 40min are written but I need to start putting the text together with dance and movement, and for that I need space and time. Here's how your contribution will be employed if I make the goal: 

$500 will be used toward renting about 40h of rehearsal space between now and May 26th so that I can work on the dancing/movement parts of the piece.

$150 will go towards printing promotional material for the performance happening at EAT as well as the following performances at the Hive in Brooklyn at the beginning of June.

$200 will go towards hiring a sound/light person for the night of the 26th

$150 will go towards buying some props I still need (I have kept the show as light as possible, but still need a few things to put in my migrant suitcase :) )

$500 will go towards paying my amazing director Kate Szekely, who has been giving her time away for free since January and is prepared to do it again until May (but please help me pay her :) )

What else? 

Well, that's about it... This project is very dear to me, and I also believe it addresses something that I have rarely seen discussed on stage. During my time at theatre school, we studied Chekov extensively, and our teacher used to say that most of Chekov's characters goal in life was "to soar". This is my attempt to look at my own need for soaring, and my hope that I will help audiences soar with me and start looking at their life on Earth from a higher vantage point.   

How Else can you help?

If you cannot participate to the campaign, please spread the word about it, and about the show if you're in New York! :) 


Une quête de sens

Je suis une danseuse, actrice, écrivain et tricoteuse vivant actuellement à New York. Une fois diplômée de l'école de théâtre, j'ai trouvé le jeu sans fin des auditions et des rejets épuisant et pas du tout excitant créativement. Vers la même époque, je me senti terrassée par le mal du pays, et je me surpris à méditer sur le sort des premiers immigrants, qui n'avaient souvent aucun espoir de rentrer un jour chez eux.

Ma créativité étant de plus en plus frustrée, je décidai de commencer à travailler sur un solo qui utiliserait à la fois le jeu et le mouvement, et lierait intimement ma propre expérience avec celle de mon arrière grand-mère russe, qui emigra en France avec mon arrière grand-père et finit par devenir folle. Lorsque je commençai à travailler sur le projet, le concept d'exil s'élargit, et je me trouvai vouloir aborder le sentiment que j'ai depuis que je suis enfant, d'être exilée sur Terre, de venir d' "un autre endroit", dont je n'arrive pas vraiment à guériri la nostalgie.

Par conséquent, le spectacle devint une allégorie utilisant à la fois l'histoire de mon ancêtre et ma propre relation avec Dieu et le Divin au long de mon enfance et adolescence. C'est un spectacle très personnel, et il me permet de développer ma créativité dans trois domaines à la fois, l'écriture, la comédie et la chorégraphie.

Comment vous pouvez m'aider!

Woman seeks God a été sélectionné pour participer au festival Emerging Artists Theater New Work Series à New York en mai. Au jour d'aujourd'hui, j'ai environ 20 solides minutes qui ont déjà été présentées devant un public. Les 40 autres minutes sont écrites mais je dois commencer à créer la partie dansée et la l'intégrer au texte, et pour cela j'ai besoin de temps et d'espace. Voici comment votre contribution sera utilisée si je remplis mon objectif:

$500 seront utilisés pour la location d'environ 40h de studio de répétition entre maintenant et le 26 mai pour que je puisse travailler sur les parties dansées du solo, ainsi que sur son developpement dans l'espace.

$150 seront consacrés à l'impression du matériel promotionnel pour la performance à EAT ainsi que les performances suivantes à The Hive à Brooklyn au début de Juin.

$200 iront à l'embauche d'un technicien du son/lumière pour la soirée du 26

$150 seront consacrés à l'achat de quelques accessoires dont j'ai encore besoin (J'ai fait en sorte que le spectacle soit le plus léger possible, mais j'ai encore besoin de quelques objets à mettre dans ma valise de migrante :))

$500 iront à payer ma merveilleuse metteuse en scène, Kate Szekely, qui donne de son temps gratuitement depuis Janvier et serait prête à continuer jusqu'en mai (mais s'il vous plaît aidez moi à la payer :))

Quoi d'autre?

Eh bien, c'est tout ... Ce projet est très cher à mon coeur, et je crois aussi qu'il aborde quelque chose que j'ai rarement vu discuté sur scène. Pendant  ma formation, nous avons beaucoup étudié Chekov, et notre professeur avait l'habitude de dire que l'objectif de vie de la plupart des personnages de Chekov était de «s'envoler». Ceci est une tentative de partager mon propre besoin d'envol, et mon espoir est d'aider le public à s'envoler avec moi et à considérer leur vie sur Terre d'un point de vue plus élevé.

Si vous ne pouvez pas participer à la campagne, s'il vous plaît passez le mot à ceux qui peuvent! Merci mille fois!

story:
THIS INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN HAS ENDED SEPT 6TH. IF YOU WISH TO CONTRIBUTE TO PAULINE'S TRIP, PLEASE CONTACT ZOIE at info@jamiiesplanade.org TO MAKE A DONATION . WE APOLOGIZE FOR THE INCONVENIENCE. 

In September, Pauline, a 12-years-old from The Esplanade, is traveling to China.

One-of-a-kind opportunity.

Jamii, a community-arts organization based on The Esplanade, and CORPUS, a Toronto dance/theatre company, are offering Pauline the opportunity to step in as Assistant Stage Manager. She will accompany the dancers on their performances of Les moutons at the Meriton Children’s Festival in Xi’An.

When back in her neighbourhood, Pauline will share her experience with friends, family, neighbours and classmates.

Pauline has already fundraised $300 selling lemonade during the summer. We need your support to help financing the rest of Pauline’s trip.

Any donations beyond the set goal of $2200 will go towards community-arts projects on The Esplanade co-produced by Jamii & CORPUS.

For donations above $25, a tax receipt will be provided.


www.corpus.ca

www.jamiiesplanade.org

story:
Our background:

The Unknown Theatre Company is a voluntary young person's theatre (ages 13 -25). Formed over 17 years ago, we strive to undertake amazing, unique projects that will develop confidence and performance skills in young people that they can use in their future; be it on stage, on screen or in their every day lives.  To this end we firmly believe it should not be that you can afford to  'pay to be talented' and our opportunities are therefore affordable for all.  We harness young energy and enthusiasm, throw in a measure of theatre skills and techniques, give opportunities to work with industry professionals whilst creating new musicals, performing established works and allowing the young people to gain recognition and awards in various festivals, performances and competitions on a local, national and international stage.  However equally important is that they also appreciate and interact with their local community and to this end, we can often be found entertaining at old people's homes and singing at community concerts.

The project:

A couple of years ago, we were contacted by a travel company who were looking for a young person's theatre group to host a group of young people from McCurdy Theatre Arts. They were going to visit Cardiff for a day as part of a tour of UK and wanted to perform.  Always on the look out for something different for our youngsters to participate in, we welcomed our guests, had an evening of singing for each other and made friends along the way.  This year we are getting together again to collaborate on a new Musical -  Cult the Musical.  Our visitors will arrive in Cardiff during August for a week of rehearsals with our young people, undertake social and cultural activities, homestay with our young people and then we will all travel together to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival to perform at Venue 13 for a week. 

The total project cost for the UK part of the project will be £11,370. Of this the young people will be contributing towards their accommodation in Edinburgh, subsistence in Edinburgh and their travel costs to get to Edinburgh.  Additionally our visitors from USA will be covering the costs of their travel to Cardiff and back. 

However, there are a number of aspects of the project that we need to raise funds towards including production costs and cultural aspects. There is the cost of rehearsal and performance venue hire, fringe entry, costumes, props, set, posters, t.shirts and programmes.  Then there are travel costs for our visitors to and from rehearsals, subsistence during rehearsal times, cultural activities such as visits to sites of specific interest in Cardiff and group activities to get to know each other.

Total anticipated shortfall is £2500. 

We can offer our sponsors acknowledgement on our facebook group, in our show programme, a Cult the Musical t.shirt or tickets to our show in Edinburgh or to future shows that the company undertakes.

Our project is important to the young people on both sides of the pond because it will give them an opportunity to experience performing at a world class festival, giving them a taste for life in the ‘real’ performance world.  It will also enable them to watch a wide variety of performances that they would otherwise not be exposed to.  As participants in the festival, they will also become audience members for other performers, thus enabling those shows to showcase their work to a wider audience. 

This will be the 9th time that The Unknown Theatre Company has visited Edinburgh.  In each of those visits we have taken a new musical that we either commissioned, was written for or with us or had permission from the composer/writer to perform.  It is an amazing opportunity, yet again for our young people to perform new writing and be a part of a new musical.  The company also has a track record of collaboration with other young people around the world. In 2001 they hosted a group of young people from Kawaguchi for a collaborative production and made a return visit to Japan in 2002.  They were chosen to represent the UK to perform at the World Festival Fusion in Monaco in 2005 and from this were invited to participate in a youth festival in St Avertin France.

The Challenges:

As a group that are not funded by any governmental or central bodies, we rely entirely on our own funding efforts to make these projects happen.  And happen they do!  The small committee of volunteers, together with the young people of the company, are dedicated in their efforts to find solutions to financial challenges.  Will you help us in this challenge?

Shout it out:

If you can’t contribute at the moment, thank you anyway for your time to read about our project and group.  Please like our facebook page – the unknown theatre company and share it amongst your friends…THANKS!

Indiegogo has some share tools you can use.

Our background:The Unknown Theatre Company is a voluntary young person's theatre (ages 13 -25). Formed over 17 years ago, we strive to undertake amazing, unique projects that will develop confidence and performance skills in young people that they can use in their future; be it on stage, on screen or in their every day lives.  To this end we firmly believe it should not be that you can afford to  'pay to be talented' and our opportunities are therefore affordable for all.  We harness young energy and enthusiasm, throw in a measure of theatre skills and techniques, give opportunities to work with industry professionals whilst creating new musicals, performing established works and allowing the young people to gain recognition and awards in various festivals, performances and competitions on a local, national and international stage.  However equally important is that they also appreciate and interact with their local community and to this end, we can often be found entertaining at old people's homes and singing at community concerts.The project:

story:
Short Summary

My name is Frank Marquette and I’m a professional actor, writer, director, producer, artist and sales and marketing wizard with over 35 years of passion in each discipline. In 1998 I combined all of my experiences and gave birth to Murder Café in Las Vegas, Nevada. My purpose was to offer residents and company groups comedy-musical murder mystery plays, a genre we lifted to new heights. (Yes, many do it badly.) During our 11 year run in Sin City, our little family-run theatre company took us in many unexpected directions. For eight years we had the only family-oriented Christmas show in Las Vegas, that being our celebrated dinner theater version of Charles Dickens’ classic, A Christmas Carol. Not only were we an annual fixture at Lawry’s Prime Rib Restaurant, we presented a condensed version of the play at dozens of schools in the greater Las Vegas area. This first venture into educational theatre was unwritten by The Rotary Club and it exposed hundreds of underserved students to their first live performance. Elementary school kids throughout the city were excited and engaged when they met Scrooge, the Ghosts of Christmas and Charles Dickens himself. Bringing literature to life became an essential part of our purpose.

In 2009 we returned “home” to the Hudson Valley of New York State and brought Murder Café with us. We continued producing quality comedies, musicals and murder mysteries but also put a lot of our efforts into fundraising, educational programs and community outreach. Scrooge and Dickens found a new home in New York and since they were embraced by area residents we added Edgar Allan Poe. In 2010 we were commissioned by the Poughkeepsie Library District to create an original play based on the works of Poe. This was part of the library’s Big Read program funded by the National Endowment for the Arts. Over the past three years Mr. Poe has made numerous appearances throughout the area, most notably on stage at Columbia-Greene Community College in Hudson, New York.

The research involved in writing and producing my original play Poe’s Last Mystery led us to historical reenactments and a series of “haunted” shows. Last year my acting troupe began performing as historical characters at the Mills Mansion in Staatsburg, the Morton Library in Rhinecliff and the Vanderbilt House in Philmont. Those shows presented actors performing as both historical figures and ghosts who have been known to haunt the locations mentioned. Our original series, A Haunting on the Hudson: voices from the past, a site specific play, has recently been requested by the Rhinecliff Hotel, Emmett’s Castle in Pearl River, the Shandley Hotel in Naponoch and Museum Village in Monroe. Considering the history of the mid-Hudson Valley our venture into history and hauntings has unlimited possibilities.

I’m proud to tell you because of our haunting shows, we introduced a lot of people to President Lincoln’s funeral ghost train. That is a story worth Googling!

In order to bring living theatre that is both educational and entertaining to area historic sites, schools and colleges, libraries and museums we created a company called Theatre on the Road. Yes, there are many superb theatre companies in New York State but none quite share our business model and plan. Simply put, our purpose is to expose the magic of theatre to people who normally don’t go to the theatre and that’s an idea we have found to be pretty unique. Let me expand on this. Who isn’t afraid of Shakespeare? Using the four-scene, dinner theatre format we’ve been using in Murder Café for the past 16 years, we are going to launch A Taste of Shakespeare: bite sized portions presented by William Shakespeare. This original production offers four classic and timely scenes with the Bard acting as host and narrator. Like everything else we do the proverbial “fourth wall” will be torn down and audiences will have an opportunity to interact with the characters they’ve been avoiding since 11th grade. 

How about a little variety? Our original show, The Legend of Charlie and Myrtle: A History of Vaudeville in America, will walk the audience through the history of what was once our most popular form of live entertainment. Students and the public alike will be amazed by a presentation set in 1914 that features singers comedy, jugglers, dancers, musicians, magic and a roster of performers who later became household names. Fortunately there are a number of theatres in the Hudson Valley that once housed vaudeville shows. How retro! How amusing! How enlightening!

Using professional actors, carefully researched scripts and handmade and historically accurate costumes and production values, we will be filling a need and many rooms. Without leaving their schools or local venues, both students and the public alike will have access to living history and literature like never before. People will be entertained by, and can interact with, the likes of Poe, Dickens, Washington Irving, Thomas Cole, Henry Hudson, Sojourner Truth, Matthew Vassar and Cornelius Vanderbilt to name a few. Our performers and storytellers will also include common folk whose labor and creativity made the Hudson Valley what it is today. Students will learn from artists, farmers, canal workers and those who both divided and united us – Native Americans, Dutch settlers, and British occupiers and explorers.

We can sum this up in one simple phrase: Live is better! We are not only passionate about this campaign but believe it is our responsibility to bring living history and literature to area students and the general public. As the Hudson Valley continues to expand with tourists and new homeowners we are thrilled at the prospect of entertaining young and old, at school or at a local institution, in an appealing and painless way.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution to Theatre on the Road will us gain much needed space, transportation, personnel and materials. We’re breaking it down like this:

  • Rehearsal and storage facility (rent and utilities for 12 months)  9,500
  • Cargo trailer   1,800
  • Administrative assistant (12 months)  9,800
  • Marketing (printing, direct mail, web and social media, promo)    3,200
  • Instructional materials (show programs, visual aids, CDs and videos)    2,200
  • Office supplies (dedicated computer, software)    2,000
  • Travel expenses and insurance 1,500

Grand total:    30,000


    The Impact

    By donating to this campaign you’ll be sponsoring a one-of-a-kind group of passionate actors who will:

    • Bring educational and entertaining performances to underserved students

    • Offer “live literature and living history” to students and the general public in a fun and non-threatening way. (We’re not stuffy!)

    We are uniquely qualified to follow through on everything we outlined in our summary. Why? Because we’ve done it, we just want to do more of it. We’ve performed a condensed version of A Christmas Carol at dozens of at-risk schools to the delight of students who never experienced an interactive, live performance. We created Poe’s Last Mystery and successfully brought Edgar Allan Poe to area schools, theatres and libraries. And we presented historic figures like Cornelius Vanderbilt and Matthew Vassar to local homes and inns that claim to be haunted. Who better to expand all of these creations than us?

      Risks & Challenges

      We’re passionate but we don’t wear rose colored glasses. Business is business and we realize it comes with roadblocks that sometimes seem difficult to cross. In addition to our artistic endeavors, we also have 35 years in corporate sales and marketing and graphic design. We’re also up to speed on web marketing and social media. We’ve been marketing Murder Café successfully for 16 years along with the venues we perform in. Promotion is a full time job, so whether it’s writing press releases, or designing posters, flyers and mailers we’re prepared. We also prepared to work with school officials and administrators, museum and library directors, theatre managers and restaurant owners of every type. With Murder Café we average 45 shows a year so we can handle almost any situation.


        Other Ways You Can Help

        Just because you can't contribute financially, doesn't mean you can't help!

        • We need your help to get the word out. Tell EVERYONE and ANYONE about Theatre on the Road.
        • Do you have a student or know one who you think is starved for creative and educational theatre? How about yourself; are you tired of the same entertainment choices? How about a little Shakespeare? Poe? A famous ghost who will give you the history of your favorite historic site?
        • If you agree Theatre on the Road could offer a much needed contribution of the culture of the area, let everyone know we need their support.
        • Share this IndieGoGo Campaign on Facebook, Twitter and email.

story:
Short Summary

We are starting a year-round, community theatre in Ashland, Oregon.'Thanks for the Memories Theatre' will be a theatre to provide live entertainment and a variety of quality live and affordable theatre to the community. It is our goal to be a living, breathing part of the community that will be an asset to all. 


What We Need & What You Get

The funds we are raising here will go to the look, accessibility and overall comfort of your theatre experience at 'Thanks for the Memories Theatre'. By donating you will become part of the family and get to experience the incredible parts of an amazing theatre experience.


The Impact

Myself and all the people assembled have an ongoing love and passion for live theatre and what it brings. We don't just wish to be an entertainment venue, but also a part of the community. We want to help build on culture and passion and dreams. Ashland, Oregon is an incredible place of culture and community and we want to be a part of that.

We are looking to bring a unique variety of shows to the area, from original works to musicals and established classic plays.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and attend shows, or volunteer! We want this to be a year-round theatre that is not only beneficial to the artists, but also the community as a whole.

Our Theatre People

Geoff Ridden - Board of Directors

Steven Dominguez - Board of Directors

Susan Aversa-Orrego - Board of Directors

Peter Wickliffe - Artistic Director

story:
BREAKING NEWS:  PHANTOMWISE has been invited to perform at the New York International Fringe Festival!!!  We couldn't be more thrilled.  This means we're working towards a fully produced production of PHANTOMWISE for the Fringe by August.  Our total fundraising goal with be $10,000 -- anything exceeding our initial goal will go towards the 10,000 dollar Fringe budget.  Please help us by spreading the word - the more people we can get to donate even five dollars, the closer we get to making this a reality!

 

Dear friends, family, supporters of the arts, and amazing humans,

In 1862, Charles Dodgson told a girl named Alice Liddell a story about another Alice who fell down a rabbit hole into a world called Wonderland.  

Alice in Wonderland is a story that captured both of our imaginations as children -- as it has so very many -- and it has intrigued us both well beyond those early years:  especially when we became better acquainted with the figure of Alice Liddell herself.

Sweeping between fantasy and reality, Oren Stevens' PHANTOMWISE tells the story of Alice Liddell's life and her relationship with the Wonderland story she inspired.  

PHANTOMWISE had a very successful student production with the Yale dramat in 2010 under the direction of Maya Seidler.  Avital and Oren had met in a theatre design class at Yale, and it was at an early table read in preparation for the dramat production that Avital fell in love with Oren's play.  By the time it was performed, Avital had graduated and it was another two years before Oren finished Yale and moved to New York.  Now both artists in the "real world," Avital and Oren began talking last fall about how they might further develop PHANTOMWISE.

We are very excited to be continuing PHANTOMWISE's development in the Big Apple!  For this, we need your help.

We are working towards a eventual professional production of this play, but need first to develop the text with a company of professional actors.  This will allow us to take risks and further develop the text before sharing our process with you in a staged reading on Thursday, May 24th.

As you know, producing theatre in New York is expensive.  We need to be able to rent rehearsal space, rent a performance venue for the staged reading, and honor the time and commitment of our artists.  Also, if you have any leads on reduced rate/donated rehearsal space please do let us know.  This could make a huge difference in the success of this campaign.

Thank you in advance for your generous support and we hope to see you all at our reading this May!  


Gratefully yours,

Oren and Avital

story:
According to American author and educator, Henry Van Dyke, time is too slow for those who wait, two swift for those who fear, too long for those who grieve, too short for those who rejoice, but for those who love, time is eternity. REJOICE is a modern day ritual celebrating life and love through various creations ranging from lyrical abstractions, social dances to vivid dance commentaries on culture and history.  

Niles Ford's Urban Dance Collective will perform a two-program evening of dance featuring the world premiere, Give Thanks, which was commissioned by Dixon Place.  The run is the first at Dixon Place by the company since Ford's death at the age of 52.   Ford was hailed in the New York Times as "a dancer of quiet intelligence, understated sweetness and intense focus." 

Give Thanks celebrates life and love through various movement creations ranging from lyrical abstractions, social dances to vivid dance commentaries on culture and history. Give Thanks is dedicated to the loving memory of Ford and to the memory of Carli Zackery-Rogers. Choreography:  Royce Zackery & Nathan Trice

We Are People is a fast-paced, highly physical and eclectic program that pays tribute to what has happened in the world in the past 10 years including issues around 9/11, the Iraq War, homosexuality and racism. Choreography: Niles Ford

Performers:  Katie Balton, Stephesha David, Robert Graham, Cara Robino, Julie Seal, Michelle Siegel, Damani Pompey.

Other Collaborators:  Daisy Zackery Clark, Vocalist; Matthew Hill, Percussionist; Marline A. Martin, Poet.

Performance Schedule:  Fridays & Saturdays
December, 6, 7, 13, 14, 20, 21, 2013

For Tickets:  www.dixonplace.org Or Call:  212-219-0736.

About UDC - Urban Dance Collective is a Brooklyn-based dance company working in more than one dimension to address social issues through dance, spoken word and music.  Like other artists we communicate the psychological effects of these issues — poverty, war, sexism, religion, and homosexuality — through physical movement.  Founded in 2002 by the late Niles Ford, UDC works with dancers and choreographers from other dance companies, sharing ideas artistically and to witness other view points. The choreography aesthetic is a hybrid of many techniques including ballet, modern, jazz, hip-hop, club dancing, and pedestrian movement.

We Need to Fund our Performance Season at Dixon Place!  Combined with the commissioning funds from Dixon Place, your contribution will go towards paying the dancers, musicians and collaborators that  will help make our show an even greater success!!!  Producing Dance in New York City is an expensive endeavor.  That is why we need more help to cover expenses for all of our dancers, the cost of costumes, guest artists and other production costs.   Help UDC make their season at Dixon Place a success!  Be it $5 or $500, your contribution will help to get us one step closer to realizing Niles' dream for the future of his company. So many of you have helped with time and emotional support and if you are unable to make a monetary contribution here, you can still help us by spreading the word.  Feel free to share links to this page on your personal Facebook and Twitter accounts and please LIKE the official Urban Dance Collective Page:  https://www.facebook.com/UrbanDanceCollectiveUdc

Thank You!

story:
UPDATE!! IT'S OFFICIAL--JAYA IS GOING TO SAB!!!

A Miraculous benefactor has come forward! Their donation has helped us surpass our Indigogo goal of $3000! We are filled with a sense of awe and we are brimming with gratitude!  

We still have 3 days left on our campaign, and if we are fortunate enough to receive any further contributions,  the monies will go directly to a fund for more training opportunities for Jaya (e.g. additional modern/lyrical classes at the famous Steps On Broadway Studios in NY). As well as funds needed (approx: $240) for accomodations in NY before checking Jaya in at SAB. 

Our deepest thanks to all  who helped make Jaya's SAB dream a reality!

My Story


Hi!  My name is Jaya Celeste and I am 13 years old.  I dance.  It's like breathing to me!  I have been studying ballet at the Oregon Ballet Academy (OBA) in Eugene, OR since I was 6 yrs old. That is over half of my entire life up to this point(e)!  So, to say that I am serious about ballet would most certainly be an understatement.  I am in class 6 days a week, up to 4 hours per day.  I am diligently pursuing my dream of becoming a professional Ballet Dancer and hope to further that dream with YOUR help.  

A huge part of an aspiring ballet dancer's life is the instruction he or she is fortunate enough to receive through "summer intensives".  Summer intensives are typically concentrated dance instruction (from one to 6 weeks) offered by many regional and high profile dance companies or schools around the country during the summer. Students  take several dance classes a day as well as participate in workshops on nutrition, proper care and fitting of pointe shoes, pilates or yoga.  They may also be given the opportunity to work with world reknowned teachers and choreographers. Dancers must audition and be accepted in order to attend most of these high quality programs. 

I started attending summer intensives at the age of 9. My first intensive was 
American Ballet Theatre's Young Dancer's Summer Workshop in Los Angeles. I have since studied for the past 3 summers in San Francisco at Alonzo King's LINES ballet.  The training at both of these schools was superlative and has helped to shape the dancer I am becoming.  This year I was fortunate enough to get into several of the most prestigious summer programs in the country.   ABT NY, Pacific Northwest Ballet and Joffrey to name a few.  (See my acceptance letters in the gallery!) In addition to these honors,  the Big Kahuna....the brass ring of ballet schools accepted me... SAB! (The School of American Ballet at Lincoln Center in NYC).  This is the school that was founded by George Balanchine.  It is incredibly selective (only 200 students are accepted each summer out of the 2000+ students who audition) and I was fortunate enough to have been one of the few deemed capable enough for their rigorous program.

WHAT INSPIRES ME?   


I owe much of my success to the fact that I have been super lucky to have John Grensback, the director of OBA as my teacher!  He was a principal dancer with the Houston Ballet; he danced with the Joffrey and with the New York City Ballet and was put under contract by George Balanchine himself.

One of my very favorite stories that
John told us was about the time he was in class with Mikhail Baryshnikov!  He said that Mikhail watched him (John) do a combination then said "You're pretty good...  I'll have to work harder!"  I never forgot that story and have been inspired and motivated by it ever since.  I work very hard every day on my technique....you know....for when I just happen to take class with Svetlana Zakharova or Natalia Osipova.......!  

If you don't know who these supremely brilliant ballerinas are please enjoy these links!  This is the standard to which I hold myself.  I am determined to reach this level of artistry and technique!

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cpsk0GPEI1U&feature=fvsr

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SOvXo841L1o&feature=related

The Challenge:

My Mom and Dad have been the most supportive parents I could ever hope for.  Over the years, and with OBA's help they have found a way to make my dance dreams come true.  This year's acceptance to SAB took them a bit by surprise as I was barely 13 at the time of the audition.  So, the expense of going to SAB at Lincoln Center in NYC this July is an unexpected one and beyond their current means....

The total cost of the summer program is $5200. plus another $800 for travel expenses.  My parents have managed to make a downpayment and have applied for and received some financial aid.  Phew! In a nutshell we still need roughly $3000 to make this happen.  



This is where YOU, my dear family, friends, benefactors and Patrons of the Arts enter CENTER STAGE!!  I promise I will make you all proud and dance with the heart of a grateful warrior to honor all who help shape my Dance Destiny and to inspire those with dreams of their own!

We are working hard to get me to NY this summer, so even if we don't make our goal all the money will go toward that end.  I am also working odd jobs and making hairbows, earrings and decorated pointe shoes to sell.  These lovely items, designed by mom and me will also be offered as part of the perks for you lovely donors out there!  And if we are blessed enough to raise more than our goal, 100% of the money will go toward additional training/workshop opportunities for which I qualify.

Being a Ballet Dancer is a career that starts very, very young and ends sooner than most.  That is why there is a sense of urgency here. As with any profession, the best education in one's chosen field is part of achieving the level of ability required to be able to obtain success at a high level.  


SAB is like the Harvard or Yale of ballet schools and being invited to study there is quite a privilege!   To put it into perspective, the next 4 years of my dance education is like my college! By age 17 I should be apprenticing with a major company (I hope!)  So, I'm starting now and with your help I can find a way to give a little beauty back to the world.


The impact your generosity will have on me and my family is hard to quantify.  Helping me be part of  a rarified and unique art form such as Ballet is an investment not only in me but in the preservation of a much under appreciated iconic art form.  Those who dedicate their lives to The Ballet are passionately committed, hard working and fierce! Please let me prove to you that I can flourish in that arena and take the impact you will have made on me to turn around and make an impact on the ballet world!  

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

No donation is too small.  Every penny is like a step in a beautiful dance
choreographed by you! With each of those steps getting me closer and closer to performing on the world's greatest stages. And even if you can't donate at this time, you can be the music by letting your voice be heard. If you know someone who appreciates the fine arts, please just lead them to my campaign!  Your kindness and faith in me would be like the beating of a butterfly's wings rippling out into a mysterious and beautiful universe! 

“I don't want people who want to dance. I want people who have to dance.” 

â€• George Balanchine

â€• George Balanchine

story:
Here’s the Story…

As I explain in the video, my name is Whitney and I was born and raised in Greensburg, KS. On May 4th, 2007 our small town was 95% destroyed by a 1.7 mile wide tornado.

It has taken a lot of blood, sweat, and tears, but we have turned our town around! Many homes and businesses have already been rebuilt in an environmentally sustainable way! We are the only town in America that has majority LEED certified buildings (think really, really green). We still have a long way to go to “fully” recover and one project left to rebuild is our Twilight Theatre. The former theatre stood proud in our community for 90 years before being completely destroyed

 

Greensburg will never be the same without such a signature part of our community being reborn. The exterior is now finished, but significant funding is still needed to finish the interior. Many items have been donated from various companies such as a popcorn machine, the movie screen, lighting, sound, etc. None of this will matter without having somewhere for the people to sit!

 

This building will not just be a movie theatre. The Twilight Theatre and Community Auditorium will host school functions such as plays, concerts, programs and award shows. It will hold hundreds of community members for Veterans Day ceremonies, Christmas pageants and town meetings. It will spark renewed excitement for local artists and performers to come and share their talent, too!

The Impact: Decades of Memories

Now it is time to bring back a part of history and make it available for many generations to come! This isn’t just a single play we are funding that will run its course and be forgotten. It isn’t a film with a beginning and end only to be enjoyed a few times. This will be a place where memories are made, laughter and quality time will be shared, and a community can feel whole once again.

 

What we need and what you get!

Right now we are raising $75,000 to complete the seating. We will be able to seat over 400 in this incredible, state of the art Twilight Theatre. There are other components to be completed as well, but seating is a crucial element! Your generous donation will not only get us one step closer to closing out another element of rebuilding, it will also encourage others to do the same!! We also want to give back to you for donating! As you can see along the right hand side of the page, there are rewards for each donation level. I don’t know about you, but the thought of having my name or a memorial for a loved one on a seat that will be in this building for decades to come is amazing! Every little bit helps! You will receive a personal thank you along with the appreciation of an entire community.

      

Other ways you can help

Whether or not you can give financially, we can still use your help!! The more people that know about this project, the greater chance it has for success. Please, take a minute and think of who you might know, whether friends or family, that might love to hear about The Twilight Theatre. We live in a world of instant communication. Use your social media, email, phone, or even good old fashioned face to face conversation to help us spread the word! You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to make it easy.  Every single dollar counts to finish this theatre and the continued rebirth of a community.

story:
My Story

Before I even introduce myself I want to say thank you. Thank you for even reading this. Ok. Now...

 

My name is Sam Picart and I am a Junior at the Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle.I have been training in dance for three years, mainly in ballet. Before my training I lived in Blue Springs, Missouri. As a kid I would watch hip hop and funk dancers on Youtube in my room and I'd try to imitate what the dancers were doing while watching myself in the mirror. I was stunned and amazed at how the human body could move and I wanted all of those 'super powers' that made me feel so inspired. Dancing was the only way I could truly express myself so it made sense that I would pursue it as a career dream.  At age 18 I left my home to live with my dad here in Seattle. I wanted to take a leap of faith and try to become a serious dancer. Most professional dancers start at a very young age so I knew then that my journey would be a long and difficult one.  Through luck, love from family and friends, and hard work I was accepted into a wonderful college in Seattle. When things happen to you like that it makes you believe that this life is meant for something special.

 

Through audition I was recently selected to attend Joffrey Ballet School's Summer Intensive Program in New York City. The thing is I have always been afraid to audition for anything and with the right push(or violent shove) from the right people I actually showed up. With all the power and confidence I might have on stage, it dwindles when it comes to putting myself out there with the likes of other talented people and especially leaving my home to do it. I think it was an amazing miracle and blessing to have been accepted into this program. I don't know about some but I never thought something like this could happen to me until I read the acceptance email yesterday morning(February 24, 2012). I have never been to the East Coast and being from a small town in the Midwest its rather intimidating to say the least. None the less I must chase my dream and with the right training I feel as if I could be a well-rounded artist with success in the dance world. My experience in New York would be a great launching point for my dance career and I know that is the reality.

 

What I Need

I'm not going to lie to you I heard New York is kind of expensive so I think that's why this program is so pricey. For this trip to be possible I need 5000 dollars.This money will pay for the four-week tuition, registration, housing fees, transportation, and the meal plan so I can have the energy a dancer needs! If I can't reach my minimum goal of $5000 I will use what I have and send videos of myself crying to family and friends that didn't donate. I also will be putting in extra hours at work and praying to the heavens that I get what I need and I believe things will work out. And just know even $5 goes a long way :)

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would please spread the word about this campaign of mine by sending links and sharing this page I would forever be in your debt. I thank you so much for your consideration and support. It means the world to me that you would support me in something I never thought could or would happen. My dreams of becoming a professional dance artist are starting to take shape and I am eternally grateful to all those involved. Again, thank you so much!!!!

If I can't reach my minimum goal of $5000 I will use what I have and send videos of myself crying to family and friends that didn't donate. I also will be putting in extra hours at work and praying to the heavens that I get what I need and I believe things will work out. And just know even $5 goes a long way :)
 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you would please spread the word about this campaign of mine by sending links and sharing this page I would forever be in your debt. I thank you so much for your consideration and support. It means the world to me that you would support me in something I never thought could or would happen. My dreams of becoming a professional dance artist are starting to take shape and I am eternally grateful to all those involved. Again, thank you so much!!!!

story:
Our Story

The Theatre of the Republic is one of the best community theatre's around.  We have big ideas for our future, however, our theatre is need of a facelift. 

The Impact

With a remodel, our theatre will be able to provide a safe, efficient, creative outlet for the community.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise enough funds that will cover the cost of putting a new floor in various rooms.  Our current floors are a hodge podge of dusty carpet, splintered wood, and peeling laminate.  We hope to be able to install a new laminate floor that will be easy to keep clean and withstand wear.  We are excited to show you our progress!!


Any donations of 100 dollars or more will receive a backstage tour, autographed poster, and a meeting with the cast of a show of their choice.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and repost this link in your Facebook page.  Thank you so much and let's get our theatre in tip top shape!

story:
Hello and welcome to the IndieGoGo page for the upcoming original two act theater production, "Laboratories of Our Youth". Please take a moment to watch our short video explaining the who, what, where and when of our production.

---------------------------------------------------

What is "Laboratories of Our Youth"?

â€œLaboratories of Our Youthâ€ is a story about young love, cocktails, summer internships and growing up.  Itâ€™s the summer 1965 and Harvey and Abe are hard at work on their graduate school internships at a strange antennae in New Jersey.  Neither one of them are getting quite the experience that they thought they would, however.  They spend their days intricately filing incomprehensible data for their arrogant boss Dr. Nootboom, and bickering between each other.  The only thing that breaks up the monotony of the day is their mutual love for Harveyâ€™s fetching girlfriend Rosemary, who will soon be moving away to start her freshman year at Dartmouth.

Strangers at the beginning of the summer, the boys have found it difficult to live and work together.  On the surface, Harvey seems like the perfect candidate for a life of academia:  heâ€™s organized, driven, and unfailingly polite.  Unfortunately for Harveyâ€™s scientific career he is also intensely neurotic and deeply insecure, traits that have become abundantly clear to Abe through several months of sharing a bunk bed.  While Harvey dotes upon Dr. Nootboom, Abe prefers to plant himself on the sofa doing the bare minimum.  He spends his days blaring jazz music, perfecting his alcoholic fatherâ€™s martini recipe, and chain smoking as Harvey obsessively cleans up the ashes.  Though they couldnâ€™t be more mismatched, sharing Dr. Nootboomâ€™s burdens has helped build a tenuous friendship that neither young men, intent upon disliking each other, are aware of.
Throughout the summer, Abe has gotten to know Rosemary and, despite himself, fallen in love with her.  When the boys receive the news that a strange visitor is coming to see Dr. Nootboom, Abe begins to put a bizarre plan in motion, a plan to get Rosemary and Harvey apart, and win her affections for himself.

For Rosemary, neither of our heroes presents an easy choice.  She is starting to believe that Harvey may not be right for her, and is surprised to find that Abe could be.  She doesnâ€™t want to hurt either one of them, but sheâ€™s quickly learning that to live the life she wants, someone is going to have to be hurt.

One the eve of an enormous scientific discovery made by Dr. Nootboom, the three of them come together with the Doctorâ€™s very strange old friend, an Italian fighter ace who may have a bit of a crush on Harvey, for drinks, cheeseburgers, and hard learned life lessons.  In the end, â€œLaboratories of Our Youthâ€ is a story about our shared desire to understand the world around us, finally grasping that there are no easy answers, and that though the data may seem cryptic, the research is worth it in the end.   

_____________________________________

As a team, we've hit the ground running. The production is well on it's way, with casting completed, rehearsals in progress and the down payment on our lease with The Complex, a theater located in Hollywood already paid for. With your help, we will have the necessary funds to pay for costumes, props, set pieces, stage makeup, theater rental costs, advertising, transportation, scripts and any number of other costs.


The key crew has already contributed $1500 to the production because we truly believe that if you're not wiling to invest in yourself, then why should anyone else? This money, along with $3000 from private investors, puts us incredibly close to our goal of $7000. That's where you come in. Any and all contributors you can make will go directly to making this play ready to go on opening night!

story:
Short Summary

I am a local writer and community worker, coworking with a fantastic group of people, many of whom were involved in the Survived project this May.  I also run Seasonally Effected an open mic night for creatives at the Dot Cafe in Rochester.

The Skywatcher will be an exciting mix of interactive, site specific theatre and scavenger hunting around the City of Rochester.  The audience will visit six scenes, in different Rochester locations, each based on a piece of classic science fiction stories.  They will also solve puzzles, explore and have loads of fun on the way.  We love Rochester and think this is a great way to share this with other people.

By supporting this event, you will help us to create printed materials and fund additional props, costumes and artwork.   This will enhance the audience experience and help us to run a fantastic event.    

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are looking for any amount up to £2000 to contribute towards running the event.    Some of this will pay for printed materials, but the majority will be used for props, costumes and any special effects that we can get our hands on!
  • We have a range of perks available for funders, ranging from props used during the event to advertising and making a business part of the event.
  • The event will be running whatever funding we receive, any funding raised will be divided amongst the six scenes to give each a small budget for costume and props.  

The Impact

  • By supporting this project, you will do a bit (or a lot) to help make Rochester an even more exciting, creative place.  We hope this will spark people's imaginations and introduce people to some of the lesser known landmarks, businesses and sites. 
  • Our experience from the Survived project, has helped us put together a strong team of creatives who will be working tirelessly to develop The Skywatcher and make it a fresh and entertaining show.
  • Most of all support this, because someones got to find out what those lights were over the castle! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us with money there are other ways you could help:

  • Let people know about the campaign and the event by sharing this page.
  • Or contact me if you would like to donate any art work, props or time at: theskywatcher2013@gmail.com  

What do you believe?
